\chapter*{Introduction}

The aim of this work is to introduce the reader to Gröbner-bases theory,
which was developed by Bruno Buchberger's during his doctoral thesis
on the direction of Wolfgang Gröbner in 1965. Years after a period
of few repercussions, Gröbner bases theory was rediscovered in 1985
by the computer-science and the mathematical community, who needed
of algebraic computation. Although applications of the theory may
be found in many contexts, we focus our attention on the ring of polynomials
and algebraic structures. The aim of the project is to reproduce a
classical introduction to the Gröbner theory and its application to
ring of polynomials. Chapter 1 has the necessary background for the
developing of the theory, whereas Chapter 2 starts developing the
theory from its basis, relation theory and term orders. Chapter 3
contains the main theorems and algorithms concerning Gröbner bases;
among these results, Gröbner basis existence and Buchberger's Algorithm
are the leading ones. Finally, Chapter 4 ends with some application
and specializations of the previously developed. Moreover, every algorithm
is given with an example. Since Gröbner basis have been in the mathematical
community for a while, plenty of literature, and articles, may be
found related with this topic, in particular, what has been here presented
consists of a compilation of book \cite{book-bueno-Grobner_Bases}
and article \cite{paper1985multidimensional}, which contains most
of the results up to that time. The reader is advised to check the
above citations for further learning.

\chapter{Notation and Preliminaries\label{chap:Notation-and-Initials}}

We provide a list of notation and word list which will be used all
along the text.

For a given set $X$, the collection of all possible subsets of $X$
is denoted by $\mathcal{P}\left(X\right)$, and is called \textbf{power
set} of $X$. \nomenclature{$\mathcal{P}\left(X\right)$}{power set of $X$}\index{power set of X@power set of \textbf{$X$}}

Let $X$ be a set. For $A\in\mathcal{P}\left(X\right)$, denote by
$\overline{A}$ the complement of $A$ in $X$, that is, $A\cup\overline{A}=X$.
We define a binary operation in $\bigtriangleup$ on $\mathcal{P}\left(X\right)$
by setting$\mathcal{P}\left(X\right)$ 
\[
A\bigtriangleup B=\left(A\cap\overline{B}\right)\cup\left(B\cap\overline{A}\right)
\]
for $A,B\in\mathcal{P}\left(X\right)$. The set $A\bigtriangleup B$
is called the \textbf{symmetric difference} of $A$ and $B$, or the
\textbf{union without the intersection} of $A$ and $B$.\textbf{
\nomenclature{$A\bigtriangleup B$}{symmetric difference or union without intersection of $A$ and $B$}\index{symmetric difference}\index{union without the intersection}}

We denote by $\mathcal{P}_{fin}\left(X\right)$ \textbf{the set of
all finite subsets of} $X$.\textbf{ \index{the set of all finite subsets of X}}\nomenclature{$\mathcal{P}_{fin}\left(X\right)$}{set of all finite subsets of $X$}For
a finite set $A$, $\left|A\right|$ denotes the\textbf{ \nomenclature{$\left|A\right|$}{cardinal of the set $A$}\index{cardinal}cardinal
}of $A$, i.e., the number of elements of $A$. 
\begin{defn}
A method to construct a mathematical object, whose existence is known,
in finitely many steps from other objects that it depends upon is
called an \textbf{algorithm} \index{algorithm}. When verifying an
algorithm, one must prove that it \textit{terminates} after finitely
many steps for every input as specified and that it performs that
task \textit{correctly}, i.e., it outputs an object that has the desired
properties. A \textbf{loop} \textbf{invariant} \index{loop invariant}is
a mathematical statement or mathematical object that remains unaffected
by the execution of the loop in question. 
\end{defn}

\begin{defn}
Let $M$ be a non-empty set. Recall that $M\times M$ denotes the
set of all ordered pairs $\left(a,b\right)$ of elements $a,b\in M$.
A (\textbf{binary}) \textbf{relation} \index{relation}\index{binary relation}\nomenclature{$r$}{(binary) relation} on
$M$ is a subset $r$ of $M\times M$. The relation \index{diagonal}\nomenclature{$\Delta\left(M\right)$}{diagonal of $M$}
\[
\Delta\left(M\right)=\left\{ \left(a,a\right)\mid a\in M\right\} ,
\]

is called the \textbf{diagonal} of $M$. If $r,s$ are relations on
$M$, then 
\[
r^{-1}=\left\{ \left(a,b\right)\mid\left(b,a\right)\in r\right\} 
\]
is the\textbf{inverse relation} \index{inverse relation} \nomenclature{$r^{-1}$}{inverse relation}
of $r$, and 
\[
r\circ s=\left\{ \left(a,c\right)\mid\mbox{exists }b\in M:\,\left(a,b\right)\in r,\left(b,c\right)\in s\right\} 
\]

is the\textbf{\nomenclature{$r\circ s$}{product of two relations}\index{product of two relations}\index{composition of two relations}product,
or composition,} of the two relations $r$ and $s$. If $r\subseteq s$,
then $s$ is called an extension of $r$. We say that a relation $r$
has \textbf{ \nomenclature{$r\_s$}{ strict part}\index{strict part}strict
part }$r_{s}$ meaning that $r_{s}=r\setminus r^{-1}$. 
\end{defn}

\begin{rem}
For a relation $r$ on $M$, given two elements $a,b\in M$, we write
$a\,r\,b$ instead of $\left(a,b\right)\in r$. 
\end{rem}

\begin{defn}
Let $r$ be a relation on $M$. Then $r$ is called
\begin{enumerate}
\item \textbf{reflexive \index{relation!reflexive}}if $\Delta\left(M\right)\subseteq r$,
\\
 
\item \textbf{symmetric \index{relation!symmetric}}if $r\subseteq r^{-1}$,
\\
 
\item \textbf{transitive \index{relation!transitive}}if $r\circ r\subseteq r$,
\\
 
\item \textbf{antisymmetric \index{relation!antisymmetric}} if $r\cap r^{-1}\subseteq\Delta\left(M\right)$,
\\
 
\item \textbf{connex \index{relation!connex}}if $r\cup r^{-1}=M\times M$,\\
 
\item \textbf{irreflexive \index{relation!irreflexive}}if $\Delta\left(M\right)\cap r=\emptyset$,
\\
 
\item \textbf{strictly \index{relation!strictly antisymmetric}antisymmetric}
if $r\cap r^{-1}=\emptyset$, \\
 
\item an \textbf{equivalence} \textbf{relation \index{relation!equivalence relation}}on
$M$ if $r$ is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive, \\
 
\item a \textbf{quasi-order \index{relation!quasi-order}}on $M$ if $r$
is reflexive and transitive,\\
 
\item a \textbf{partial} \textbf{order} \index{relation!partial order}on
$M$ if $r$ is reflexive, transitive, and antisymmetric,\\
 
\item a (\textbf{linear}) \textbf{order }\index{order}\textbf{\index{relation!linear order}}on
$M$ if $r$ is a connex partial order on $M$, and\\
 
\item a \textbf{\index{relation!linear quasi-order}linear} \textbf{quasi-order}
on $M$ if $r$ is a connex quasi-order on $M$. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{defn}

\begin{rem}
For a symmetric relation, it is also true that $r=r^{-1}$. However,
for a transitive relation $r=r\circ r$ is not necessarily true, for
instance if $r=\left\{ \left(a,b\right)\right\} $, then $r\circ r=\emptyset$. 
\end{rem}

\begin{rem}
We know that the natural ordering $\leq$ on $\mathbb{N}$ satisfies
the trichotomy law; that is, if $<$ is the strict part of $\leq$
and $a,b\in\mathbb{N}$, one and only one of the conditions $a<b$,
$b<a$ and $a=b$ is satisfied. Hence, if a relation $r$ is connex
and antisymmetric, then $r$ satisfies the trichotomy law. 
\end{rem}

\begin{example}
~ 
\end{example}

\begin{enumerate}
\item Given a set $X$, inclusion of sets $\subseteq$ is a partial order
on $\mathcal{P}\left(X\right)$. \\
 
\item Divisibility relation is a partial order on $\mathbb{N}$.\\
 
\item less-or-equal $\leq$ is a linear order on $\mathbb{N},\mathbb{Z},\mathbb{Q},\mathbb{R}$.\\
 
\end{enumerate}
\begin{defn}
If $r$ is a relation on $M$, we say that $\left(M,r\right)$ is
a \textbf{partially ordered set} (\textbf{totally ordered set}) if
$r$ is a partial order (a linear order). When we refer to a total
ordered subset of a partially ordered set, we use the term \textbf{$r$-chain}. 
\end{defn}

\begin{defn}
A \textbf{partition \index{partition}} of a set $M$, is a subset
$\Pi$ of the power set $\mathcal{P}\left(M\right)$ of $M$ such
that the elements of $\Pi$ are pairwise disjoint, non-empty subsets
of $M$ whose union equals $M$. A subset $S$ of $M$ is called a
\textbf{system of unique representatives \index{system of unique representatives}
}for the partition $\Pi$ of $M$ if $P\cap S$ contains exactly one
element for each $P\in\Pi$.

Whenever $\sim$ is an equivalence relation on $M$, then 
\[
\left[a\right]=\left\{ b\in M\mid b\sim a\right\} 
\]
is called the \textbf{equivalence class \index{equivalence class}}
of $a$ with respect to $\sim$, and the set 
\[
\left\{ \left[a\right]\mid a\in M\right\} 
\]
of all equivalence classes is denoted by $M/\sim$. \nomenclature{$M/\sim$}{quotient of $M$  by the equivalence relation $\sim$} 
\end{defn}

\begin{defn}
Let $r$ be a relation on $M$ with\textbf{ }strict\textbf{ }part\textbf{
}$r_{s}$ and let $N\subseteq M$. Then an element $a\in N$ is called
$r$\textbf{-minimal \index{r-minimal}\index{r-maximal}}($r$\textbf{-maximal})
in $N$ if there is no $b\in N$ with $br_{s}a$ (with $ar_{s}b$).
\\
 A \textbf{strictly} \textbf{descending} (\textbf{strictly} \textbf{ascending})
\index{strictly descending}\textbf{\index{strictly ascending}}$r$-chain
in $M$ is an infinite sequence $\familia[a][n][\mathbb{N}]$ of elements
of $M$ such that $a_{n+1}r_{s}a_{n}$ (such that $a_{n}r_{s}a_{n+1})$
for all $n\in\mathbb{N}$. \\
 The relation $r$ is called \textbf{well-founded} (\textbf{noetherian})
\textbf{\index{well-founded}}\index{noetherian}if every non-empty
subset $N$ of $M$ has a $r$-minimal (a $r$-maximal) element. \\
 The relation $r$ is a \textbf{well-order \index{well-order}}on
$M$ if $r$ is a well-founded linear order on $M$. 
\end{defn}

\begin{rem}
An element $a$ is $r$-minimal ($r$-maximal) in $N$ iff $bra$
implies $arb$ (iff $arb$ implies $bra$) for $b\in N$. 
\end{rem}

\begin{prop}
\label{prop:4.31 iff well-founded descending chain}Let $r$ be a
relation. Then $r$ is well-founded (noetherian) iff there are no
strictly descending (no strictly ascending) $r$-chains in $M$. 
\end{prop}

\begin{proof}
If $\familia[a][n][\mathbb{N}]$ is a strictly descending $r$-chain
in $M$, then the set 
\[
N=\left\{ a_{n}\mid n\in\mathbb{N}\right\} 
\]
has no $r$-minimal element. Conversely, suppose $\emptyset\neq N\subseteq M$
and has no $r$-minimal element. Then the set 
\[
A_{a}=\left\{ b\in N\mid br_{s}a\right\} 
\]
is not empty for each $a\in N$. The axiom of choice, applied to the
family $\left\{ A_{a}\right\} _{a\in N}$, provides a function 
\[
f:N\rightarrow\cup_{a\in N}A_{a}\subseteq N,
\]
with $f\left(a\right)r_{s}a$ for all $a\in N$. Let $a_{0}\in N$.
Now the sequence $\familia[a][n][\mathbb{N}]$ defined recursively
by $a_{n+1}=f\left(a_{n}\right)$ forms a strictly descending $r$-chain.
The noetherian case is handled analogously. 
\end{proof}
\begin{defn}
\label{def:Closure}Let $r$ be a relation on $M$. Then $r\cup r^{-1}$
is obviously the smallest relation extending $r$ that is symmetric
on $M$. It is called the\textbf{ \index{symmetric closure}symmetric}
\textbf{closure} of $r$. \\
 We define the \textbf{powers \label{def:power of a relation}}$r^{n}$
with $n\in\mathbb{N}$ recursively by 
\[
r^{0}=\Delta\left(M\right)\mbox{ and }r^{n+1}=r\circ r^{n}.
\]
Then we call 
\[
r^{+}=\cup_{n=1}^{\infty}r^{n},
\]
the\textbf{ \nomenclature{$r^{+}$}{transitive closure of $r$}\index{transitive closure}transitive}
\textbf{closure} of $r$, and 
\[
r^{*}=\cup_{n=0}^{\infty}r^{n}=r^{0}\cup r^{+},
\]
the\textbf{ reflexive-transitive closure \index{reflexive-transitive closure}\nomenclature{$r^{*}$}{reflexive-transitive closure}}of
$r$. 
\end{defn}

\begin{rem}
One can easily prove, by induction, that a pair $\left(a,c\right)\in r^{n}$
with $n\geq2$ if and only if there exists a sequence $\variables[b][n-1]$
so that $arb_{1}rb_{2}r...rb_{n-1}rc$.

We now show that $r^{+}$ is in fact transitive: If $\left(a,c\right)\in r^{+}\circ r^{+}$,
then there exist $b\in M$ so that $\left(a,b\right),\left(b,c\right)\in r^{+}$;
thus there exists $m,n\geq1$ such that $\left(a,b\right)\in r^{m},\left(b,c\right)\in r^{n}$,
and so, by the previous observation, there exist sequences $\variables[a][m-1]$
and $\variables[b][n-1]$ so that 
\[
ara_{1}ra_{2}r...ra_{m-1}brb_{1}rb_{2}r...rb_{n-1}rc.
\]
By joining the sequence, we have a sequence of $m+n-1$ elements,
which shows that $\left(a,c\right)\in r^{m+n-1}\subseteq r^{+}$,
as desired.

Note that $r\subseteq r^{+}$ by definition and if $r$ is transitive,
then $r^{N}\subseteq r$ for all $N\geq1$, and so $r^{+}\subseteq r$,
that is, if $r$ is transitive, then $r=r^{+}$.

We now show that $r^{*}$ is transitive (note that is reflexive by
definition): If $r^{*}$ is not transitive, then there exist $\left(a,b\right),\left(b,c\right)\in r^{*}$
but $\left(a,c\right)\notin r^{*}$. Hence $a\neq b\neq c$, and so
$\left(a,b\right),\left(b,c\right)\in r^{+}$. Because $r^{+}$ is
transitive, $\left(a,c\right)\in r^{+}\subseteq r^{*}$, a contradiction.

In particular, if $r$ is a symmetric relation, then $r^{+}$ and
$r^{*}$ are also symmetric. This is immediate from the fact that
if $a,b\in M$ and $ar^{*}b$, then either $a=b$ or $ar^{+}b$ and
so there exists a chain 
\[
ar\variables[a][n-1][r]rb\,\,\left(n\geq2,\variables[a][n-1]\in M\right),
\]
and since $r$ is symmetric, we have 
\[
bra_{n-1}r...ra_{2}ra_{1}ra,
\]
that is, $\left(b,a\right)\in r^{n}\subseteq r^{+}\subseteq r^{*}$. 
\end{rem}

\begin{defn}
Given a quasi-order $\quasi$ on a set $M$, the relation $\rel$
on $M$ defined as $\quasi\cap\left(\quasi\right)^{-1}$ (that is,
$a\rel b$ iff $a\quasi b$ and $b\quasi a$) is an equivalence relation
which we shall refer to as the \textbf{associated equivalence relation}
of $\quasi$.\textbf{ \index{associated equivalence relation}}Whenever
$N\subseteq M$ and $\rel$ is the associated equivalence relation
of a quasi-order $\quasi$, we may restrict $\rel$ to $N$, so that
$\left[a\right]\cap N$ for $a\in N$ are the equivalent classes in
$N$. In case $a$ is $\quasi$-minimal, we call the restricted equivalent
class $\left[a\right]\cap N$, \textbf{min-class} of $N$. \index{min-class of $N$} 
\end{defn}

\begin{defn}
A set $M$ together with a\textbf{ \index{binary operation}binary}
\textbf{operation} $*:M\times M\rightarrow M$ is said to be a \textbf{monoid}
\textbf{\index{monoid}}if $*$ verifies the following axioms:
\begin{enumerate}
\item $*$ is \index{associative}\textbf{associative}, i.e., $\left(a*b\right)*c=a*\left(b*c\right)$
for all $a,b,c\in M$, and 
\item $*$ has \index{identity element}\textbf{identity} \textbf{element},
i.e., there exists $e\in M$ with $e*a=a$ for all $a\in M$. 
\end{enumerate}
We represent a monoid by the pair $\left(M,*\right)$ and say that
it is an \textbf{\index{abelian monoid}abelian monoid} if in addition
$*$ is\textbf{ \index{commutative}commutative}, i.e., $a*b=b*a$
for all $a,b\in M$.

Instead of symbol $*$, we will use $+$ and $\cdot$, which are called
additive and multiplicative notation. When using the additive notation,
we write $0$ for the identity element, whereas when using the multiplicative
notation, we write $1$ instead. 
\end{defn}

\begin{defn}
Let $\left(M,+\right)$ be an abelian monoid and let $\leq$ be a
linear order on $M$ with strict part $<$. Then we say $\leq$ is
\textbf{admissible \index{admissible}}if for all $a,b,c\in M$,
\begin{enumerate}
\item $0\leq a$, and\\
 
\item $a<b$ implies $a+c<b+c$. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{defn}

If $\leq$ is an admissible order on $M$, then we call $\left(M,\leq\right)$
an \index{ordered monoid}\textbf{ordered monoid}.
\begin{defn}
A \textbf{group\index{group}} is a monoid $\left(M,*\right)$ for
which all elements are invertible, i.e., for all $a\in M$ there exist
$b\in M$ such that $a*b=e=b*a$. In this case $b$ is said to be
the inverse of $a$ and also denoted by $a^{-1}$. An abelian group
is an abelian monoid for which all elements are invertible.\\
 A subset $N$ of a group $\left(M,*\right)$ is called a subgroup
of $\left(M,*\right)$ if $\left(N,*\right)$ is also a group. 
\end{defn}

\begin{defn}
A \textbf{ring} \textbf{(with identity)\index{ring (with identity)}}
$R$ is a triple $\left(R,+,\cdot\right)$ for which $\left(R,+\right)$
is an abelian group, $\left(R\setminus\left\{ 0\right\} ,\cdot\right)$
a monoid and $\cdot$ is distributive with respect to $+$, that is,
for all $a,b,c\in R$ we have 
\begin{eqnarray*}
a\cdot(b+c) & = & (a\cdot b)+(a\cdot c)\mbox{ (left distributivity)}\\
(b+c)\cdot a & = & (b\cdot a)+(c\cdot a)\mbox{ (right distributivity)}
\end{eqnarray*}
An element $0\neq a\in R$ is said to be a divisor of $0$ if there
exist an element $0\neq b\in R$ so that $a\cdot b=0$. A ring $\left(R,+,\cdot\right)$
is said to be
\begin{itemize}
\item a \textbf{commutative} \textbf{ring \index{commutative ring}}if $\left(R,\cdot\right)$
is an abelian monoid.\\
 
\item an \textbf{integral domain \index{integral domain}}if $\left(R,\cdot\right)$
is an abelian monoid and $R$ has no zero divisors.\\
 
\item a \textbf{division ring} \index{division ring}if $\left(R\setminus\left\{ 0\right\} ,\cdot\right)$
is a group.\\
 
\item a \textbf{field \index{field}}if $\left(R\setminus\left\{ 0\right\} ,\cdot\right)$
is an abelian group. 
\end{itemize}
We will say that $R$ is a ring instead of $\left(R,+,\cdot\right)$
whenever no possible confusion occur. 
\end{defn}

\begin{defn}
A\textbf{ \index{vector space}vector space} over a field $K$ is
a triple $\left(V,+,\cdot\right)$ , where $V$ is a set, $\left(V,+\right)$
is an abelian group and $\cdot:K\times V\rightarrow V$ is called
scalar operation, and verifies
\begin{enumerate}
\item $a\cdot\left(b\cdot v\right)=\left(ab\right)\cdot v$, where the product
$ab$ is considered in $K$\\
 
\item $a\cdot\left(u+v\right)=a\cdot u+a\cdot v$,\\
 
\item $\left(a+b\right)\cdot v=a\cdot v+b\cdot v$,\\
 
\item $1\cdot v=v$, where $1$ denotes the identity of the field, 
\end{enumerate}
\end{defn}

for all $a,b\in K$, $u,v\in V$.
\begin{defn}
For a vector space $\left(V,+,\cdot\right)$ over a field $K$, we
say that a set $B\subseteq V$ is a \textbf{generating set \index{generating set}}if
for all $v\in V$, there exist $\variables[b]\in V$, $\variables[\lambda]\in K$
so that 
\[
v=\lineal[\lambda][b].
\]
We say that $B$ is \textbf{linearly independent \index{linearly independent}}
if the relation 
\[
\lineal[\lambda][b][m]=0,
\]
for some $\variables[b][m]\in B$, $\variables[\lambda][m]\in K$,
implies $\variables[\lambda][m][=]=0$. We say that $B\subseteq V$
is a \textbf{basis \index{basis}}if it is a linearly independent
generating set. 
\end{defn}

\begin{rem}
It is known that every vector space has a basis. The cardinal of such
basis is referred as the \textbf{dimension \index{dimension}}of the
vectorial space. 
\end{rem}

\begin{defn}
A subset $I$ of $R$ is called an \textbf{ideal}\textbf{\textit{
\index{ideal}}}of $R$ if $\left(I,+\right)$ is a subgroup of $\left(R,+\right)$
and for all $x\in I$, $r\in R$ we have $x\cdot r\in I$ and $r\cdot x\in I$.
An ideal $I$ is said to be \textbf{generated \index{ideal generated by the set F}}\nomenclature{$\ideal[F]$}{ideal generated by $F$}by
the set $F\subseteq R$, and write $I=\ideal[F]$, if $I$ is the
intersection of all the ideals of $R$ containing $F$. If $I=\ideal[F]$
for a finite set $F$, we say that $I$ is \textbf{finitely generated};\textbf{
\index{finitely generated}}in this case, if $F=\left\{ \variables[x][m]\right\} $,
then 
\[
I=\left\{ a_{1}x_{1}b_{1}+...+a_{m}x_{m}b_{m}\mid r_{i},b_{i}\in R\,i=1,...,m\right\} .
\]

An ideal $I$ generated by a unique element is said a\textbf{ \index{principal ideal}principal
ideal}. A domain $R$ so that every ideal is principal is called \textbf{principal
ideal domain \index{principal ideal domain}\index{P.I.D.}} (\textbf{P.I.D.}). 
\end{defn}

\begin{defn}
Given a ring $R$, the set 
\begin{eqnarray*}
R\left[\variables[X]\right] & = & \{\suma[i][1][k]a_{i}X_{1}^{i_{1}}\cdot...\cdot X_{n}^{i_{n}}\mid a_{i}\in R,i_{j}\in\mathbb{N}\\
 &  & \mbox{for }j=1,...,n,\,i=1,...,k\}
\end{eqnarray*}
is called the\textbf{ \index{polynomial ring}\nomenclature{$R\left[\variables[X]\right]$}{polynomial ring over $R$ in the indeterminates $X_1,X_2,...,X_n$}polynomial
ring} over $R$ in the indeterminates $\variables[X]$. Elements of
$R\left[\variables[X]\right]$ are called polynomials whereas symbols
$X_{j}^{i_{j}}$ are called the powers of $X_{j}$, and by convention,
$X_{j}^{0}=1$ and $X_{j}^{k}\cdot X_{j}^{r}=X_{k}^{k+r}$. 
\end{defn}

\begin{rem}
A basic fact is that if $R$ has no zero divisors, then the polynomial
ring $R\left[\variables[X]\right]$ is a ring (with identity) without
zero divisors. 
\end{rem}

\begin{defn}
In the ring $R\left[X\right]$, every polynomial is of the form $f=\suma[i][0][d]a_{i}X^{i}$
for some $d\in\mathbb{N}$. We denote $d$ by $\deg\left(f\right)$,
and say that $d$ is the \textbf{degree \index{degree}}\nomenclature{$\deg (f)$}{degree of the polynomial $f$}of
the polynomial $f$. 
\end{defn}

\begin{thm}[Division Algorithm]
\label{thm:Division algorithm K x}Let $R$ be a ring (with identity)
and let $f,g\in R\left[X\right]$ with $g\neq0$ and $\deg\left(f\right)\geq\deg\left(g\right)$.
Suppose that $g=\polinomio[a][d][X]$ where $a_{d}$ has inverse in
$R$, then there exist unique polynomials $q,r\in R\left[X\right]$
so that $f=qg+r$ with $r=0$ or $r\neq0$ and $\deg\left(r\right)<\deg\left(g\right)$. 
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
See \cite{book_profesor_Ideals_varieties_and_algorithms}, page 39. 
\end{proof}
\begin{rem}
The polynomials $g,q,r$ of the division algorithm are called divisor,
quotient, and remainder of the division, respectively.
\end{rem}

\begin{defn}
Given a ring $R$, we say that $R$ is \textbf{Noetherian\index{Noetherian}}
if satisfies \textbf{A.C.C.\index{A.C.C.}} (the ascending chain condition)
on ideals, that is, given a $\subseteq$-chain on the set $M$ of
ideals of $R$, 
\[
\variables[I][][\subseteq]\subseteq...
\]
there exist $N\in\mathbb{N}$ such that 
\[
I_{N}=I_{N+1}=I_{N+2}=...
\]

We say that $R$ is \textbf{Artinian\index{Artinian}} if it satisfies
\textbf{D.C.C.\index{D.C.C.}} (the descending chain condition) on
ideals, that is, given a $\supseteq$-chain on the set $M$ of ideals
of $R$, 
\[
\variables[I][][\supseteq]\supseteq...
\]
there exist $N\in\mathbb{N}$ such that 
\[
I_{N}=I_{N+1}=I_{N+2}=...
\]
\end{defn}

\begin{rem}
Note that by Proposition \ref{prop:4.31 iff well-founded descending chain},
a ring $R$ is said Noetherian (Artinian) iff the relation $\subseteq$
is noetherian (well-founded). 
\end{rem}

\begin{thm}[Hilbert's basis Theorem]
If $R$ in noetherian, then $R\left[X_{1}\right]$ is also noetherian
(and so is $R\left[\variables[X]\right]$). 
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
See \cite{reid1995undergraduate}, page 54. 
\end{proof}
\begin{defn}
Let $I$ be an ideal of $R\left[\variables[X]\right],$ then the equivalence
relation $\equiv_{I}$ defined by 
\[
f\equiv_{I}f\mbox{ iff }f-g\in I
\]
is called\textbf{ \nomenclature{$\equiv_{I}$}{congruece relation modulo $I$}\index{congruence relation}congruence
relation} modulo $I$ on $R\left[\variables[X]\right].$ The set $R\left[\variables[X]\right]/\equiv_{I}$
has structure of ring, and it is called \textbf{residue class ring
\index{residue class ring}\nomenclature{$R\left[\variables[X]\right]/\equiv_{I}$}{residue class ring of the ring of polynomials}}of
the ring of polynomials $R\left[\variables[X]\right]$. 
\end{defn}

\begin{rem}
Whenever we write $R$ or $K$, we understand that $R$ is a \underline{commutative}\textit{
}ring with identity and $K$ is a\textit{ }\underline{field}. 
\end{rem}


\section{Simple Explanation of Gröbner Bases \label{sec:Explanation of Gr=00003D0000F6bner bases}}

An informal introduction of Gröbner basis is now performed in order
to provide a simple idea.

Given an ideal $I$ on $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$, we are interested
in discerning whether a polynomial $f\in I$ or $f\notin I$ \index{membership problem}(membership
problem). By Hilbert's basis Theorem, $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
is noetherian, that is, every ideal is finitely generated, and so
$I=\ideal[F]$ for some finite family $F\subseteq K\left[\variables[X]\right]$.
Best scenario, $f\in F$ and we are done. In other case, if $f\in I$
and $f\notin F$, then $f=\lineal[a][f][m][+]$ for some $f_{i}\in F$
and $a_{i}\in K$. The idea of subtracting elements of $F$ until
the element $f$ is \textit{reduced} \textit{to} $0$, conforms the
intuitive idea of the theory. Moreover, if we can't reduce $f$ to
$0$ by subtracting elements of $f$ we expect $f\notin I$, and so
$f\in I$ iff $f$ reduces to $0$ modulo $F$ (see Definition \ref{def:reduction modulo }).
However, in opposition to the univariate case, in which the division
algorithm provides uniques residues, when subtracting form $f$ elements
$f_{i}\in F$ multiplied by scalars in $K$, one may reach different
results depending on the election of the $f_{i}$. For instance, take
$f=x^{3}y\in K\left[x,y\right]$ and $F=\left\{ f_{1},f_{3}\right\} $
where 
\begin{align*}
f_{1}:= & 3x^{2}y+2xy+y+9x^{2}+5x-3,\\
f_{3}:= & x^{3}y+x^{2}y+3x^{3}+2x^{2}.
\end{align*}
By subtracting $f_{1}$ to $f$ several times, we achieve the polynomial
$g_{1}=\frac{1}{9}xy+\frac{2}{9}y-3x^{3}+\frac{1}{3}x^{2}+\frac{19}{9}x-\frac{2}{3}$;
however, when subtracting $f_{3}$ to $f$, we get $g_{3}=\frac{1}{2}xy+\frac{1}{2}y-3x^{2}+x^{2}+\frac{3}{2}x-\frac{3}{2}$.
We notice that $g_{1}\neq g_{3}$, but also $g_{1},g_{3}$ are \textit{residues}
of $f=x^{3}y$ with respect to $F$, that is, they can no longer be
reduced by subtracting elements in $F$.

A Gröbner basis for an ideal $I$, is a finite family $G\subseteq K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
such that a polynomial $f\in I$, if and only if, $f$ can be reduced
to $0$ by subtracting elements of $G$. An immediate characterization,
is that $G$ is a Gröbner basis if and only if the reduction of provides
unique residues (on the further theory, unique normal form, see Definition
\ref{unique nromal form definition}). The fundamental theorem of
the theory, Gröbner basis existence, claims that every ideal $I\subseteq K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
has a Gröbner basis. Another important result, Buchberger's algorithm,
provides an algorithm to compute such a basis from a finite set $F$
generating the ideal $I$, i.e., provided a finite set $F$ such that
$I=\ideal[F]$.

As the reader may guess, Gröbner-bases theory generalizes the Euclidean
algorithm from the univariate case to the multivariate, and from a
single divisor to a finite family.

Our motivational problem for Gröbner-bases theory, is the problem
of effectively computing on $K\left[\variables[X]\right]/I$ since
membership of a polynomial $f$ in a class $\left[g\right]$ is equivalent
to membership of $f-g$ on the ideal $I$. 
\begin{rem}
\label{rem: f_1 f_2  f_3}In order to provide this text with useful
examples, we selected from \cite{paper1985multidimensional} those
who are of our interest. In particular, the set $F=\left\{ f_{1},f_{2},f_{3}\right\} $
with 
\begin{eqnarray*}
f_{1} & = & 3x^{2}y+2xy+y+9x^{2}+5x-3,\\
f_{3} & = & x^{3}y+x^{2}y+3x^{3}+2x^{2},\\
f_{2} & = & 2x^{3}y-xy+6x^{3}-2x^{2}-3x+3.
\end{eqnarray*}
will appear repeatedly in the examples given. 
\end{rem}


\chapter{Initials}

This chapter is divided into 6 sections, in which the fundamental
notions relating Gröbner-bases theory are exposed. Sections \ref{sec:Dickson-relations}
and \ref{sec:Reduction-relations} introduce the reader to two types
of relations, Dickson's relations and reduction relation, as well
as some properties. Section \ref{sec:Computations-and-Algorithmics}
presents some aspects concerning \textit{computer }computability and
algorithms. Finally, sections \ref{sec:Term-Orders}, \ref{sec:The-induced-quasi-order}
and \ref{sec:Polynomial-reductions} specializes to relations on the
ring of polynomials $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$, \textit{context}
in which Gröbner-bases theory will be developed.

\section{Dickson's relations\label{sec:Dickson-relations}}

We start the section with a definition. 
\begin{defn}
Let $\quasi$ be a quasi-order on $M$ and let $N\subseteq M$. Then
a subset $B$ of $N$ is called a\textbf{ \index{Dickson basis}Dickson}
\textbf{basis}, or simply a basis of $N$ w.r.t. (with respect to)
$\quasi$ if for every $a\in N$ there exist some $b\in B$ with $b\quasi a$.
We say that $\quasi$ has the \index{Dickson property}\textbf{\index{Dickson quasi-order}Dickson
property}, or that is a \textbf{Dickson quasi-order}, if every subset
$N$ of $M$ has a finite basis w.r.t. $\quasi$. 
\end{defn}

\begin{lem}
Every well-founded linear quasi-order has the Dickson property. In
particular, every well-order has the Dickson property. 
\end{lem}

\begin{proof}
Assume that $\quasi$ is a linear quasi-order on a set $M$. If $N$
is a subset of $M$, then $N$ has a minimal element $b$. Because
the relation $\quasi$ is connex, we have $b\quasi a$ or $a\quasi b$
for every $a\in M$. Given that $b$ is minimal, $a\quasi b$ implies
$b\quasi a$ and the set $B=\left\{ b\right\} $ is a basis of $\quasi$. 
\end{proof}
Indeed, we will further see that every Dickson quasi-order is well-founded. 
\begin{prop}
\label{prop:4.42 Dickson quasi order equivalence}Let $\quasi$ be
a quasi-order on $M$ with associated equivalence relation $\sim$.
Then the following are equivalent:
\begin{enumerate}
\item $\quasi$ is a Dickson quasi-order,\\
 
\item whenever $\familia[a][n][\mathbb{N}]$ is a sequence of elements of
$M$, then there exist $i,j\in\mathbb{N}$ with $i<j$ and $a_{i}\quasi a_{j}$,\\
 
\item for every non-empty subset $N$ of $M$, the number of min-classes
in $N$ is finite and non-zero. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{prop}

\begin{proof}
\rom{1}$\Rightarrow$\rom{2}: Set $N=\left\{ a_{n}\mid n\in\mathbb{N}\right\} $
%		and let $B$ a finite basis of $N$. Take $j\in\mathbb{N}$ such that
 $j>i$ for all $i\in\mathbb{N}$ with $a_{i}\in B$. Then $a_{i}\quasi a_{j}$
for some $a_{i}\in B$ with $i<j$.

\rom{2}$\Rightarrow$\rom{3}: Suppose there exist infinitely many
min-classes in some non-empty subset $N$ of $M$. Using the axiom
of choice, we get an infinite sequence $\familia[a][n][\mathbb{N}]$
of pairwise $\sim$-inequivalent minimal elements of $N$. By \rom{2},
$a_{i}\quasi a_{j}$ for some $i<j$. From the minimality of $a_{j}$,
we conclude that $a_{j}\quasi a_{i}$ and so $a_{i}\sim a_{j}$, a
contradiction. On the other hand, if $N$ has no minimal element,
then we can produce a strictly descending $\quasi$-chain as in the
proof of Proposition \ref{prop:4.31 iff well-founded descending chain},
contradicting \rom{2}.

\rom{3}$\Rightarrow$\rom{1}: Let $N$ be a non-empty subset of
$M$. Choosing one element of each of the finitely many min-classes,
we form a finite subset $B$ of $N$ such that each $b\in B$ is $\quasi$-minimal
in $N$. We claim that $B$ is a basis of $N$. If $a\in N$ then
\[
N'=\left\{ d\in N\mid d\quasi a\right\} 
\]
is a non-empty set since $a\in N'$ and so there exists $c\in N'$
that is $\quasi$-minimal in $N'$. In addition, if $c'\in N$ is
such that $c'\quasi c\quasi a$, then $c'\quasi a$ and by minimality
of $c$, $c\quasi c'$, that is, $c$ is $\quasi$-minimal in $N$
too. Hence, $c\sim b$ for some $b\in B$ and $b\quasi c\quasi a$,
as required. 
\end{proof}
\begin{cor}
\label{cor:Uninique minimal finite bassis}Let $\leq$ be a Dickson
partial order on $M$. Then every non-empty subset $N$ of $M$ has
a unique \textbf{\index{minimal finite basis}minimal finite basis
$B$}, i.e., a finite basis $B$ such that $B\subseteq C$ for all
other bases $C$ of $N$. In particular, $B$ consists of all minimal
elements of $N$. 
\end{cor}

\begin{proof}
From the above proposition, the set $B$ of all minimal elements of
$N$ forms a basis of $N$. Let now $C$ be another basis of $N$.
Then for every $b\in B$ there exists some $c\in C$ such that $c\leq b$,
and so $c=b$ by the minimality of $b$. This shows that $B\subseteq C$. 
\end{proof}
The following theorem is an immediate consequence of the condition
\rom{3} from the above proposition. 
\begin{thm}
Every Dickson quasi-order is well-founded. 
\end{thm}

\begin{rem}
If $\quasi$ is a Dickson's quasi-order on a set $M$, and $N=\left\{ a_{n}\right\} _{n\in\mathbb{N}}$
is an infinite subset of $M$, given $a_{i}\in N$ we define\textbf{
the set of superior elements of} $a_{i}$ as 
\[
S\left(a_{i}\right)=\left\{ a_{n}\in N\mid a_{i}\quasi a_{n}\right\} .
\]
If $B=\left\{ \variables[b][k]\right\} $ is a finite basis of $N$,
then $\cup_{j=1}^{k}S\left(b_{j}\right)=N$ is infinite, and so $S\left(b_{j}\right)$
has infinitely many elements for some $1\leq j\leq k$. As to simplify
the proof of the following result, we define $\mathbb{N}_{S\left(a_{i}\right)}$
as the set of indexes of elements in $S\left(a_{i}\right)$, that
is, $\mathbb{N}_{S\left(a_{i}\right)}=\left\{ n\in\mathbb{N}\mid a_{n}\in S\left(a_{i}\right)\right\} .$
For short, we simply write $S_{i}$ and $\mathbb{N}_{i}$ for the
sets $S\left(a_{i}\right)$ and $\mathbb{N}_{S\left(a_{i}\right)}.$
Clearly $\mathbb{N}_{i}$ and $S_{i}$ have the same cardinality. 
\end{rem}

\begin{prop}
\label{prop:4.45 descending chain Dikson quasi order}Let $\quasi$
be a Dickson quasi-order on $M$, and let $\familia[a][n][\mathbb{N}]$
be a sequence of elements of $M$. Then there exist a strictly ascending
sequence of natural numbers, $\left\{ n_{i}\right\} _{i\in\mathbb{N}}$
such that $a_{n_{i}}\quasi a_{n_{j}}$ for all $i<j$. 
\end{prop}

\begin{proof}
Along the proof, we will use the notation introduced in the previous
Remark. We define the sequence $\left\{ n_{i}\right\} _{i\in\mathbb{N}}$
recursively so that in the end it verifies
\begin{enumerate}
\item $a_{n_{i}}\quasi a_{n_{i+1}}$ for all $i\in\mathbb{N}$, and \\
 
\item for all $i\in\mathbb{N}$, the set $\mathbb{N}_{n_{i}}$ is infinite. 
\end{enumerate}
For $i=0$, we set $N=\left\{ a_{n}\mid n\in\mathbb{N}\right\} $
and using the previous remark, there exist a finite basis $B$ of
$N$ and $b_{j}\in B$ so that $S\left(b_{j}\right)$ is infinite.
Now, because $b_{j}\in N$, it is of the form $b_{j}=a_{m}$. We set
$n_{0}=m$ and clearly $\mathbb{N}_{n_{0}}=\mathbb{N}_{S\left(b_{j}\right)}$
is infinite, thus claim \rom{2} for $i=0$ follows.

Consider defined the sequence $n_{0},\variables[n][i]$ so that $a_{n_{j}}\quasi a_{n_{j+1}}$
for $0\leq j<i$ and $\mathbb{N}_{n_{j}}$ is infinite for $1\leq j\leq i$.
Now we have to define $a_{n_{i+1}}$ so it verifies $a_{n_{i}}\quasi a_{n_{i+1}}$
and $\mathbb{N}_{n_{i+1}}$ is infinite.

Since $\mathbb{N}_{n_{i}}$ is infinite, the sequence $N'=S_{n_{i}}$
is also infinite. Using the previous remark, now applied to $N'$,
there exists $b'_{j}$ in a finite basis of $N'$ so that $S'\left(b'_{j}\right)=\left\{ a_{n}\in N'\mid b'_{j}\quasi a_{n}\right\} $
is infinite. Because $n'_{j}\in N'=S_{n_{i}}$, $b'_{j}=a_{m'}$ for
some $m\in\mathbb{N}$ and $a_{n_{i}}\quasi a_{m'}$. Now we set $n_{i+1}=m$
and trivially $\mathbb{N}_{n_{i}+1}=\left\{ n\in\mathbb{N}\mid a_{n_{i+1}}=b'_{j}\quasi a_{n}\right\} $
is infinite since the set $S'\left(b'_{j}\right)$ is infinite and
$N'\subseteq N$.

Note that the sequence of natural numbers is not necessarily an ascending
sequence. However, we can easily correct this, it suffices to change
the definition of $S\left(a_{i}\right)$ so that $S\left(a_{i}\right)=\left\{ a_{n}\in N\mid a_{i}\quasi a_{n}\mbox{ \textbf{and} }i<n\right\} .$
Then $S\left(a_{i}\right)$ is infinite w.r.t. the new definition,
if and only if, it is infinite w.r.t. the previous one. Because $n_{i+i}=m'$
where $a_{m'}\in S\left(a_{n_{i}}\right)$ then $n_{i}<n_{i+1}$ and
we are done. 
\end{proof}
\begin{defn}
Let $\left(M,\quasi\right)$ and $\left(N,\quasi\right)$ be quasi-ordered
sets. Then we define $\quasi'$ on $M\times N$ as follows: 
\[
\left(a,b\right)\quasi'\left(c,d\right)\mbox{ iff }a\quasi c\mbox{ and }b\quasi d
\]
for $\left(a,b\right),\left(c,d\right)\in M\times N$. Note that $\quasi'$
is reflexive and transitive, that is, a quasi-order.

For a finite family of quasi-ordered sets, $\left\{ \left(M_{i},\quasi\right)\right\} _{i=1}^{n}$
the direct product is defined by 
\[
\left(\variables[a]\right)\quasi\left(\variables[b]\right)\mbox{ iff }a_{i}\quasi b_{i}\mbox{ for all }1\leq i\leq n.
\]
\end{defn}

Now, we are ready to prove the main result of this section, and its
corollaries, among which Dickson's Lemma is the most relevant. 
\begin{thm}
Let $\left(M,\quasi\right)$ and $\left(N,\quasi\right)$ be Dickson
quasi-ordered sets, and let $\left(M\times N,\quasi'\right)$ be their
direct product. Then $\left(M\times N,\quasi'\right)$ is a Dickson
quasi-ordered set. 
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
We verify \rom{2} of Proposition \ref{prop:4.42 Dickson quasi order equivalence}.
Let $\left\{ \left(a_{n},b_{n}\right)\right\} _{n\in\mathbb{N}}$
be a sequence of elements of $M\times N$. By Proposition \ref{prop:4.45 descending chain Dikson quasi order},
there exists a strictly ascending sequence $\left\{ n_{i}\right\} _{i\in\mathbb{N}}$
such that $a_{n_{i}}\quasi a_{n_{j}}$ for all $i<j$. By \rom{2}
of Proposition \ref{prop:4.42 Dickson quasi order equivalence} applied
to the sequence $\left\{ b_{n_{i}}\right\} _{i\in\mathbb{N}}$, there
exist $i<j$ with $b_{n_{i}}\quasi b_{n_{j}}$, and thus $\left(a_{n_{i}},b_{n_{i}}\right)\quasi'\left(a_{n_{j}},b_{n_{j}}\right)$. 
\end{proof}
\begin{cor}
Let $\left(M_{i},\quasi\right)$ be a Dickson quasi-orders sets for
$1\leq i\leq n$, and let $\left(M,\quasi'\right)$ be the direct
product of the $\left(M_{i},\quasi'\right)$. Then $\left(M,\quasi'\right)$
is a Dickson quasi-ordered set. 
\end{cor}

\begin{cor}[Dickson's Lemma]
\label{cor:Dickson's Lemma}Let $\left(\mathbb{N}^{n},\quasi'\right)$
be the direct product of $n$ copies of the natural numbers $\left(\mathbb{N},\leq\right)$
with its natural ordering. Then $\left(\mathbb{N}^{n},\quasi'\right)$
is a Dickson partially ordered set. More explicitly, every subset
$S$ of $\mathbb{N}^{n}$ has a finite subset $B$ such that for every
$\left(\variables[m]\right)\in S$, there exists $\left(\variables[k]\right)\in B$
with $k_{i}\leq m_{i}$ for $1\leq i\leq n$. 
\end{cor}


\section{Reduction relations\label{sec:Reduction-relations}}

The goal of this section is to provide the necessary notions for the
formalization of what has been roughly explained in the Prelude about
reducing a polynomial $f$ to $0$, and subtracting elements form
$F$ to $f$.
\begin{defn}
Let $\rightarrow$ be a relation on a non-empty set $M$. Then $\rightarrow$
is called a \textbf{reduction relation \index{reduction relation}}on
$M$ if $\rightarrow$ is strictly antisymmetric. We say that $a\in M$
is \textbf{reducible} with respect to $\rightarrow$ if there exist
$b\in M$ with $a\rightarrow b$ (reads $a$ reduces to $b$). In
connection with a reduction relation $\rightarrow$ on $M$, we will
write
\begin{enumerate}
\item $\clausura[\rightarrow]$ for the \textbf{reflexive-transitive closure
\nomenclature{$\clausura[\rightarrow]$}{ reflexive-transitive closure of $\rightarrow$}\index{reflexive-transitive closure}}of
$\rightarrow$, \\
 
\item $\fii$ for the \textbf{symmetric closure \nomenclature{$\fii$}{symmetric closure of $\rightarrow$}\index{symmetric closure}}of
$\rightarrow$, i.e., $a\fii b$ iff $a\rightarrow b$ or $b\rightarrow a$
for $a,b\in M$, \\
 
\item $\clausura[\fii]$ for the \textbf{reflexive-transitive closure \nomenclature{$\clausura[\fii]$}{reflexive-transitive closure of $\rightarrow$}\index{reflexive-transitive closure}}of
$\fii,$ i.e., the smallest equivalence relation on $M$ extending
$\rightarrow$, \\
 
\item $\overset{n}{\rightarrow}$ for $\left(\rightarrow\right)^{n}$ (where
the exponent refers to the definition of powers or a relation given
in definition \ref{def:power of a relation}) \nomenclature{$\overset{n}{\rightarrow}$}{power of the relation $\rightarrow$}\\
 
\item $\overset{n}{\fii}$ for $\left(\fii\right)^{n},$ and\\
 
\item $\downarrow$ for the relation on $M$ defined by $a\downarrow b$
iff there exists $c\in M$ with $a\overset{*}{\rightarrow}c\overset{*}{\leftarrow}b$.
\nomenclature{$\downarrow$}{relation} 
\end{enumerate}
\end{defn}

\begin{rem}
The relations $\reduction[\,]*,\fii,\overset{*}{\fii}$ are no longer
strictly antisymmetric. In particular, $\reduction[\,]*$ is an antisymmetric
quasi-order, and $\overset{*}{\fii}$ is a partial order. 
\end{rem}

\begin{defn}
\label{unique nromal form definition}An element $a\in M$ is said
to be in\textbf{ \index{normal form}normal form}, or a \textbf{normal
form}, with respect to $\rightarrow$ if $a$ is $\rightarrow$-maximal
in $M$. We say that $b\in M$ is a \textbf{normal form of} $a\in M$
with respect to $\rightarrow$ if $a\overset{*}{\rightarrow}b$ and
$b$ is in $\rightarrow$-normal form. Often we just say that an element
is in normal form when it is clear the reduction relation we are dealing
with.

As we will see in Section \ref{sec:Euclid's-Algorithm} and pointed
out before in Section \ref{sec:Explanation of Gr=00003D0000F6bner bases},
normal forms are the generalization of the residue in Euclid's algorithm.

Our first result is a sufficient condition for the existence of such
\textit{residues}. 
\end{defn}

\begin{lem}
\label{lem:noehterian has at least one normal form}If $\rightarrow$
is a noetherian reduction relation on $M$, then each $a\in M$ has
at least one normal form $a'\in M$ with respect to $\rightarrow$. 
\end{lem}

\begin{proof}
The set $N=\left\{ b\in M\mid a\clausura[\rightarrow]b\right\} $
is a non-empty set because $a\in N$, and so $N$ contains a $\rightarrow$-maximal
element. 
\end{proof}
What is worth noticing of the above result is that the element $a$
and the set $M$ play no role in the existence of the normal form
of $a$ w.r.t. $M$. This shows the importance of the reduction that
we choose, in particular, the noetherian property will always be desired
for a reduction relation.

We give now a sufficient condition for a relation to be noetherian. 
\begin{lem}
\label{lem:ar_sb  implies  -> noehterian}Let $r$ be a well-founded
relation on $M$ with strict part $r_{s}$, and assume that $a\rightarrow b$
implies $br_{s}a$. Then $\rightarrow$ is a noetherian reduction
relation on $M$. 
\end{lem}

\begin{proof}
We use the characterization shown in Proposition \ref{prop:4.31 iff well-founded descending chain}.
Assume $M$ has a strictly ascending $\rightarrow$-chain $\familia[a][n][\mathbb{N}]$.
Then $\familia[a][n][\mathbb{N}]$ is a strictly descending chain
$r$-chain, and has and $r$-minimal element $a_{n}$, since $r$
is a well-founded relation. Then, $a_{n}r_{s}a_{n+1}$ and $a_{n+1}r_{s}a_{n}$,
a contradiction. 
\end{proof}
\begin{defn}
Let $\rightarrow$ be a reduction relation on $M$. Then $\rightarrow$
is said
\begin{enumerate}
\item to be \textbf{locally confluent} \index{locally confluent}if $b\leftarrow a\rightarrow c$
implies $b\downarrow c$ for all $a,b,c\in M$, \\
 
\item to be \textbf{confluent \index{confluent}}if $b\clausura[\leftarrow]a\clausura[\rightarrow]c$
implies $b\downarrow c$ for all $a,b,c\in M$, \\
 
\item to have the \textbf{Church-Rosser} \textbf{property \index{Church-Rosser property}}if
$b\clausura[\fii]c$ implies $b\downarrow c$ for all $b,c\in M$,
\\
 
\item to have \textbf{\index{unique normal form}unique normal form} if
$b\clausura[\leftarrow]a\clausura[\rightarrow]c$ with $b$ and $c$
in $\rightarrow$-normal form implies $b=c$ for all $a,b,c\in M$. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{defn}

The following result establishes the equivalence of the above numbered
sentences. Remark that \rom{4} is the desired property for a set
$G$ to be Gröbner basis (given an adequate reduction by elements
of $G$), and so the result is crucial for the Gröbner-bases theory. 
\begin{thm}[Newman's Lemma]
\label{thm:Newman's} Let $\rightarrow$ be a noetherian reduction
relation on $M$. Then the following are equivalent:
\begin{enumerate}
\item $\rightarrow$ is locally confluent, \\
 
\item $\rightarrow$ is confluent, \\
 
\item $\rightarrow$ has unique normal form, \\
 
\item $\rightarrow$ has the Church-Rosser property. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
\rom{1}$\Rightarrow$\rom{2}: Assume for a contradiction that
$\rightarrow$ is locally confluent, but the set 
\[
N=\left\{ a\in M\mid\mbox{there exist }b,c\in M\mbox{ with }b\underset{}{\overset{*}{\leftarrow}}a\overset{*}{\rightarrow}c,\mbox{ but not }b\downarrow c\right\} 
\]
is non-empty. Since $\rightarrow$ is noetherian, $N$ has a $\rightarrow$-maximal
element, say $a$, and let $b,c\in M$ with $b\underset{}{\overset{*}{\leftarrow}}a\overset{*}{\rightarrow}c$
but not $b\downarrow c$. Thus, $a\neq b$ and $a\neq b$ since otherwise
$b\downarrow c$, and there exist $b',c'\in M$ with 
\[
b\overset{*}{\leftarrow}b'\leftarrow a\rightarrow c'\overset{*}{\rightarrow}c.
\]
Because $\rightarrow$ is locally confluence there exist $d\in M$
with $b'\overset{*}{\rightarrow}d\overset{*}{\leftarrow}c'$. Hence,
we have $b\overset{*}{\leftarrow}b'\overset{*}{\rightarrow}d$ with
$a\rightarrow b'$; by the maximality of $a$ in $N$, $b\downarrow d$
and so there exist $e\in M$ with 
\[
b\overset{*}{\rightarrow}e\overset{*}{\leftarrow}d.
\]
In addition, we have $e\overset{*}{\leftarrow}c'\overset{*}{\rightarrow}c$
with $a\rightarrow c'$, and so by minimality of $a$ in $N$ $a$
$e\downarrow c$ and there exists $f\in M$ with 
\[
e\overset{*}{\rightarrow}f\overset{*}{\leftarrow}c.
\]
In summary, we have proved $b\overset{*}{\rightarrow}e\overset{*}{\rightarrow}f\overset{*}{\leftarrow}c$,
a contradiction.

\rom{2}$\Rightarrow$\rom{3}: If $b\overset{*}{\leftarrow}a\overset{*}{\rightarrow}c$,
by\rom{2} there exists $d\in M$ with $b\overset{*}{\rightarrow}d\overset{*}{\leftarrow}c$.
If $b$ and $c$ are in $\rightarrow$-normal form, then $b=d=c$.

\rom{3}$\Rightarrow$\rom{4}: We show by induction on $k\in\mathbb{N}$
that for all $a,b\in M$ with $a\overset{k}{\fii}b$ it follows that
$a\downarrow b$. The case $k=0$ is trivial. Let now $a\overset{k+1}{\fii}b,$
say 
\[
a\overset{k}{\fii}c\fii b.
\]
then by induction hypothesis there exists $d\in M$ with $a\overset{*}{\rightarrow}d\overset{*}{\leftarrow}c$.
If $c\leftarrow b$ we are done. Consider the case $c\rightarrow b$
and let $d',b'$ be $\rightarrow$-normal forms of $d$ and $b$ respectively.
Then 
\[
d'\overset{*}{\leftarrow}d\overset{*}{\leftarrow}c\overset{*}{\rightarrow}b\overset{*}{\rightarrow}b',
\]
and so $d'$ and $b'$ are normal forms of $c$. Hence, by \rom{3},
$d'=b'$ and $a\overset{*}{\rightarrow}d\overset{*}{\rightarrow}d'\overset{*}{\leftarrow}b$,
that is $a\downarrow b$.

\rom{4}$\Rightarrow$\rom{1}: Let $b\leftarrow a\rightarrow c$.
Then $b\overset{*}{\fii}c$, and so $b\downarrow c$ by \rom{4}. 
\end{proof}
\begin{cor}
\label{cor:Cor Newans}Let $\rightarrow$ be a locally confluent,
noetherian reduction relation on $M$ and let $a,b\in M$. Then the
following are equivalent:
\begin{enumerate}
\item $a\overset{*}{\fii}b$, 
\item whenever $a'$ and $b'$ are normal forms of $a$ and $b$ w.r.t.
$\rightarrow$, then $a'=b'$. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{cor}

\begin{proof}
The converse implication is obvious. For the direct implication, we
trivially have that $a'\overset{*}{\fii}b'$ and by the Church-Rosser
property, $a'\rightarrow c\leftarrow b'$ for some $c\in M$. Because
$a',b'$ are in $\rightarrow$-normal form, $a'=c=b'$ as required. 
\end{proof}
\begin{rem}
As we show early, noetherian condition is desired for a reduction
relation. From the previous results we see that a relation being locally
confluent is also important for our purpose since it provides unique
normal form. Moreover, the reflexive-symmetric-transitive closure
of the relation will be an important object of our study. 
\end{rem}


\section{Computations and Algorithms\label{sec:Computations-and-Algorithmics}}

Since the goal of Gröbner bases and Buchberger's algorithm is to offer
a method for computing on the residue class ring $K[\mathbf{X}]/I$,
typically using a computer, this chapter focuses on concepts related
to algorithms and the computability of operations. 
\begin{defn}
A set $M$ is \textbf{decidable \index{decidable}}if its elements
are given in such a way that there is an algorithm which, upon input
of $a,b\in M$, decides whether $a=b$, or not. 
\end{defn}

\begin{defn}
Let $\rightarrow$ be a reduction relation on $M$ and let $\rel$
be an equivalence relation on $M$. Then we call $\rightarrow$ \textbf{adequate
\index{adequate}}for $\rel$ if $\rel$ coincides with the reflexive-symmetric-transitive
closure $\clausura[\fii]$ of $\rightarrow$. We say $\rightarrow$
is \textbf{decidable \index{decidable}} if there is an algorithm
which, on the input of $a\in M$, decides whether $a$ is reducible
with respect to $\rightarrow$, and if so selects some $b\in M$ with
$a\rightarrow b$. 
\end{defn}

\begin{thm}
\label{thm:noetherian relation adequate for equivalence relation equiv }Let
$\rel$ be an equivalence relation on a non-empty set $M$. Let $\rightarrow$
be a locally confluent noetherian reduction relation on $M$ that
is adequate for $\rel$, and suppose $M$ and $\rightarrow$ are decidable.
Then there exists an algorithm which, on input of $a,b\in M$, decides
whether $a\rel b$ or not. 
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
~

\begin{algorithm}[H]
\begin{description}
\item [{\caption{EQUIV\label{alg:EQUIV}}
}] ~
\item [{Specification:}] $v\leftarrow\mbox{EQUIV}\left(a,b\right)$\\
 Test whether $a\rel b$
\item [{Given:}] $a,b\in M$
\item [{Find:}] $v\in\left\{ \mathbf{true},\mathbf{false}\right\} $ such
that $v=\mathbf{true}$ iff $a\rel b$
\item [{begin~EQUIV}] ~
\item [{$A\leftarrow a;$}] $B\leftarrow b$;
\item [{while}] $A$ is reducible w.r.t. $\rightarrow$ \textbf{do}\\
 select $C\in M$ with $A\rightarrow C$\\
 $A\leftarrow C$
\item [{end}] ~
\item [{while}] \textbf{$B$ }is reducible w.r.t. $\rightarrow$ \textbf{do
}\\
 select $D\in M$ with $B\rightarrow D$\\
 $B\leftarrow D$
\item [{end}] ~
\item [{if}] $A=B$
\item [{~}] \textbf{return(true)}
\item [{else}] ~
\item [{~}] \textbf{return(false)}
\item [{end}] ~
\item [{end~EQUIV}] ~
\end{description}
\end{algorithm}

\textit{Termination:} An infinite loop would provide an infinite ascending
$\rightarrow$-chain, contradicting the fact that $\rightarrow$ is
noetherian.

\textit{Correctness: }By definition, $a\rel b$ iff $a\overset{*}{\fii}b$.
Moreover, if $a',b'$ are normal forms of $a,b$, by Corollary \ref{cor:Cor Newans},
$a\rel b$ iff $a'=b'$ and the algorithm is correct. 
\end{proof}
\begin{rem}
Provided a relation $\rel$ and a reduction relation $\rightarrow$
as in the theorem above, the set $\left\{ h\in M\mid h\mbox{ is in }\rightarrow\mbox{-normal form}\right\} $
is a system of unique representatives for the partition $M/\rel$
of $M$. 
\end{rem}

Because we are not at the point to define a noetherian reduction relation,
we will later see an example of the above algorithm (Example \ref{exa:equiv}). 
\begin{defn}
A monoid $M$ (a ring $R$) is called \textbf{computable}\textbf{\textit{
\index{computable}}}if the elements of $M$ (of $R$) are given in
such a way that $M$ ($R$) is decidable as a set, and there is an
algorithm (there are algorithms) which, upon input of $a,b\in M$
(if $a,b\in R$) computes $ab\in M$(computes $ab,a+b$ and $-a\in R$).
A field $K$ is called a \textbf{computable field \index{computable field}}if
it is computable as a ring and there is an algorithm which, upon input
of $0\neq a\in K$, computes $a^{-1}\in K$. An order $\leq$ is called
\textbf{decidable \index{decidable}}if there is an algorithm that
decides, for $a,b\in M$, whether $a\leq b$.
\end{defn}

The following example constitutes an apéritif for the computation
on the polynomial residue ring $K\left[\variables[X]\right]/I$. 
\begin{example}
\label{exa: R/I}Let $R$ be a computable ring, $\left\{ 0\right\} \ne I$
an ideal of $R$ such that there is an algorithm which, upon input
$a\in R$, decides whether $a\in I$, or not. We claim that the residue
class $R/I$ is a computable ring. The elements $a+I$ of $R/I$,
are obviously given as elements of $R$, viewed as residue class modulo
$I$. Two elements $a$ and $b$ of $R$, represent the same residue
class iff $a-b\in I$, a condition which we can effectively test by
our assumption on $I$. Addition, subtraction, and multiplication
in $R/I$ are performed by doing the respective in $R$ on representatives,
which is possible by the assumption on $R$. 
\end{example}


\section{Term Orders\label{sec:Term-Orders}}

On Euclid's algorithm, the notion of degree of a polynomial is as
essential as clear. However, on the multivariate case, no notion of
degree of a polynomial seems obvious since the many possibilities
one can think. This section is devoted to term orders, that is, (linear)
orders on the variables and to introduce the notion of degree in the
multivariate case. 
\begin{defn}
A\textbf{ \index{term}term} $t$ in the indeterminates, or variables,
$\variables[X]$ is a power product of the form $t=\potencias[X][e]$
with $e_{i}\in\mathbb{N}$ for $\valores$; in particular $1=X_{1}^{0}\cdot...\cdot X_{n}^{0}$
is a term. We denote by $T\left(\variables[X]\right)$, or simply
by $T$, the set of all terms in these variables. The set $T$ forms
an abelian (multiplicative) monoid with identity element $1$ w.r.t.
the natural multiplication. \nomenclature{$T\left(\variables[X]\right),T$}{set of all terms with variables $\variables[X]$} 
\end{defn}

\begin{rem}
Note that two terms are different, if and only if, their exponent
tuples are different. This means that the abelian monoids $\left(T,1,\cdot\right)$
and $\left(\mathbb{N}^{n},\left(0,...,0\right),+\right)$ are isomorphic
via the \textbf{exponent map \index{exponent map}\nomenclature{$\eta$}{exponent map}}$\eta:T\rightarrow\mathbb{N}^{n}$
given by $\eta\left(\potencias[X][e]\right)=\left(\variables[e]\right)$. 
\end{rem}

\begin{defn}
The partial order $\leq'$ on $\mathbb{N}^{n}$ defined by 
\[
\left(\variables[k]\right)\leq'\left(\variables[m]\right)\mbox{ iff }k_{i}\leq m_{i}\mbox{ for }\valores
\]

is called\textbf{ \index{natural partial order}\nomenclature{$\leq'$}{natural partial ordern on $\mathbb{N}^{n}$}natural
partial order} on $\mathbb{N}^{n}$. The \textbf{\index{divisibility relation}}\nomenclature{$\mid$}{divisibility relation}\textbf{divisibility
relation }$|$ on $T$ is defined by $s|t$ iff there exists $s'\in T$
with $s\cdot s'=t$. Clearly, $s|t$ iff $\eta\left(s\right)\leq'\eta\left(t\right)$
where $\leq'$ is the natural partial order on $\mathbb{N}^{n}$. 
\end{defn}

Although the divisibility relation in $T$ could have been defined
as in $R\left[\variables[X]\right]$, that is, $s\mid t$ if there
is a $r\in R\left[\variables[X]\right]$ such that $t=rs$, the previous
definition allows us to extend previous results about Dickson's quasi-orders
to the division relation, in particular we have the following result. 
\begin{thm}
\label{thm:4.42 The-divisibility-relation is a Dickson partial order}
The divisibility relation $|$ on $T$ is a Dickson partial order
on $T$. More explicitly, every non-empty subset $S$ of $T$ has
a finite subset $B$ such that for all $s\in S$, there exists $t\in B$
with $t|s$. 
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
This result is an immediate consequence \nameref{cor:Dickson's Lemma}
(Corollary \ref{cor:Dickson's Lemma}). 
\end{proof}
From the above theorem, we see that Dickson partial orders are indeed
part of our study, and Section \ref{sec:Dickson-relations} represents
no deviation from our goal. 
\begin{defn}
\label{def:term-order}\textbf{ \index{term order}}A\textbf{ term
order }is an admissible linear order for the monoid $\left(T,\cdot\right)$,
i.e., is a linear order on $T$ that satisfies the following conditions.
\begin{enumerate}
\item $1\leq t$ for all $t\in T$. \\
 
\item $t_{1}<t_{2}$ implies $t_{1}\cdot s<t_{2}\cdot\mathit{s}$ for all
$s,t_{1},t_{2}\in T$. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{defn}

\begin{rem}
A term $t$ is in correspondence with a tuple in $\mathbb{N}^{n}$
(of exponents of the variables $\variables[X]$). Therefore, any commutation
of the variables is not allowed in a term. Given a polynomial $f$
on $R\left[\variables[X]\right]$, we may reorder the power products
appearing in $f$ as to form a term, and so we need the variables
$\variables[X]$ to commute. For this reason, we set every ring $R$
to be a commutative ring. 
\end{rem}

From the definition of term order, we see that the divisibility relation
is a term order. But we can say more, every term order on $T$ is
paired with an admissible order in $\mathbb{N}^{n}$ and vice versa. 
\begin{lem}
Let $\leq$ be and admissible order on $\left(\mathbb{N}^{n},\left(0,...,0\right),+\right)$,
and define $\leq'$ on $T$ by setting $s\leq't$ iff $\eta\left(s\right)\leq\eta\left(t\right)$.
Then $\leq'$ is a term order on $T$. Moreover, every term order
on $T$ is obtained in this way, and the resulting correspondence
between term orders on $T$ and admissible orders in $\left(\mathbb{N}^{n},\left(0\right),+\right)$
is one-to-one. 
\end{lem}

\begin{proof}
Let $\leq$ be an admissible order on $\left(\mathbb{N}^{n},\left(0\right),+\right).$
Then $\leq'$ is a term order on $T$, since $\eta\left(1\right)=\eta\left(0\right)$
and $\eta\left(s\cdot t\right)=\eta\left(s\right)+\eta\left(t\right)$.
Using the fact that $\eta^{-1}:\left(\mathbb{N}^{n},\left(0\right),+\right)\rightarrow\left(T,1,\cdot\right)$
is an isomorphism, one easily proves that every order on $T$ is obtained
in this way, and that the correspondence is one to one. 
\end{proof}
The following theorem is an immediate consequence of the theorem and
lemma above. Property \rom{2} is also a consequence of \nameref{cor:Dickson's Lemma}
(Corollary \ref{cor:Dickson's Lemma}). 
\begin{thm}
\label{thm:Every term order is a well order on T}~
\begin{enumerate}
\item If $\leq$ is a term order on $T$, then $s\mid t$ implies $s\leq t$
for all $s,t\in T$. \\
 
\item Every term order is a well-order on $T$. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{thm}

Some of the most common terms orders are given in the following definition. 
\begin{defn}
We define now some common term orders on $T$.
\begin{enumerate}
\item $\potencias[X][d]\leq\potencias[X][e]$ iff the following holds: $\left(\variables[d]\right)=\left(\variables[e]\right)$,
or there exists $\Valores$ with $d_{j}=e_{j}$ for $\valores[j][][i-1]$
and $d_{i}<e_{i}$. This term order is called the \index{lexicographical or lexical order}\textbf{lexicographical},
or \textbf{lexical} \textbf{order} on $T$. \\
 
\item $\potencias[X][d]\leq\potencias[X][e]$ iff the following holds: $\left(\variables[d]\right)=\left(\variables[e]\right)$,
or there exists $\Valores$ with $d_{j}=e_{j}$ for $\valores[j][i+1][n]$
and $d_{i}<e_{i}$. This term order is called the\textbf{ \index{inverse lexicographical, or inverse lexical order}inverse}
\textbf{lexicographical}, or \textbf{inverse lexical} \textbf{order
}on $T$. \\
 
\item Let $\leq$ be an order on $T$ that satisfies condition: $t_{1}\leq t_{2}$
implies $t_{1}\cdot s\leq t_{2}\cdot\mathit{s}$ for all $s,t_{1},t_{2}\in T$
(see Definition \ref{def:term-order}). Set 
\[
\potencias[X][d]\leq'\potencias[X][e]
\]
iff the following condition holds: 
\[
\suma d_{i}<\suma e_{i}\mbox{, or}
\]
\[
\suma d_{i}=\suma e_{i}\mbox{, and }\potencias[X][d]\leq\potencias[X][e].
\]
This class of term orders is called the class of \textbf{total degree
orders}. If $\leq$ is the lexicographical order, then the resulting
term order is called the\textbf{ \index{total degree-inverse lexicographical order}total
degree-lexicographical order}. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{defn}

\begin{example}
The polynomials $f_{1},f_{2}$ and $f_{3}$ defined in Remark \ref{rem: f_1 f_2  f_3}
are ordered w.r.t. the inverse lexicographical order.

Now, consider the polynomial in $K\left[x,y\right]$ 
\[
f=x^{2}y^{2}+x^{2}y+xy^{2}+x^{2}+y^{2}+xy+x+y.
\]

Then the polynomials 
\begin{eqnarray*}
f_{1} & = & x^{2}y^{2}+xy^{2}+y^{2}+x^{2}y+xy+y+x^{2}+x,\\
f_{2} & = & x^{2}y^{2}+x^{2}y+x^{2}+xy^{2}+xy+x+y^{2}+y,\\
f_{3} & = & x^{2}y^{2}+xy^{2}+x^{2}y+y^{2}+xy+x^{2}+x++y,
\end{eqnarray*}
are the representation of $f$ w.r.t. the inverse lexicographical
order, the lexicographical order and the total degree-inverse lexicographical
order respectively. Note that by swapping the terms $xy$ and $y^{2}$
if $f$, it would be ordered w.r.t. the total degree-inverse-inverse
lexicographical order. 
\end{example}

Previous to define an ``ordering'' on the polynomials, we present
a polynomial as sum of terms, or tuple of terms, and make sure that
representation is computable. 
\begin{prop}
\label{prop: unique representation}Let $M$ be the set of all monomials
in $R\left[\variables[X]\right]$.
\begin{enumerate}
\item Let $\leq$ be a term order on $T$. Then every polynomial $f\in R\left[\variables[X]\right]$
has a unique representation as sum of monomials $\suma[][][k]m_{i}$
with $m_{i}\in M$ and $\variables[m][k][>]$. \\
 
\item If, in addition, $R$ is a computable ring and $\leq$ is a decidable
order on $T$, there is an algorithm that computes the representation
of $(i)$ from any arbitrary representation of $f$ as a sum of monomials. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{prop}

\begin{proof}
Given the unique representation of $f$ as sum of pairwise inequivalent
monomials, $\suma[i][1][k]m_{i}$, we can subtract the coefficient
of each $m_{i}$ to obtain a term $t_{i}$. By ordering the sequence
$\left(t_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{k}$, say $t_{i_{1}}>t_{i_{2}}>...>t_{i_{k}}$,
where the strict part is possible since monomials $m_{i}$ are pairwise
inequivalent. We set $f=\suma[j][1][k]m_{i_{j}}$, and the claims
follows. Condition \rom{2} is now immediate from \rom{1}. 
\end{proof}
\begin{rem}
Note that $m_{i}$ are monomials and not terms, so the relation $m_{i}>m_{j}$
must be understood as relation on the terms appearing in $m_{i},m_{j}$.
However, as in the proposition, we will write $\variables[m][k][>]$
since less notation is needed. 
\end{rem}

The previous result allows us to define the following. 
\begin{defn}
Given a polynomial $f\in R\left[\variables[X]\right]$, let $f=\suma[][][k]m_{i}$
be the unique representation of $f$ with $m_{i}$ monomials of $R\left[\variables[X]\right]$
such that $\variables[m][k][>]$. Then we write \textbf{ \nomenclature{$M\left(f\right)$}{the set of all monomials of $f$}\index{the set of all monomials of $f$}}$M\left(f\right)=\left\{ m_{i}\right\} _{i=1}^{k}$
for\textbf{ the set of all monomials} \textbf{of} $f$; $T\left(f\right)$
\textbf{\index{the set of all terms of $f$}}\nomenclature{$T\left(f\right)$}{the set of all terms of $f$}for
\textbf{the set of all terms of $f$}, i.e., the set of all terms
of monomials $m\in M\left(f\right)$; and $C\left(f\right)$\textbf{
\nomenclature{$C(f)$}{the set of all coefficientes of $f$}\index{the set of all coefficients of $f$}}for\textbf{
the set of all coefficients of} $f$.

When we omit the polynomial $f$, $M$ ($T$) denotes \textbf{the
set of all monomials\nomenclature{$T$}{ the set of all terms}\nomenclature{$M$}{ the set of all monomials }
\index{the set of all monomials}\index{the set of all of all terms}}(\textbf{of
all terms}) of $R\left[\variables[X]\right].$ We will also write
$\coef$ for\textbf{ \nomenclature{$\coef$}{the coeficient of the term $t$ in $f$}\index{the coefficient of the term $t$ in $f$}the
coefficient of the term} $t$ \textbf{in} $f$. 
\end{defn}


\section{\label{sec:The-induced-quasi-order}Induced quasi-order of a term
order}

The aim of this section is to define a quasi-order on the polynomial
ring $R\left[\variables[X]\right]$. As an anticipation, the resulting
quasi-order is a consequence of the chosen ordering on $T$ extended
recursively on a polynomial using its representation as sums of monomials.

The following technical result will be later needed. 
\begin{lem}
\label{lem:quasi-order equivalnce fi then is well-founded}Let $\quasi$
be a quasi-order on $M$ with associated equivalence relation $\rel,$
let $\leq$ be a well-founded partial order on $N$, and let $\varphi:M\rightarrow N$
be a map such that for all $a,b\in M$, the following hold:
\begin{enumerate}
\item $a\quasi b$ implies $\varphi\left(a\right)\leq\varphi\left(b\right)$,
and \\
 
\item $\varphi\left(a\right)=\varphi\left(b\right)$ implies $a\rel b$. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{lem}

Then $\quasi$ is well-founded.
\begin{proof}
Assume for a contradiction that $\familia[a][n][\mathbb{N}]$ is a
strictly descending $\quasi$-chain. Then $\varphi\left(a_{j}\right)\leq\varphi\left(a_{i}\right)$
for $i<j$, and $\varphi\left(a_{i}\right)\neq\varphi\left(a_{j}\right)$
since otherwise $a_{i}\rel a_{j}$. Then $\left\{ \varphi\left(a_{n}\right)\right\} _{n\in\mathbb{N}}$
form a strictly descending $\leq$-chain, a contradiction. 
\end{proof}
\begin{defn}
\label{def:<' in P fin}Let $\left(M,\leq\right)$ be an ordered set,
and let $\mathcal{P}_{fin}\left(M\right)$ be the set of all finite
subsets of $M$. Every $\emptyset\neq A\in\mathcal{P}_{fin}\left(M\right)$
obviously has a maximal and minimal element w.r.t. the order $\leq$.
We denote these by $\max\left(A\right)$, and $\min\left(A\right)$,
respectively. With $A'=A\setminus\left\{ \max A\right\} $, we define
a binary relation $\leq'$ on $\mathcal{P}_{fin}\left(M\right)$ as
follows. Let $A,B\in\mathcal{P}_{fin}\left(M\right)$; then $A\leq'B$
is defined by recursion on the number $\left|A\right|$: if $A=\emptyset$,
then $A\leq'B$. If $A\neq\emptyset$, then $A\leq'B$ iff $B\neq\emptyset$
and the following conditions holds: 
\begin{eqnarray*}
\max\left(A\right) & < & \max\left(B\right),\mbox{ or}\\
\max\left(A\right) & = & \max\left(B\right)\mbox{ and }A'\leq'B'.
\end{eqnarray*}
\end{defn}

The next result follows easily by induction, whereas the posterior
one uses the Cantor's second diagonal argument. 
\begin{lem}
\label{lem:4.67 <' is an ordered set}Let $\left(M,\leq\right),$
$\mathcal{P}_{fin}\left(M\right)$ and $\leq'$ be as in the definition
above. Then $\left(\mathcal{P}_{fin}\left(M\right),\leq'\right)$
is an ordered set. 
\end{lem}

\begin{proof}
$\leq'$ is reflexive: we argue by induction on $n=\left|A\right|$
for $A\in\mathcal{P}_{fin}\left(M\right)$ that $A\leq A$. It is
clear from definition for $n=0$. If $n>0$, it follows by induction
hypothesis that $A'\leq'A'$ since $\left|A'\right|<n$ and so $A\leq'A$
from definition.

$\leq'$ is transitive: assume that $A,B,C\in\mathcal{P}_{fin}\left(M\right)$
with $A\leq'B$ and $B\leq'C$. We use induction on $n=\left|A\right|$
to prove that $A\leq'C$. This is trivial if $n=0$. If $n>0$, then
$A\neq\emptyset$, and so $B,C\neq\emptyset$. We thus have 
\[
\max\left(A\right)\leq\max\left(B\right)\mbox{ and }\max\left(B\right)\leq\max\left(C\right).
\]
If at least one of the inequalities is strict, then it follows immediately
that $A\leq'C$. If we have equality in both cases, then 
\begin{eqnarray*}
A' & \leq' & B'\leq'C',
\end{eqnarray*}
and so $A'\leq'C'$ by hypothesis induction. This together with $\max\left(A\right)=\max\left(C\right)$
implies that $A\leq'C$.

$\leq'$ is antisymmetric: suppose $A,B\in\mathcal{P}_{fin}\left(M\right)$
with $A\leq'B$ and $B\leq'A$. To prove that $A=B$, we proceed by
induction on $n=\left|A\right|.$ If $n=0$, then $A=B=\emptyset$.
If $n>0$, then both $A,B$ must be non-empty, and we must have $\max\left(A\right)=\max\left(B\right)$
and both $A'\leq'B'$ and $B'\leq'A'$. The induction hypothesis now
implies that $A=B$.

$\leq'$ is connex: let $A,B\in\mathcal{P}_{fin}\left(M\right)$.
If $B=\emptyset$ then $B\leq'A$. For the remaining case, $B\neq\emptyset$
and we use induction on $n=\left|A\right|$ to prove that $A\leq'B$
or $B\leq'A$. This is trivial if $n=0$. Finally, if $n>0$, then
either the maximal of $A$ and $B$ are different, in which case we
are done, or they agree, in which case we apply induction hypothesis
to $A'$ and $B'$. 
\end{proof}
\begin{thm}
\label{thm:p_fin <' is a well ordered set}If $\left(M,\leq\right)$
is a well-ordered set, then so is $\left(\mathcal{P}_{fin}\left(M\right),\leq'\right)$. 
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
Assume for contradiction that there is a strictly descending $\leq'$-chain
$\familia[A][n][\mathbb{N}]$ in $\mathcal{P}_{fin}\left(M\right)$.
We will show there exist a strictly descending $\leq$-chain in $M$.
We first note that $A_{n}\neq\emptyset$ for all $n\in\mathbb{N}$
by the definition of $\leq'$. We construct by recursion on $k\in\mathbb{N}$
a sequence 
\[
\left\{ \left(a_{k},\left\{ B_{kn}\right\} _{n\in\mathbb{N}}\right)\right\} _{k\in\mathbb{N}},
\]
formed by ordered pairs which the first component is an element of
$M$, while the second component is a sequence of elements on $\mathcal{P}_{fin}\left(M\right)$.
Moreover, we define the sequence in such a way so it verifies:
\begin{enumerate}
\item $\left\{ B_{kn}\right\} _{n\in\mathbb{N}}$ is a strictly descending
$\leq'$-chain in $\mathcal{P}_{fin}\left(M\right)$ for each $k\in\mathbb{N}$.\\
 
\item $a_{k}>\max\left(B_{kn}\right)$ for all $n\in\mathbb{N}$. 
\end{enumerate}
For $k=0$, let 
\[
C=\left\{ \max\left(A_{n}\right)\mid n\in\mathbb{N}\right\} ,
\]
and set $a_{0}=\min\left(C\right)$. Now let $j$ be the least index
such that $a_{0}\in A_{j}.$ Then $a_{0}=\max\left(A_{n}\right)$
for all $n\geq j$, since $\left\{ A_{n}\right\} _{n\in\mathbb{N}}$
is a strictly descending $\leq'$-chain. If we now set $B_{0n}=A'_{j+n}$
for all $n\in\mathbb{N}$, then $a_{0}=\max\left(A_{j+n}\right)>\max\left(A_{j+n}'\right)$
by definition of $\leq'$ and because $\max\left(A_{j+n}\right)=a_{0}=\max\left(A_{j+\left(n+1\right)}\right)$,
the fact $\left\{ A_{n}\right\} _{n\in\mathbb{N}}$ is a strictly
descending $\leq'$-chain implies $B_{0n}=A'_{j+n}>A'_{j+\left(n+1\right)}=B_{0n+1}$.
Suppose we have defined the sequence up to the index $k$, let's now
define the pair $\left(a_{k+1},\left\{ B_{\left(k+1\right)n}\right\} \right)$.
Consider the set 
\[
D=\left\{ \max\left(B_{kn}\right)\mid n\in\mathbb{N}\right\} ,
\]
and define $a_{k+1}=\min\left(D\right)$. Let $j$ be the least index
such that $a_{k+1}\in B_{kj}$. Then $a_{k+1}=\max\left(B_{kj}\right)$
for all $n\geq j$, and we set $B_{\left(k+1\right)n}=B'_{k\left(n+j\right)}$.
As before, the fact that $\left\{ B_{kn}\right\} _{n\in\mathbb{N}}$
is a strictly descending $\leq'$-chain and $\max\left(B_{k\left(j+n\right)}\right)=a_{k+1}=\max\left(B_{k\left(j+n+1\right)}\right)$,
by definition of $\leq'$ we have $B_{\left(k+1\right)n}=B'_{k\left(j+n\right)}>B'_{k\left(j+n+1\right)}=B_{\left(k+1\right)\left(n+1\right)}$
and so $\left\{ B_{\left(k+1\right)n}\right\} _{n\in\mathbb{N}}$
is a strictly descending $\leq'$-chain. Because $a_{k+1}=\max\left(B_{kj}\right)$
for all $n\geq j$, the claim $a_{k+1}>\max\left(B'_{k\left(j+n\right)}\right)=\max\left(B_{\left(k+1\right)n}\right)$
is clear.

Finally, remark that $a_{k+1}\in B_{kn}$ for all $k\in\mathbb{N}$
by definition, and so $a_{k}>a_{k+1}$ for all $k\in\mathbb{N}$ by
\rom{2}. Hence, $\left\{ a_{k}\right\} _{k\in\mathbb{N}}$ is a
strictly descending $\leq$-chain in $M$, a contradiction since $\leq$
is well-founded. 
\end{proof}
Specializing the above to our interest, the ring of polynomials, we
can enunciate the following. 
\begin{defn}
Let $\leq$ be a term order on $T$ and let $\leq'$ be the induced
well-order on $\mathcal{P}_{fin}\left(T\right)$ of theorem above.
We define a relation $\quasi$ on $R\left[\variables[X]\right]$ by
setting 
\[
f\quasi g\mbox{ iff }T\left(f\right)\leq'T\left(g\right).
\]
\end{defn}

\begin{thm}
\label{thm:Extension to well-founded quasi-order} Let $\leq$ be
a term order on $T.$ Then $\leq$ can be extended to a linear well-founded
quasi-order $\quasi$ on $R\left[\variables[X]\right]$. 
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
Consider the relation $\quasi$ defined above. The order $\leq'$
on $\mathcal{P}_{fin}$ upon which the definition of $\quasi$ is
based is a linear order by Lemma \ref{lem:4.67 <' is an ordered set},
i.e., it is reflexive, transitive and connex. Trivially $\quasi$
inherits these properties. Moreover, we can apply Lemma \ref{lem:quasi-order equivalnce fi then is well-founded}
to $\quasi$ with $M=R\left[\variables[X]\right],$ $N=\mathcal{P}_{fin}\left(T\right)$
and $\varphi:R\left[\variables[X]\right]\rightarrow\mathcal{P}_{fin}\left(T\right)$
defined by $\varphi\left(f\right)=T\left(f\right)$, and so $\quasi$
is well-founded. 
\end{proof}
\begin{rem}
Theorem and definition above is of utmost importance for the Gröbner
bases theory; whenever a term order $\leq$ has been fixed and $f\leq g$
occurs for some polynomials $f,g$, then it is the \textbf{induced}
\textbf{(well-founded linear) quasi-order} \index{induced quasi-order}$\quasi$
on $R\left[\variables[X]\right]$ that is being referred to. 
\end{rem}

\begin{example}
Consider the polynomials $f=x^{2}y+y^{2}+x$ and $g=x^{2}y+x^{2}+y$
and $h=x^{3}+y^{2}$.

If $\leq$ is both the inverse lexicographical order on $T$, and
the induced quasi-order on $R\left[\variables[X]\right]$, then $\thead[f]=y^{2}$,
$\thead[g]=x^{2}y$ and $\thead[h]=y^{2}$. Hence $f>g$ and $h>g$.
Because $\thead[f]=\thead[h]$ we consider the polynomials $f'=f-\thead[f]=x^{2}y+x$
and $h'=h-\thead[h]=x^{3}$. Now, $\thead[f']=x^{2}y$ and $\thead[h']=x^{3}$
which implies $f'>h'$, and so $f>h$.

If we now consider the total degree-inverse lexicographical order.
Then $\thead[f]=x^{2}y,$$\thead[g]=x^{2}y$ and $\thead[h]=x^{3}$.
Hence $f>h$ and $g>h$. Now consider $f'=f-\thead[f]=y^{2}+x$ and
$g'=g-\thead[g]=x^{2}+y$. Because $\thead[f']=y^{2}>x^{2}=\thead[g']$
we conclude that $f'>g'$, and so $f>g$. 
\end{example}


\section{Polynomial reductions\label{sec:Polynomial-reductions}}

In this section we introduce reduction relations to the ring of polynomials
over a field $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$.

Before to proceed with reduction relations, we give some definition
that are useful in order to describe polynomials in a more precise
way. 
\begin{defn}
Let $\leq$ be a term order on $T$. For any finite, non-empty subset
$A$ of $M$ consisting of pairwise inequivalent monomials, we let
$\max\left(A\right)$ be the unique maximal element of $A$ w.r.t.
$\leq$. For any non-zero polynomial $f\in R\left[\variables[X]\right]$
we define the\textbf{ }\textbf{\textit{\nomenclature{$\thead$}{head term of $f$}}}\textbf{\index{head term}head
term} $\thead$, the\textbf{ }\textbf{\textit{\nomenclature{$\mhead$}{head monomial of $f$}}}\textbf{\index{head monomial}head
monomial }$\mhead$, and the\textbf{ }\textbf{\textit{\nomenclature{$\chead$}{head coefficient of $f$}}}\textbf{\index{head coefficient}head
coefficient} $\chead$ of $f$ w.r.t. $\leq$ as follows: 
\begin{eqnarray*}
\thead & = & \max\left(T\left(f\right)\right),\\
\mhead & = & \max\left(M\left(f\right)\right),\mbox{ and}\\
\chead & = & \mbox{the coefficient of }\mhead.
\end{eqnarray*}

Given an ideal $I$, we may also write \nomenclature{$\thead[I]$}{set of head terms of $I$}\nomenclature{$\mhead[I]$}{set of head monomials of $I$}

\begin{eqnarray*}
\thead[I] & = & \left\{ \thead[f]\mid f\in I\right\} ,\mbox{ and}\\
\mhead[I] & = & \left\{ \mhead[I]\mid f\in I\right\} .
\end{eqnarray*}
The \textbf{\nomenclature{$\reductum$}{reductum}\index{reductum}reductum
$\reductum$ }of $f$ w.r.t. $\leq$ is defined as $f-\mhead$, i.e.,
$f=\mhead+red\left(f\right)$. A polynomial $f\in R\left[\variables[X]\right]$
is called \textbf{monic \index{monic}}w.r.t. $\leq$ if $f\neq0$
and $\chead=1$. 
\end{defn}

\begin{rem}
If $f=\suma[][][k]m_{i}$ is the unique representation of $f$ with
$\variables[m][k][>],$ $m_{i}\in M$, then $m_{1}=\mhead$. In addition,
$\reductum=m_{2}+...+m_{k}<m_{1}$ follows from the definition of
the relation and so $\reductum<\mhead\leq f$ (note that $\leq$ denotes
the relation $\quasi$ of Theorem \ref{thm:Extension to well-founded quasi-order}). 
\end{rem}

\begin{rem}
The induced quasi-order on $R\left[\variables[X]\right]$ can be defined
recursively by $f\leq g$ if $f=0,$ and for $f,g\neq0$ the relation
$f\leq g$ holds iff 
\begin{eqnarray*}
\mhead & < & \mhead[g],\mbox{ or}\\
\mhead & = & \mhead[g]\mbox{ and }\reductum[f]\leq\reductum[g].
\end{eqnarray*}
\end{rem}

\begin{lem}
Let $R$ be an integral domain and let $f,g\in R\left[\variables[X]\right]$
with $f,g$ non-zero. Then
\begin{enumerate}
\item $\thead[fg]=\thead\cdot\thead[g]$,\\
 
\item $\mhead[fg]=\mhead\cdot\mhead[g],$\\
 
\item $\chead[fg]=\chead\cdot\chead[g],$ and\\
 
\item $\thead[f+g]\leq\max\left\{ \thead,\thead[g]\right\} $. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{lem}

\begin{proof}
\rom{1} By definition $T\left(fg\right)=\left\{ t\cdot s\mid t\in T\left(f\right),s\in T\left(g\right)\right\} $,
because term orders are admissible, if $t<\thead[f]$ or $s<\thead[g]$,
then $t\cdot s<\thead\cdot\thead[g]$.\\

\rom{2} Because the only product of monomials of $f$ and $g$ that
has $\thead[f]\cdot\thead[g]$ as term is $\mhead[f]\cdot\mhead[g]$,
the claim follows.\\

\textit{\rom{3} Is immediate form \rom{1} and \rom{2}.}\\

\rom{4} It follows form the fact $T\left(f+g\right)\subseteq T\left(f\right)\cup T\left(g\right)$. 
\end{proof}
\begin{rem}
We now define the notion of reduction of a polynomial. As said before,
we now restrict to polynomials over a field; the reason why is simple,
we need the inverse of the head coefficient of every polynomial on
the ring. 
\end{rem}

\begin{defn}
\label{def:reduction modulo }Let $f,g,p$ be polynomials in $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
with $f,p\neq0$, and let $P$ be a subset of $K\left[\variables[X]\right].$Then
we say
\begin{enumerate}
\item \nomenclature{$f\underset{p}{\rightarrow}g\left[t\right]$}{polynomial reduction}$f$\textbf{
reduces} \textbf{to} $g$ \textbf{modulo} $p$ \textbf{by} \textbf{eliminating}
$t$ (notation $f\underset{p}{\rightarrow}g\left[t\right]$), if $t\in T\left(f\right),$
there exists $s\in T$ with $s\cdot\thead[p]=t$, and 
\[
g=f-\frac{\coef}{\chead[p]}\cdot s\cdot p,
\]
\item \nomenclature{$f\underset{p}{\rightarrow}g$}{polynomial reduction}$f$
\textbf{reduces} \textbf{to} $g$ \textbf{modulo} $p$ (notation $f\underset{p}{\rightarrow}g$),
if $f\underset{p}{\rightarrow}g\left[t\right]$ for some $t\in T\left(f\right),$\\
 
\item \nomenclature{$f\underset{P}{\rightarrow}g\left[t\right]$}{polynomial reduction}$f$
\textbf{reduces} \textbf{to} $g$ \textbf{modulo} $P$ (notation $f\underset{P}{\rightarrow}g$),
if $f\underset{p}{\rightarrow}g$ for some $p\in P$,\\
 
\item \nomenclature{$f\underset{p}{\rightarrow}g$}{polynomial reduction}$f$
is \textbf{reducible} \textbf{modulo} $p$ if there exists $g\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
such that $f\underset{p}{\rightarrow}g$, and\\
 
\item \nomenclature{$f\underset{P}{\rightarrow}g$}{polynomial reduction}$f$
is \textbf{reducible} \textbf{modulo} $P$ if there exists $g\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
such that $f\underset{P}{\rightarrow}g$.\\
 
\end{enumerate}
\end{defn}

If $f$ is not reducible modulo $p$ (modulo $P$), then we say $f$
is\textbf{ \index{normal form modulo $p$}\index{normal form modulo $P$}in
normal form modulo} $p$ (\textbf{modulo} $P$). A \textbf{normal
form} of $f$ \textbf{modulo} $P$ is a polynomial $g$ that is in
normal form modulo $P$ and satisfies 
\[
f\underset{P}{\overset{*}{\rightarrow}}g,
\]
where $\underset{P}{\overset{*}{\rightarrow}}$ is the reflexive-transitive
closure of $\underset{P}{\rightarrow}$ (see Definition \ref{def:Closure}).
We call 
\[
f\underset{p}{\rightarrow}g\,\left[t\right],
\]

a \textbf{top-reduction \index{top-reduction}}of $f$ if $t=\thead[f]$;
whenever a top-reduction of $f$ exists (with $p\in P$), we say that
$f$ is \textbf{top-reducible} \textbf{modulo} $p$\textbf{ \index{top-reducible modulo $p$}\index{top-reducible modulo $P$}}(\textbf{modulo}
$P$).

As expected, reduction of polynomials can be computed. 
\begin{lem}
If $\leq$ is a decidable term order and $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
is a polynomial ring over a computable field, then $\underset{P}{\rightarrow}$
is decidable for every finite $P\subseteq K\left[\variables[X]\right].$ 
\end{lem}

\begin{proof}
Using the unique representation of a polynomial $f$ shown in Proposition
\ref{prop: unique representation}, we can clearly decide whether
or not $f$ is reducible modulo $P$ (note that $P$ is finite and
claim \rom{2} of the proposition asserts there is an algorithm to
