find that representation). In addition, if we can reduce $f$ modulo
$P$, then the computability of $K$ and $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
allows us to compute $f-\frac{\coef}{\chead[p]}\cdot s\cdot p,$ i.e.,
to compute $f\underset{P}{\rightarrow}g$. 
\end{proof}
Some simple properties about reductions on $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
are compiled in the following lemma. 
\begin{lem}
Let $f,g,p$ be polynomials in $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ and
$P$ a subset of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$. The the following
hold:
\begin{enumerate}
\item $f$ is reducible modulo $p$ iff there exists $t\in T\left(f\right)$
such that $\thead[p]\mid t$.\\
 
\item If $f\underset{p}{\rightarrow}f-mp$ for some monomial $m$, then
$\thead[mp]\in T\left(f\right)$.\\
 
\item Suppose $f\underset{p}{\rightarrow}g\,\left[t\right]$. Then $t\notin T\left(g\right),$
while for all $t'\in T$ with $t'>t$, we have $t'\in T\left(f\right)$
iff $t'\in T\left(g\right)$. In fact, $m\in M\left(f\right)$ iff
$m\in M\left(g\right)$ for every monomial $m>t$.\\
 
\item If $f\underset{p}{\rightarrow}g,$ then $g<f$.\\
 
\item If $f\reduction[P]*g$, then $g\leq f$, and $g=0$ or $\thead[g]\leq\thead[f]$. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{lem}

\begin{proof}
(i) and (ii) are immediate from the definitions.

{[}start=3{]} 
\begin{enumerate}
\item By Proposition \ref{prop: unique representation} (i), we can write
$f=\suma[i][1][k]m_{i}$ with $\variables[m][k][>]$. Because $f$
reduces to $g$ modulo $p$ by eliminating $t$, there exists $q\in T$
such that $q\cdot\thead[p]=t$, and so 
\[
m_{j}=\frac{\coef[t][f]}{\chead[p]}\cdot q\cdot\mhead[p]
\]
for some $1\leq j\leq k$. If we now write $\frac{\coef[t][f]}{\chead[p]}\cdot q\cdot p=\suma[i][1][s]r_{i}$
with $m_{j}=r_{1}>r_{2}>...>r_{s}$, then 
\[
g=f-\frac{\coef[t][f]}{\chead[p]}\cdot q\cdot p=\suma[i][1][k]m_{i}-m_{j}-\suma[][2][s]r_{i},
\]
and the claim follows since $m_{i}>r_{d}$ for all $1\leq d\leq s$
if $i<j$.\\
 
\item From (iii) above, we see that $T\left(g\right)<T\left(f\right)$ in
the well-order of $\mathcal{P}_{fin}\left(T\right)$ induced by $\leq$,
and so $g<f$.\\
 
\item The first statement follows easily from (iv) by induction on the length
of the reduction chain $f\reduction[P]*g$. The second one is now
obvious form the definition of the induced quasi-order. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
\begin{rem}
Inequality $g\leq f$ of \rom{5} is not strict. Because when doing
several reductions to a polynomial $f$ we still consider the terms
in $f$, and not only the terms of the reduced polynomials, we may
recover an eliminated term, which may provide the equality. With some
care this can be avoided in practice and the inequality may be considered
strict. 
\end{rem}

In Section \ref{sec:Reduction-relations} we saw the importance of
choosing a noetherian reduction relation. Therefore, wee may check
noetherian condition out of the list given the following result. 
\begin{thm}
\label{thm: reuction P is notherian} The relation $\reduction[P]{}$
is a noetherian reduction relation on $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
for every $P\subseteq K\left[\variables[X]\right].$ 
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
We have already seen that $\leq$ is a well-founded relation on $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
(see Theorem \ref{thm:Extension to well-founded quasi-order}) and
that if $f,g\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ with $f\reduction[P]{}g$,
then $g<f$ (see (iv) of Lemma above). Now we apply Lemma \ref{lem:ar_sb  implies  -> noehterian}
to finish the proof. 
\end{proof}
Now Lemma \ref{lem:noehterian has at least one normal form} applied
to the relation $\reduction[P]{}$ produces the desired result. 
\begin{cor}
Every polynomial $f\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ has at least
one normal form modulo $P$. 
\end{cor}

Actually, given a polynomial $f$ and a finite set of polynomials
$P$, there is an algorithm, Algorithm \ref{alg:REDPOL}, that on
input of $f,P$ produces a normal form of $f$ modulo $P$ as output.
Note that this algorithm, generalizes the division of polynomials
in one variable to the multivariate case, and from one divisor to
a (finite) family. 
\begin{prop}
\label{prop:REDPOL algo standard representation}Let $P$ be a subset
of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ and $f\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$.
Then there is a normal form $g\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ of
$f$ modulo $P$ and a family $\mathscr{F}=\left\{ q_{p}\right\} _{p\in P}$
of elements of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ with 
\[
f=\left(\Suma[p][P]q_{p}p\right)+g\mbox{ and }\max\left\{ \thead[q_{p}p]\mid p\in P,q_{p}p\neq0\right\} \leq\thead[f].
\]
If $P$ is finite, the ground field is computable, and the term order
on $T$ is decidable, then $g$ and $\left\{ q_{p}\right\} _{p\in P}$
can be computed form $f$ and $P$. 
\end{prop}

\begin{proof}
We give an algorithm, (Algorithm \ref{alg:REDPOL}) for the computation
of $g$ and $q_{p}$.

\begin{algorithm}[H]
\begin{description}
\item [{\caption{REDPOL\label{alg:REDPOL}}
}] ~
\item [{Specification:}] $\left(\mathscr{F},g\right)\leftarrow\mbox{REDPOL}\left(f,P\right)$\\
 Complete reduction of $f$ modulo $P$.
\item [{Given:}] a finite subset $P$ of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
and $f\in K\left[\variables[X]\right].$
\item [{Find:}] a normal form $g$ of $f$ modulo $P$, and a family of
polynomials $\mathscr{F}=\left\{ q_{p}\right\} _{p\in P}$ with $f=f=\left(\Suma[p][P]q_{p}p\right)+g$
and $\max\left\{ \thead[q_{p}p]\mid p\in P,q_{p}p\neq0\right\} \leq\thead[f].$
\item [{begin}] ~
\item [{$q_{p}\leftarrow0\left(\mbox{for all }p\in P\right)$}] ~
\item [{$g\leftarrow f$}] ~
\item [{while}] $g$ is reducible modulo $P$ \textbf{do}\\
 select $p\in P$ such that $g$ is reducible modulo $p$,\\
 determine a monomial $m$ with $g\reduction[p]{}g-mp$\\
 $g\leftarrow g-mp$\\
 $q_{p}\leftarrow q_{p}+m$
\item [{end}] ~
\item [{$\mathscr{F}\leftarrow\left\{ q_{p}\right\} _{p\in P}$}] ~
\item [{return$\left(\mathscr{F},g\right)$}] ~
\item [{end~REDPOL}] ~
\end{description}
\end{algorithm}

For general, possibly non-computable field, non-decidable term order
and infinite subset $P$, the steps of the algorithm can be interpreted
as mathematical constructions that prove the existence of the $q_{p}$.

Le us denote by $g_{i}$ the value of $g$ after the $i$-th run trough
the \textbf{while}-loop, with $g_{0}=f$.

\textit{Termination}: An infinite run of the \textbf{while-}loop would
rise to an infinite ascending chain $g_{0}\reduction[P]{}g_{1}\reduction[P]{}...,$
a contradiction with $\reduction[P]{}$ being a noetherian relation.

\textit{Correctness:} Suppose there are $N$ runs through the \textbf{while}-loop.
From $g_{i}\reduction[P]{}g_{i+1}$ for all $0\leq i<N$, we conclude
that $f\reduction[P]*g$ is an invariant of the loop. It is easy to
see that the equation 
\[
f=\left(\Suma[p][P]q_{p}p\right)+g
\]
is also a loop invariant. Finally, we claim that 
\[
\max\left\{ \thead[q_{p}p]\mid p\in P,q_{p}p\neq0\right\} \leq\thead[f],
\]
is an invariant of the loop. It is trivial true upon initialization.
Now suppose it is true after the $i$th run for $1\leq i<N$, then
$f\reduction[P]*g_{i}$ and $\thead[g_{i}]\leq\thead[f]$. Let $mp$
be the polynomial that is being subtracted form $g$ during the next
run. Then $\thead[mp]\in T\left(g\right)$ and so $\thead[mp]\leq\thead[g_{i}]\leq\thead[f]$;
because $T\left(g_{i}-mp\right)\subseteq T\left(g_{i}\right)\cup T\left(mp\right)$,
we have 
\[
\thead[g_{i}-mp]\leq\max\left\{ \thead[g_{i}],\thead[mp]\right\} \leq\thead[f],
\]
and the claim follows since $g_{i+1}=g_{i}-mp$. 
\end{proof}
\begin{rem}
Algorithm above is often referred as the division algorithm in several
variables. Following this terminology, the polynomial $g$ is called
residue and despite the univariate case, this residue is not necessarily
unique as shown on the introduction. 
\end{rem}

\begin{example}
\label{exa: normal form of spol}Consider the polynomial $f=2x^{2}y+\frac{5}{2}xy+\frac{3}{2}y+8x^{2}+\frac{3}{2}x-\frac{9}{2}$
and let $F=\left\{ f_{1},f_{2},f_{3}\right\} $ as in Remark \ref{rem: f_1 f_2  f_3}.
We see that $\thead[f_{1}]=x^{2}y$ divides $\thead[f]$, and so $f$
is reducible modulo $F$. In particular we have the reduction $f\reduction[F]{}h$
where $h=f_{1}-\frac{2}{3}f_{1}=\frac{7}{6}xy+\frac{5}{6}y+2x^{2}-\frac{11}{6}x-\frac{5}{2}$.
Because $\thead[h]$ is not divisible by $\thead[f_{i}]$ for any
$1\leq i\leq3$, the algorithm terminates with $f=\left(\frac{2}{3}f_{1}\right)+h$. 
\end{example}


\chapter{Gröbner Basis}

The Chapter is divided into 5 sections and is committed to proof Gröbner
basis existence and its construction via Buchberger's Algorithm. Section
\ref{sec:Congruece-relation} introduces the last and necessary results
for the proof of Gröbner bases existence, which is achieved in Section
\ref{sec:Gr=00003D0000F6bner-basis-existence}. In Section \ref{sec:Buchberger's-Algorithm}
Buchberger algorithm for constructing such bases is given, and then
improved in Section \ref{sec:Improved-Gr=00003D0000F6bner-Basis}.

\section{Congruence relation\label{sec:Congruece-relation}}

In this section, necessary and sufficient conditions for $f\reduction[P]*0$
are studied. The name of the section is referred to the membership
problem, which is now connected with reduction relation and constitutes
the main result of the section together with the more technical result
called \nameref{lem:Translation lemma} (Lemma \ref{lem:Translation lemma}). 
\begin{lem}
\label{lem:5.24implication with f in P and reduction to cero}Let
$P\subseteq K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ and $f,g,h\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$,
and let $m\in M$.
\begin{enumerate}
\item If $f\in P$, then $hf\reduction[P]*0$.\\
 
\item If $f\reduction[P]{}g,$ then $mf\reduction[P]{}mg$.\\
 
\item If $f\reduction[P]*g$, then $mf\reduction[P]*mg$. In particular,
$f\reduction[P]*0$ implies $mf\reduction[P]*0$. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{lem}

\begin{proof}
~
\begin{enumerate}
\item Assume for a contradiction that the set 
\[
H=\left\{ h\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]\mid\mbox{not }hf\reduction[P]*0\right\} 
\]
is non-empty. Then $H$ contains a $\leq$-minimal element $h\neq0$.
With $m=\mhead[h],$ we obtain $\mhead[hf]=m\cdot\mhead,$ and so
\[
hf\reduction[f]{}hf-mf\mbox{ and }hf-mf=\reductum[h]\cdot f.
\]
We have $\reductum[h]\notin H$ since $\reductum[h]<h$, and so $\reductum[h]\cdot f\reduction[P]*0$;
thus $hf\reduction[P]*0$, a contradiction. \\
 
\item Suppose $f\reduction[p]{}g$, say $g=f-m'p$ for some $p\in P$, then
$\thead[m'mp]\in T\left(f\right)$ and so $\thead[m'mp]\in T\left(fm\right)$.
Finally we see that 
\[
mf\reduction[p]{}mf-m'mp\mbox{ and }mf-mm'p=mg.
\]
\item This follows from (ii) by induction on the length $k$ of the reduction
chain $f\reduction[P]kg$. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{proof}
\begin{lem}[Translation Lemma]
\label{lem:Translation lemma} Let $f,g,h,h_{1}\in K\left[\variables[X]\right],$
and let $P\subseteq K\left[\variables[X]\right]$.
\begin{enumerate}
\item If $f-g=h$ and $h\reduction[P]*h_{1}$ then there exists $f_{1},g_{1}\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
such that $f_{1}-g_{1}=h_{1},$ $f\reduction[P]*f_{1}$, and $g\reduction[P]*g_{1}$.
\\
 
\item If $f-g\reduction[P]*0,$ then $f\downarrow g$, and so in particular
$f\underset{P}{\overset{*}{\fii}}g$. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{lem}

\begin{proof}
Note that \rom{2} is the special case of \rom{1} where $h=0$.
We now proof \rom{1} by induction on $k$, where $f-g=h$, and $h\reduction[P]kh_{1}$.
For $k=0$, $f_{1}=f$ and $g_{1}=g$ satisfy the claim. For $k+1$,
$f-g=h$ and $h\reduction[P]{k+1}h_{1}$; we split the reduction as
\[
h\reduction[P]kh_{2}\reduction[P]{}h_{1},
\]
for some polynomial $h_{2}$. By induction hypothesis, there exist
$f_{2},h_{2}$ such that 
\[
f_{2}-g_{2}=h_{2},\,\,\,\,\,f\reduction[P]*h_{2}\,\,\,\,\,\mbox{and}\,\,\,\,\,g\reduction[P]*g_{2}.
\]
We now proof there exist polynomials $f_{1},g_{1}$ such that 
\[
f\reduction[P]*f_{1},\,\,\,\,\,g_{2}\reduction[P]*g_{1}\,\,\,\,\,\mbox{and}\,\,\,\,\,f_{1}-g_{1}=h_{1},
\]
and so, by transitivity of $\reduction[P]*$, the result follows.
Because $h_{2}\reduction[P]{}h_{1}$ there exist $p\in P$, $u\in T$
such that 
\[
h_{1}=h_{2}-\frac{\coef[t][h_{2}]}{\chead[p]}\cdot u\cdot p.
\]
If the above reduction eliminates the term $t\in T\left(h_{2}\right)$,
because $f_{2}-g_{2}=h_{2}$, we have $t\in T\left(f_{2}\right)\cup T\left(g_{2}\right)$.
Now set 
\[
f_{1}=f_{2}-\frac{\coef[t][f_{2}]}{\thead[p]}\cdot u\cdot p\mbox{\,\,\,\, and \,\,\,\,}g_{1}=g_{2}-\frac{\coef[t][g_{2}]}{\thead[p]}\cdot u\cdot p,
\]
where $C\left(t,f_{2}\right)=0$ if $t\not\in T\left(f_{2}\right)$
and $C\left(t,g_{2}\right)=0$ is $t\not\in T\left(g_{2}\right)$.
In both cases we have $f_{2}\reduction[P]{}f_{1}$ and $g_{2}\reduction[P]{}g_{1}$.
In addition, if $h_{2}=f_{2}-g_{2}$ the relation among coefficients
$\coef[t][h_{2}]=\coef[t][f_{2}]-\coef[t][g_{2}]$ holds. Finally,
\[
f_{1}-g_{1}=\left(f_{2}-g_{2}\right)-\frac{\coef[t][f_{2}]-\coef[t][g_{2}]}{\chead[p]}\cdot u\cdot p=h_{2}-\frac{\coef[t][h_{2}]}{\chead[p]}\cdot u\cdot p=h_{1},
\]
as required. 
\end{proof}
\begin{lem}
\label{lem5.26:equiv related with fii}Let $P\subseteq K\left[\variables[X]\right]$,
and let $f,g\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$. Then $f\equiv_{\ideal[P]}g$
iff $f\overset{*}{\underset{P}{\fii}}g$. In particular, $f\overset{*}{\underset{P}{\fii}}g$
implies $f-g\in\ideal[P]$, and $f\reduction[P]*0$ implies $f\in\ideal$. 
\end{lem}

\begin{proof}
$``\Longleftarrow"$: We show by induction on $k\in\mathbb{N}$ that
$f\overset{k}{\underset{P}{\fii}}g$ implies $g-f\in\ideal[P]$. If
$k=0$, then $f=g$, and so $g-f=0\in\ideal[P]$.

Suppose the claim is true for every two polynomials related by $\underset{P}{\overset{k}{\fii}}$,
and consider $f\overset{k+1}{\underset{P}{\fii}}g$. Say 
\[
f\overset{k}{\underset{P}{\fii}}h\overset{}{\underset{P}{\fii}}g,
\]
then $h-f\in\ideal[P]$ by the induction hypothesis, and $g-h=mp$
for some $m\in M$, $p\in P$ by the definition of $\reduction[P]{}$.
Consequently, $g-f=\left(g-h\right)+\left(h-f\right)\in\ideal[P].$

$``\Longrightarrow"$: Let $g-f\in\ideal[P]$. Then there exists $p_{i}\in P$
and $h_{i}\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ with $1\leq i\leq k$
such that 
\[
g=f+\suma[i][1][k]h_{i}p_{i}.
\]
We show by induction on $k$ that $f\overset{*}{\underset{P}{\fii}}g$.
If $k=0$, then $f=g$. If 
\[
g=f+\suma[i][1][k]h_{i}p_{i}+k_{k+1}p_{k+1},
\]
we apply induction hypothesis to $g'=f+\suma[i][1][k]h_{i}p_{i}$
and so $g'\overset{*}{\underset{P}{\fii}}f$. Because $g=g'+h_{k+1}p_{k+1}$,
we have $g\underset{P}{\overset{*}{\fii}}f+h_{k+1}p_{k+1}$ and it
suffices to show that 
\[
\left(f+h_{k+1}p_{k+1}\right)\overset{*}{\underset{P}{\fii}}f.
\]
If we set $F=f+h_{k+1}p_{k+1}$ and $G=f$, then $F-G=h_{k+1}p_{k+1}$
which reduces to zero modulo $P$ by Lemma \ref{lem:5.24implication with f in P and reduction to cero}
\rom{1}. Now, case \rom{2} of \nameref{lem:Translation lemma}
(Lemma \ref{lem:Translation lemma}) applied to $F-G$ finishes the
proof. 
\end{proof}
\begin{cor}
\label{cor:reduction relation is adequate for equiv}Let $P\subseteq K\left[\variables[X]\right].$
Then the reduction relation $\reduction[P]{}$ on $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
is adequate for $\equiv_{\ideal}$. 
\end{cor}

\begin{defn}
\label{def:reduced and monic}Let $P\subseteq K\left[\variables[X]\right].$
Then $P$ is called \textbf{monic \index{monic}}if every $p\in P$
is monic. $P$ is called \textbf{reduced \index{reduced}\index{autoreduced}}(or
\textbf{autoreduced}) if every $p\in P$ is monic and in normal form
modulo $P\setminus\left\{ p\right\} $. 
\end{defn}

\begin{prop}
Let $P$ be a finite subset of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$. Suppose
the ground field is computable and the term order on $T$ is decidable.
Then the algorithm REDUCTION (Algorithm \ref{alg:REDUCTION}) computes
a finite reduced subset $Q$ of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ such
that $\ideal[Q]=\ideal[P]$. 
\end{prop}

\begin{proof}
~ 
\begin{algorithm}[H]
\caption[REDUCTION]{REDUCTION\label{alg:REDUCTION}}

\begin{description}
\item [{Specification:}] $Q\leftarrow\mbox{REDUCTION}\left(P\right)$\\
 Construction of a finite reduced set $Q$ such that $\ideal[Q]=\ideal[P]$
\item [{Given:}] a finite subset $P$ of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
\item [{Find:}] a finite reduced set in $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
with $\ideal[Q]=\ideal[P]$
\item [{begin}] ~
\item [{$Q\leftarrow P$}] ~
\item [{while}] there is $p\in Q$ which is reducible modulo $Q\setminus\left\{ p\right\} $\textbf{
do}\\
 select\textbf{ $p\in Q$ }which is reducible modulo $Q\setminus\left\{ p\right\} $\\
 $Q\leftarrow Q\setminus\left\{ p\right\} $\\
 $h\leftarrow$some normal form of $p$ modulo $Q$\\
 \textbf{if $h\neq0$ then $Q\leftarrow Q\cup\left\{ h\right\} $
end}
\item [{end}] ~
\item [{$Q\leftarrow\left\{ \chead[q]^{-1}\cdot q\mid q\in Q\right\} $}] ~
\item [{end~REDUCTION}] ~
\end{description}
\end{algorithm}

It is easy to see that $\ideal[Q]=\ideal[P]$ is an invariant of the
\textbf{while}-loop. \textit{Correctness} is obvious from the \textbf{while}-clause.
To prove\textit{ Termination,} let $P=\left\{ \variables[p][m]\right\} $
be the input set. We may regard $P$ as an ordered $m$-tuple $\left(\variables[p][m]\right)$
rather than a set. After a run on the loop, the algorithm replaces
an element $p_{j}\in P$ with some normal form $h$ of $p_{j}$ (no
matter if $h=0$). Let $Q_{i}$ denote the $m$-tuple obtained after
the $i$th run through the loop. If the algorithm does not terminate,
it produces an infinite sequence of $m$-tuples $\left\{ Q_{i}\right\} _{i\in\mathbb{N}}$
where $Q_{i}$ is never the zero-tuple for any $i\in\mathbb{N}$,
since otherwise the loop terminates. Moreover, since an entry that
becomes zero after $k$ runs of the loop never becomes nonzero, there
must be an entry that is replaced infinitely many times with nonzero
elements. Because we replace an element $p$ with some normal form
$h$ modulo $Q$ of $p$, we have $h<p$ and the sequence of normals
forms modulo $Q$ form a strictly descending chain w.r.t. the induced
well-founded quasi-order on $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$, a contradiction. 
\end{proof}
\begin{example}
\label{exa:Reduction p_1 p_2}Consider the set $P=\left\{ p_{1},p_{2}\right\} $
in $K\left[x,y\right]$ with the inverse lexicographical order given
by 
\begin{eqnarray*}
p_{1} & = & y-\frac{14}{3}x^{3}+\frac{38}{3}x^{2}+\frac{61}{6}x-3,\\
p_{2} & = & x^{3}-\frac{5}{2}x^{2}-\frac{5}{2}x.
\end{eqnarray*}
By initialization, $Q=P$, and the while-clause is satisfied since
$\thead[p_{2}]=x^{3}\in T\left(p_{1}\right)$, that is, we can reduce
$p_{2}\in Q$ modulo $Q\setminus\left\{ p_{2}\right\} =p_{1}$ by
eliminating the term $x^{3}$. Computation of $p_{1}\reduction[p_{2}]{}p_{1}-\left(\frac{-14}{3}\right)p_{2}=p_{1}'$
leads to the new polynomial $p_{1}'=y+x^{2}-\frac{3}{2}x-3$, which
is in normal form modulo $Q$, once removed $p_{1}$, and so the if-condition
is also satisfied. Thus, we have $Q=\left\{ p_{1}',p_{2}\right\} $
and the while-clause is no longer satisfied; because both $p_{1}'$
and $p_{2}$ are monic, the last actualization of $Q$ does not modify
it, and so $Q=\left\{ p_{1}',p_{2}\right\} $ is a reduced set with
$\ideal[Q]=\ideal[P]$. 
\end{example}

\begin{rem}
Algorithm \ref{alg:REDUCTION} when applied to $P=\left\{ f,g\right\} $
with $f,g\in K\left[X\right]$ produces as result $Q=\left\{ \gcd\left(f,g\right)\right\} $,
just like the Euclidean algorithm does. 
\end{rem}


\section{Gröbner basis existence\label{sec:Gr=00003D0000F6bner-basis-existence}}

\begin{comment}
Given an ideal $I$, we want a set $Q$ such that $\ideal[Q]=I$ and
$f\reduction[Q]*0$ iff $f\in I$. The direct implication is clear,
we want the converse to be true as well.

In case $\reduction[P]{}$ is locally confluent, as application of
Newman's Lemma results that $\reduction[P]{}$ has unique normal form,
and it can be computed algorithmically. Hence we can either check
if $f\reduction[Q]*0$ or not, and so we have converse implication.
In general $\reduction[P]{}$ is not locally confluent but we prove
that we can find another set $Q$ such that $\ideal=\ideal[Q]$ and
$\reduction[Q]{}$ locally confluent.
\end{comment}

Given an finitely generated ideal $I$, we want a finite set $P$
such that $\ideal[P]=I$ and $f\reduction[P]*0$ iff $f\in I$. The
direct implication is clear and the converse constitutes the object
of this section.

If $h$ is a normal form of $f$ modulo $P$, then $f\reduction[P]*h$
and $f=\suma[i][1][k]s_{i}p_{i}+h$ for some monomials $s_{i}\in M$
and polynomials $p_{i}\in P$. In case $\reduction[P]{}$ is locally
confluent, as application of Newman's Lemma $\reduction[P]{}$ has
a unique normal form and the Church-Rosser property. Then if $f\in I$,
then $h=f-\suma[i][1][k]s_{i}p_{i}\in I,$ and $h\equiv_{I}0$, that
is, $f\overset{*}{\underset{P}{\fii}}0$; by the Church-Rosser property,
$h\rightarrow r\leftarrow0$ for some $r$, and so $h=0$ , that is,
$f\reduction[P]*0$. Conversely, if $f\reduction[P]*0$, since $\reduction[P]{}$
has a unique normal form, $h=0$ and $f\in I$.

In general $\reduction[P]{}$ is not locally confluent but fortunately,
we prove that we can always find a finite set $G$ such that $\ideal[G]=\ideal[P]$
and $\reduction[G]{}$ locally confluent, i.e., every ideal finitely
generated has a Gröbner-basis.
\begin{defn}
If $P\subseteq K\left[\variables[X]\right]$, then we set $\thead[P]=\left\{ \thead[p]\mid0\neq p\in P\right\} ;$
for $S\subseteq T$, 
\[
\mbox{mult}\left(S\right)=\left\{ t\in T\mid\mbox{there is \ensuremath{s\in S} with \ensuremath{s\mid t}}\right\} 
\]
denotes\textbf{ the set of all multiples of elements of }$S$. \nomenclature{$\mbox{mult}\left(S\right)$}{ the set of all multiples of elements of $S$}\index{the set of all multiples of elements of $S$} 
\end{defn}

\begin{thm}[Theorem-Definition]
\label{thm:Theorem-Definition}A subset $G$ of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
is called a\textbf{ \index{Gröbner basis}Gröbner} \textbf{basis}
(w.r.t. the term order $\leq)$ if it is finite, $0\notin G$, and
$G$ satisfies one of the following equivalent conditions:
\begin{enumerate}
\item $\reduction[G]{}$ is locally confluent,\\
 
\item $\reduction[G]{}$ is confluent,\\
 
\item $\reduction[G]{}$ has unique normal form,\\
 
\item $\reduction[G]{}$ has the Church-Rosser property,\\
 
\item $f\reduction[G]*0$ for all $f\in\ideal[G]$,\\
 
\item every $0\neq f\in\ideal[G]$ is reducible modulo $G$,\\
 
\item every $0\neq f\in\ideal[G]$ is top-reducible modulo $G$,\\
 
\item for every $t\in\thead[{\ideal[G]}]$ there exists $s\in\thead[G]$
with $s\mid t$,\\
 
\item $\thead[{\ideal[G]}]\subseteq\mbox{mult}\left(\thead[G]\right)$,\\
 
\item the polynomials $h\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ that are in normal
form w.r.t. $\reduction[G]{}$ form a system of unique representatives
for the partition 
\[
\left\{ f+\ideal[G]\mid f\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]\right\} 
\]
of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
We now proof that \rom{1}-\rom{10} are equivalent. We have already
seen equivalence \rom{1}-\rom{4} or an arbitrary noetherian reduction
relation (see \nameref{thm:Newman's}, Theorem \ref{thm:Newman's}).

\rom{4}$\Rightarrow$\rom{5}: Let $f\in\ideal[G]$. Then $f-0\in\ideal[G]$
and thus $f\overset{*}{\underset{G}{\fii}}0$ by Lemma \ref{lem5.26:equiv related with fii}.
Since $\reduction[G]{}$ has the Church-Rosser property, there exists
$h\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ with $f\reduction[G]*h$ and $0\reduction[G]*h$.
Since $0$ is always in normal form, $h=0$.

\rom{5}$\Rightarrow$\rom{7}: Let $0\neq f\in\ideal[G]$. By (v),
there exists $h\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ with $f\reduction[G]{}h\reduction[G]*0$.

\rom{6}$\Rightarrow$\rom{7}: Assume for contradiction that $0\neq f\in\ideal[G]$
is minimal (w.r.t. the induced quasi-order on $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$)
such that it is not top-reducible w.r.t. $\reduction[G]{}$. Then
by (vi), there exists $h\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ with $f\reduction[G]{}h$.
It follows that $h\in\ideal[G]$ and $h<f$. Moreover, $\mhead[h]=\mhead[f]$
since $f$ was not top-reducible. By the minimal choice of $f$, $h$
is top-reducible w.r.t. $\reduction[G]{}$, say $h\reduction[g]{}h_{1}$
for some $g\in G$. Then, $\thead[g]\mid\thead[h]$, and so $f$ is
top-reducible w.r.t. $\reduction[g]{}$, a contradiction.

\rom{7}, \rom{8} and \rom{9} are simple reformulations of each
other.

\rom{9}$\Rightarrow$\rom{10}: Assume for contradiction that there
exist $f_{1},f_{2}\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ both in normal
form w.r.t. $\reduction[G]{}$ with $f_{1}\neq f_{2}$ and 
\[
f_{1}+\ideal[G]=f_{2}+\ideal[G].
\]
Then, $f_{1}-f_{2}\in\ideal[G]$ and so there exist $g\in G$ with
$\thead[g]\mid\thead[f_{1}-f_{2}]$, but 
\[
\thead[f_{1}-f_{2}]\in T\left(f_{1}\right)\cup T\left(f_{2}\right),
\]
hence $f_{1}$ or $f_{2}$ is reducible modulo $G$, a contradiction.

\rom{10}$\Rightarrow$\rom{4}: Let $f_{1},f_{2}\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
with $f_{1}\underset{G}{\overset{*}{\fii}}f_{2}$. Then $f_{1}-f_{2}\in\ideal[G]$
by Lemma \ref{lem5.26:equiv related with fii}, and so 
\[
f_{1}+\ideal[G]=f_{2}+\ideal[G].
\]
Let $h_{1}$ and $h_{2}$ be normal forms of $f_{1}$ and $f_{2}$,
respectively. Then $h_{1},h_{2}\in f_{1}+\ideal[G]$ again by Lemma
\ref{lem5.26:equiv related with fii}, and so $h_{1}=h_{2}$ by \rom{10}. 
\end{proof}
\begin{rem}
Among all previous equivalent conditions, \rom{3} and \rom{5}
are conceptually the most clarifying. It is also worth noting that
the definition of Gröbner-basis, which is usually referred as a set
$G$ generating an ideal, is also a property (or properties) of the
reduction relation $\reduction[G]{}$ upon which the definition is
based, and so $G$ being a Gröbner basis is also dependent on the
induced quasi-order on $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$, and term order
on $T$. 
\end{rem}

\begin{defn}
If $I$ is an ideal of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$, then a \textbf{Gröbner}
\textbf{basis} \textbf{of} $I$\textbf{ \index{Gröbner basis of $I$}}(w.r.t.
$\leq)$ is a Gröbner basis $G$ (w.r.t. $\leq)$ such that $\ideal[G]=I$. 
\end{defn}

Next result, although simple, constitutes a characterization of Gröbner
basis $G$, being the unique subset of an ideal $I$, generating the
whole ideal $I$ with the property $f\reduction[G]*0$ for all $f\in I$
(together with other equivalent properties). 
\begin{prop}
\label{prop:Grobner of an ideal}Let $I$ be an ideal of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
and $G$ a finite subset of $I$ with $0\notin G$. Then each of the
following is equivalent to $G$ being a Gröbner basis of $I$.
\begin{enumerate}
\item $f\reduction[G]*0$ for all $f\in I$,\\
 
\item every $0\ne f\in I$ is reducible modulo $G$,\\
 
\item every $0\neq f\in I$ is top-reducible modulo $G$,\\
 
\item for every $s\in\thead[I]$ there exists $t\in\thead[G]$ with $t\mid s$,\\
 
\item $\thead[I]\subseteq mult\left(\thead[G]\right)$,\\
 
\item the polynomials $h\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ that are in normal
form w.r.t. $\reduction[G]{}$ form a system of representatives for
the partition 
\[
\left\{ f+I\mid f\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]\right\} 
\]
of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{prop}

\begin{proof}
We prove \rom{1} implies $G$ is a Gröbner basis of $I$ and then,
we prove that \rom{1}-\rom{6} are equivalent.

If \rom{1} holds, $f\reduction[G]*0$ for all $f\in I$, and because
$\ideal[G]\subseteq I$, $G$ is a Gröbner basis. Now we apply Lemma
\ref{lem:5.24implication with f in P and reduction to cero} and $f\reduction[G]*0$
implies $f\in\ideal[G]$, that is, $I=\ideal[G]$.

Equivalence of \rom{1}-\rom{6} is consequence of \rom{5}-\rom{10}
of the Gröbner basis \nameref{thm:Theorem-Definition} (Theorem \ref{thm:Theorem-Definition}). 
\end{proof}
We can now give a proof of the Gröbner bases existence. 
\begin{thm}
\label{thm:Grobner basis existence}Let $I$ be an ideal of $K\left[\variables[X]\right].$
Then there exists a Gröbner basis $G$ of $I$ w.r.t. $\leq$. 
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
By Theorem \ref{thm:4.42 The-divisibility-relation is a Dickson partial order},
the divisibility relation is a Dickson partial order on $T$. So the
set $\thead[I]$ has a finite basis $S$ w.r.t. divisibility relation.
For each $t\in S$, there exists $f_{t}\in I$ such that $\thead[f_{t}]=t$.
Let now $G=\left\{ f_{t}\mid t\in S\right\} $. Then $G$ satisfies
condition \rom{4} of the previous proposition, and so $G$ is Gröbner
basis of $I$. 
\end{proof}
Although the previous result is positive, it presents two difficulties
in order to compute the relation $\equiv_{I}$ for an ideal $I$ of
$K\left[\variables[X]\right]$. The first one is that we don't have
a way to construct a Gröbner basis, the second one, Gröbner basis
are not uniquely determined by the ideal and so we may consider different
basis for an ideal. Fortunately, both problems can be solved; first
problem will be dealt in the next chapter, and the second one can
be easily solved with the concept of\textbf{\textit{ \index{reduced Gröbner basis}reduced
Gröbner basis}}\textbf{ }(see Definition \ref{def:reduced and monic}).

In the following we give a proof of the existence and uniqueness of
reduced Gröbner bases. However, in the next section we provide a new
formulation of Gröbner basis that is useful for both comprehension
of the concept and for simplification of the reduced Gröbner basis\textit{
}proof\textit{.} 
\begin{lem}
Suppose $I$ is an ideal of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$, $m$ is
a monomial, and $f,g$ are minimal polynomials in $I$ such that $\mhead[f]=\mhead[g]=m$.
Then $f=g$. 
\end{lem}

\begin{proof}
We must have $T\left(f\right)=T\left(g\right)$ since otherwise $f<g$
or $g<f$. Note that $f-g\in I$, and $f-g=0$ or $s=\thead[f-g]<m$.
In the latter case $s\in T\left(f\right)=T\left(g\right)$, we can
reduce $f$ modulo $f-g$ so that $f\reduction[f-g]{}h$ and $h<f$
contradicting the minimality of $f$. 
\end{proof}
\begin{thm}
Let $I$ be an ideal of $K\left[\variables[X]\right].$ Then there
exists a unique reduced Gröbner basis $G$ of $I$ w.r.t. $\leq$. 
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
As in Theorem \ref{thm:Grobner basis existence} let $S$ be the unique
minimal basis of $\thead[I]$. For each $t\in S$, there exits $f_{t}\in T$
with , and because $I$ is an ideal,w.o.l.g. we may consider $\mhead[f_{t}]=t$.
Indeed, by the above lemma we may consider $f_{t}$ is the unique
minimal polynomial with $\mhead[f_{t}]=t$. We now set 
\[
G=\left\{ f_{t}\mid t\in S\right\} ,
\]
and claim that $G$ is the unique reduced Gröbner basis of $I$. By
definition, $G$ is monic and if $G$ is not reduced, there exist
$g_{1}\neq g_{2}\in G$ and $f\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ with
$g_{1}\reduction[g_{2}]{}f$. We may assume that the reduction is
a top reduction since otherwise $\mhead[f]=\mhead[g_{1}]$ with $f<g$,
again the minimality of $g_{1}\in G$. Therefore, $\thead[g_{2}]\mid\thead[g_{1}]$
and so $S'=S\backslash\left\{ \thead[g_{1}]\right\} $ is also a basis
of $\thead[I]$ with $S'\subseteq S$, a contradiction with the minimality
of $S$.

We now proof uniqueness. Assume for a contradiction that $H$ is another
reduced Gröbner basis of $I$, and let $g$ be an element of the symmetric
set difference $G\bigtriangleup H$ (see Chapter \ref{chap:Notation-and-Initials})
such that $\thead[g]$ is minimal in $\thead[G\bigtriangleup H]$.
W.l.o.g. let $g\in G\setminus H$; given that $H$ is a Gröbner basis,
there exists $h\in H$ so that $\thead[h]\mid\thead[g]$ and by the
minimality of $g$, $\thead[g]=\thead[h]$. Consider now $f=g-h$
then we clearly see that $f\in I$, $f<g$ and $\thead[f]\in T\left(g\right)\cup T\left(h\right)$.
If $\thead[f]\in T\left(g\right)$, because $f\in I$, there exist
polynomial $p\in T\left(g\right)$ so that $\thead[p]\mid\thead[f]\in T\left(g\right)$
contradicting the fact that $G$ was reduced. In case $\thead[f]\in T\left(g\right)$
we reason analogously to reach the contradiction. 
\end{proof}

\section{Reduced Gröbner bases\label{sec:Reduced-Gr=00003D0000F6bner-bases}}

We now discuss some definitions relating Gröbner basis which are frequently
used. We show the equivalence between this new definitions and those
given early and use them as to simplify the proof of reduced Gröbner
basis existence. In particular, what is been here exposed can be found
in \cite{book_profesor_Ideals_varieties_and_algorithms}. 
\begin{defn}[Alternative Definition]
For a fixed term ordering in $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$, a finite
subset $G=\left\{ \variables[g][t]\right\} $ of an ideal $I$ is
said to be a \textbf{Gröbner basis \index{Gröbner basis}}if 
\[
\ideal[{\thead[G]}]=\ideal[{\thead[I]}].
\]
\end{defn}

\begin{rem}
Using \rom{4} of Gröbner basis \nameref{thm:Theorem-Definition}
(Theorem \ref{thm:Theorem-Definition}) we can easily see the equivalence
between both definitions. 
\end{rem}

\begin{defn}
A \textbf{minimal Gröbner basis \index{minimal Gröbner basis}}for
a polynomial ideal $I$ is a Gröbner basis $G$ for $I$ such that:
\begin{enumerate}
\item $\chead[g]=1$ for all $g\in G$, and\\
 
\item for all $g\in G$, $\thead[g]\notin\ideal[{\thead[G']}]$ where $G'=G\setminus\left\{ g\right\} $. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{defn}

\begin{thm}
Let $G$ be a Gröbner basis for the ideal $I$, and let $g\in G$
be a polynomial such that $\thead[g]\in\ideal[G']$. Then $G\setminus\left\{ g\right\} $
is also a Gröbner basis. 
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
If $\thead[g]\in\ideal[{\thead[G\setminus\left\{ g\right\} ]}]$,
then $\ideal[{\thead[G\setminus\left\{ g\right\} ]}]=\ideal[{\thead[G]}]=\ideal[{\thead[I]}]$
since $G$ is a Gröbner basis and the claim follows. 
\end{proof}
\begin{rem}
Clearly converting a Gröbner basis $G$ to a monic set doesn't change
the fact that $G$ is a Gröbner basis. Now, theorem above shows that
reducing $G$ to $G'$ by eliminating those polynomials $g\in G$
with $\thead[g]\in\ideal[G']$ does implies that $G'$ is also a Gröbner
basis. Then, since Gröbner bases exist for any ideal $I$, so do minimal
Gröbner bases. 
\end{rem}

\begin{defn}
\label{def: 2 definition reduced-Gr=00003D0000F6bner-basis}A\textbf{
\index{reduced Gröbner basis}reduced Gröbner basis} for a polynomial
ideal $I$ is a Gröbner basis $I$ such that:
\begin{enumerate}
\item $\chead[g]=1$ for all $g\in G$, and \\
 
\item for all $g\in G$, no monomial of $g$ lies in $\ideal[{\thead[G']}]$
where $G'=G\setminus\left\{ g\right\} $. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{defn}

\begin{rem}
Definition above and our first definition are equivalent. Condition
\rom{1} stands that $G$ is monic and we claim condition \rom{2}
is equivalent to $g$ is not reducible modulo $G'$. If $g$ is reducible
modulo $G'$, there exists $g_{2}\in G'$ so that $\thead[g_{2}]\mid t$
for some $t\in T\left(g\right)$, and if $m$ is the monomial in $g$
so that $t\in T\left(m\right)$, then $m\in\ideal[{\thead[G']}]$.
Conversely, if some monomial $m$ of $g$ lies in $\ideal[{\thead[G']}]$,
in particular $m=a\productorio[i][1][k]\thead[g_{i}]$ for some $a\in K$,
$g_{i}\in G$, and so $\thead[g_{i}]\mid t$ where $t\in T\left(m\right)$,
that is, $g$ is reducible modulo $G'$. 
\end{rem}

\begin{prop}
Let $\left\{ 0\right\} \neq I\subseteq K\left[\variables[X]\right]$.
Then, for a given monomial ordering, $I$ has unique reduced Gröbner
basis. 
\end{prop}

\begin{proof}
Let $G$ be a minimal Gröbner basis for $I$. Our goal is to modify
$G$ until all its elements are reduced.

A first observation is that if $g$ is reduced for $G$, then $g$
is also reduced for any other minimal Gröbner basis of $I$ that contains
$g$ and has the same set of leading terms. This follows because the
definition only involves the leading terms.

Given $g\in G$, take $g'$ a normal form of $g$ modulo $G'=G\setminus\left\{ g\right\} $
and set $G^{*}=\left(G\setminus\left\{ g\right\} \right)\cup\left\{ g'\right\} $.
Then we have $\thead[g']=\thead[g]$ since $\thead[g]$ is not divisible
by any element of $\thead[G']$ and so when dividing $g$ by $G'$,
$\thead[g]$ goes to the remainder. This shows that $\ideal[{\thead[G^{*}]}]=\ideal[{\thead[G]}]$
and because $G^{*}\subseteq I$ we conclude that $G^{*}$ is a minimal
Gröbner basis of $I$ and $g'$ is reduced for $G^{*}$ by construction.

Now take the elements of $G$ and apply the above process until they
are all reduced. The Gröbner basis may change each time we do the
process, but our earlier observation shows that once element is reduced,
it stays reduced since we never change the leading terms. Thus, we
end up with a reduced Gröbner basis.

In remains to prove uniqueness. Suppose $G$ and $\widetilde{G}$
are reduced Gröbner bases for $I$. Then in particular, $G$ and $\widetilde{G}$
are minimal Gröbner bases. We now prove that $\thead[G]=\thead[\widetilde{G}]$.
Take $t_{1}\in\thead[G],$ because $t_{1}\in\ideal[{\thead[G]}]=\ideal[{\thead[\widetilde{G}]}]$
there exist some $\widetilde{t}\in\thead[\widetilde{G}]$ so that
$\widetilde{t}\mid t_{1}$. Repeating the argument for $\widetilde{t},$
there exists $t_{2}\in\thead[G]$ so that $t_{2}\mid\widetilde{t}$.
If the relation $t_{2}\mid\widetilde{t}\mid t_{1}$ holds for $t_{1}\neq t_{2}$,
then there exist $g_{1}\in G$ with $\thead[g_{1}]=t_{1}$ so that
$t_{1}\in\mathit{\ideal[{\thead[G\setminus\left\{ g_{1}\right\} ]}]}$
since $t_{2}\mid t_{1}$ and $t_{2}\in\thead[G\setminus\left\{ g\right\} ]$,
a contradiction. Hence $t_{1}=t_{2}=\widetilde{t}$ and the claim
is proved. (Notice that this also implies that $G$ and $\widetilde{G}$
have the cardinal).

Given $g\in G$, take $\widetilde{g}\in\widetilde{G}$ such that $\thead[g]=\thead[\widetilde{g}]$.
Because $g-\widetilde{g}\in I$, we have $g-\widetilde{g}\reduction[G]*0$,
and $\thead[g]=\thead[\widetilde{g}]$, this term cancels in $g-\widetilde{g}$,
and the remaining terms are divisible by none of the $\thead[G]=\thead[\widetilde{G}]$
since $G$, $\widetilde{G}$ are reduced Gröbner basis. Hence $g-\widetilde{g}$
is in normal for modulo $G$, by uniqueness of normal forms $g-\widetilde{g}=0$
and $G=\widetilde{G}$. 
\end{proof}
\begin{rem}
\label{rem:REDUCTIOn TO GROBNER}Form what has been argued on the
proof we see that application of Algorithm \ref{alg:REDUCTION} to
a Gröbner basis produces a reduced Gröbner basis. 
\end{rem}


\section{Buchberger's Algorithm \label{sec:Buchberger's-Algorithm}}

For the construction of Gröbner basis, a special class of polynomials,
called $S$-polynomials are introduced. This polynomials play a decisive
roll in Buchberger's algorithm. Before that, a sufficient condition
for $G$ being a Gröbner basis is given. 
\begin{lem}
\label{lem:suficient condition for grobner basis, m1m1-m2g2 reduces to cero}Let
$G$ be a finite subset of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ with $0\notin G$.
Assume that whenever $g_{1},g_{2}\in G$ with $g_{1}\neq g_{2}$ and
monomials $m_{1}$, $m_{2}$ such that 
\[
\mhead[m_{1}g_{1}]=\mhead[m_{2}g_{2}],
\]
it follows that $m_{1}g_{1}-m_{2}g_{2}\reduction[G]*0$. Then $G$
is a Gröbner basis. 
\end{lem}

\begin{proof}
We show that $\reduction[G]{}$ is locally confluent. Let $f,f_{1},f_{2}\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
with $f\reduction[G]{}f_{i}$ where $f_{i}=f-m_{i}g_{i}$ for some
$m_{i}\in M$, $g_{i}\in G$ for $i=1,2$. It suffices to show that
$f_{1}-f_{2}=m_{1}g_{1}-m_{2}g_{2}\reduction[G]*0$ so by application
of \nameref{lem:Translation lemma} (Lemma \ref{lem:Translation lemma}),
claim \rom{2}, $f_{1}\downarrow_{G}f_{2}$.

If $\thead[m_{1}g_{1}]=\thead[m_{2}g_{2}]=t$, because $f$ reduces
to $f_{i}=f-m_{i}g_{i}$, the equality $\mhead[m_{1}g_{1}]=\mhead[m_{2}g_{2}]$
holds, and by hypothesis $m_{1}g_{1}-m_{2}g_{2}\reduction[G]*0$ if
$g_{1}\neq g_{2}$. In case $g_{1}=g_{2},$ then $f_{1}-f_{2}=\left(m_{1}-m_{2}\right)g_{1}\reduction[G]{}0$
by statement \rom{1} Lemma \ref{lem:5.24implication with f in P and reduction to cero}.
Now consider the case $\thead[m_{1}g_{1}]\neq\thead[m_{2}g_{2}]$,
say $\thead[m_{1}g_{1}]>\thead[m_{2}g_{2}]$. Then we can perform
the top reductions $m_{1}g_{1}-m_{2}g_{2}\reduction[g_{1}]{}-m_{2}g_{2}$
by means of $g_{1}\in G$ and then $-m_{2}g_{2}\reduction[g_{2}]{}0$
by means of $g_{2}\in G$. Hence $m_{1}g_{1}-m_{2}g_{2}\reduction[G]*0$
and the claim follows. 
\end{proof}
\begin{defn}
For $i=1,2$, let $0\neq g_{i}\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$, and
$s_{i}\in T$ such that $s_{i}\cdot\thead[g_{i}]=\lcm\left(\thead[g_{2}],\thead[g_{2}]\right)$.
Then the $\mathbf{S}$\textbf{-polynomial} \nomenclature{$\spol$}{$S$-polynomial of $g_1$ and $g_2$}\index{S-polynomial}of
$g_{1}$ and $g_{2}$ is defined as 
\[
\spol=\chead[g_{2}]s_{1}g_{1}-\chead[g_{1}]s_{2}g_{2}.
\]
\end{defn}

\begin{example}
\label{exa:spol}\cite{paper1985multidimensional} Given $f_{1}:=3x^{2}y+2xy+y+9x^{2}+5x-3$
and $f_{2}:=2x^{3}y-x-y+6x^{3}-2x^{2}-3x+3$ we have 
\begin{eqnarray*}
\spol[f_{1}][f_{2}] & = & 3\cdot x\cdot f_{1}-2\cdot1\cdot f_{2},\\
 & = & 2x^{2}y+\frac{5}{2}xy+\frac{3}{2}y+8x^{2}+\frac{3}{2}x-\frac{9}{2}.
\end{eqnarray*}
\end{example}

The concept of $S$-polynomials besides its practical utility for
constructing a Gröbner basis, also provide a new characterization
for such basis. The following result will be needed when construction
Buchberger's algorithm. 
\begin{thm}[Characterization of Gröbner bases by $S$-polynomials]
\label{thm:5.48 Caracterizacion Grobner base con spol}Let $G$ be
a finite subset of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ with $0\notin G$.
Then the following are equivalent:
\begin{enumerate}
\item $G$ is a Gröbner basis,\\
 
\item whenever $g_{1},g_{2}\in G$ and $h\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
is a normal form of $\spol$ modulo $G$, then $h=0$,\\
 
\item $\spol\reduction[G]*0$ for all $g_{1},g_{2}\in G$. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
\rom{1}$\Rightarrow$\rom{2}: $\spol$ is obviously in $\ideal[G]$
for all $g_{1},g_{2}\in G$. So by Gröbner basis \nameref{thm:Theorem-Definition}
(Theorem \ref{thm:Theorem-Definition}), $\spol$ reduces to $0$
modulo $G$, and uniqueness of normal forms implies $h=0$.

\rom{2}$\Rightarrow$\rom{3}: It is trivial.

\rom{3}$\Rightarrow$\rom{1}: We show that whenever $g_{1},g_{2}\in G$
with $g_{1}\neq g_{2}$ and $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ are monomials such
that 
\begin{equation}
\mhead[m_{1}g_{1}]=\mhead[m_{2}g_{2}],\label{eq:*}
\end{equation}
it follows that $m_{1}g_{1}-m_{2}g_{2}\reduction[G]*0$ and then apply
Lemma \ref{lem:suficient condition for grobner basis, m1m1-m2g2 reduces to cero}.
For $i=1,2$, let $t_{i}=\thead[g_{i}]$, $a_{i}=\chead[g_{i}]$ and
$m_{i}=b_{i}u_{i}$ with $b_{i}\in K$ and $u_{i}\in T$. Then Equation
(\ref{eq:*}) becomes 
\begin{equation}
b_{1}a_{1}u_{1}t_{1}=b_{2}a_{2}u_{2}t_{2}.\label{eq:**}
\end{equation}
Now let $s_{1},s_{2}\in T$ such that $s_{i}t_{i}=\lcm\left(t_{1},t_{2}\right)$
for $i=1,2$. From Equation (\ref{eq:**}) we see that $u_{1}t_{1}=u_{2}t_{2}$
is a common multiple of $t_{1}$ and $t_{2}$. Hence there exists
$v\in T$ such that for $i=1,2$, 
\[
u_{i}t_{i}=v\cdot\lcm\left(t_{1},t_{2}\right)=vs_{i}t_{i}.
\]
We see that $u_{i}=vs_{i}$. Furthermore, Equation (\ref{eq:**})
implies that $\left(b_{1}/a_{2}\right)=\left(b_{2}/a_{1}\right)$,
and we obtain 
\begin{eqnarray*}
m_{1}g_{1}-m_{2}g_{2} & = & b_{1}u_{1}g_{1}-b_{2}u_{2}g_{2}\\
 & = & b_{1}vs_{1}g_{1}-b_{2}vs_{2}g_{2}\\
 & = & \frac{b_{1}}{a_{2}}\cdot v\cdot\left(a_{2}s_{1}g_{1}-a_{1}s_{2}g_{2}\right)\\
 & = & \frac{b_{1}}{a_{2}}\cdot v\cdot\spol.
\end{eqnarray*}
Using Lemma \ref{lem:5.24implication with f in P and reduction to cero}
\rom{1} and the fact that $\spol\reduction[G]*0$, we conclude that
\[
\frac{b_{1}}{a_{2}}\cdot v\cdot\spol\reduction[G]*0.
\]
\end{proof}
\begin{cor}
Let $G$ be a finite subset of $K\left[\variables[X]\right].$ Suppose
the ground field is computable, and the term order on $T$ is decidable.
Then the algorithm \ref{alg:GR=00003D0000D6BNERTEST} decides whether
$G$ is a Gröbner basis or not. 
\end{cor}

\begin{algorithm}[H]
\begin{description}
\item [{\caption{GRÖBNERTEST\label{alg:GR=00003D0000D6BNERTEST}}
}] ~
\item [{Specification:}] $v\leftarrow$GRÖBNERTEST$\left(G\right)$\\
 Test whether $G$ is a Gröbner basis
\item [{Given:}] $G=\mbox{a finite subset of }K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
\item [{Find:}] $v\in\left\{ \mathbf{true},\mathbf{false}\right\} $ such
that $v=\mathbf{true}$ iff $G$ is a Gröbner basis
\item [{begin}] ~
\item [{$B\leftarrow\left\{ \left(g_{1},g_{2}\right)\mid g_{1},g_{2}\in G\mbox{ with }g_{1}\neq g_{2}\right\} $}] ~
\item [{while}] $B\neq\emptyset$ \textbf{do} \\
 select $\left\{ g_{1},g_{1}\right\} $ form $B$ \\
 $h\leftarrow$ some normal form of $\spol$ modulo $G$\\
 \textbf{if} $h=0$\textbf{ then}\\
 \textbf{~~$B\leftarrow B\setminus\left\{ \left\{ g_{1},g_{2}\right\} \right\} $}\\
 \textbf{else }\\
 \textbf{~~return(false)}\\
 \textbf{end}
\item [{end}] ~
\item [{return(true)}] ~
\item [{end~GRÖBNERTEST}] ~
\end{description}
\end{algorithm}

\begin{example}
Let $F=\left\{ f_{1},f_{2},f_{3}\right\} $ as in Remark \ref{rem: f_1 f_2  f_3}.
We now form Example \ref{exa:spol} that $\spol[f_{1}][f_{2}]=2x^{2}y+\frac{5}{2}xy+\frac{3}{2}y+8x^{2}+\frac{3}{2}x-\frac{9}{2}$,
and form Example \ref{exa: normal form of spol}, a normal form for
$\spol[f_{1}][f_{2}]$ is $h=\frac{7}{6}xy+\frac{5}{6}y+2x^{2}-\frac{11}{6}x-\frac{5}{2}$.
Because $h\neq0$, the algorithm return $\mathbf{false}$, that is,
$F$ is not a Gröbner basis w.r.t. the inverse lexicographical order. 
\end{example}

The main result of this section, and also of the chapter, is now given. 
\begin{thm}[Buchberger's Algorithm]
Let $F$ be a finite subset of $K\left[\variables[X]\right].$ Suppose
the ground field is computable, and the term order on $T$ is decidable.
Then Algorithm \ref{alg:BUCHBERGER} computes $G$ in $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
such that $F\subseteq G$ and $\ideal[G]=\ideal[F]$. 
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
\begin{algorithm}[H]
\caption{BUCHBERGER\label{alg:BUCHBERGER}}

\begin{description}
\item [{Specification:}] $G\leftarrow$BUCHBERGER$\left(F\right)$\\
 Construction of a Gröbner basis $G$ of $\ideal[F]$
\item [{Given:}] $F=\mbox{a finite subset of }K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
\item [{Find:}] $G=\mbox{a finite subset of }K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
such that $G$ is a Gröbner basis in $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$with
$F\subseteq G$ and $\ideal[G]=\ideal[F]$.
\item [{begin}] ~
\item [{$G\leftarrow F$}] ~
\item [{$B\leftarrow\left\{ \left\{ g_{1},g_{2}\right\} \mid g_{1},g_{2}\in G\mbox{ with }g_{1}\neq g_{2}\right\} $}] ~
\item [{while}] $B\neq\emptyset$ \textbf{do}\\
 select $\left\{ g_{1},g_{2}\right\} $ from $B$ \\
 $B\leftarrow B\setminus\left\{ \left\{ g_{1},g_{2}\right\} \right\} $\\
 $h\leftarrow\spol$\\
 $h_{0}\leftarrow$ some normal form of $h$ modulo $G$\\
 \textbf{if} $h_{0}\neq0$\textbf{ then}\\
 \textbf{~~$B\leftarrow B\cup\left\{ \left\{ g,h_{0}\right\} \mid g\in G\right\} $}\\
 \textbf{~~$G\leftarrow G\cup\left\{ h_{0}\right\} $}\\
 \textbf{end}
\item [{end}] ~
\item [{end~BUCHBERGER}] ~
\end{description}
\end{algorithm}

\textit{Termination}: Assume for contradiction that the \textbf{while}-loop
does not terminate. Let $F=G_{0}\subset G_{1}\subset G_{2}\subset...$
be the successive value of $G$. Considering those runs through the
\textbf{while}-loop that actually enlarge $G$, we see that there
exists an ascending sequence $\left\{ n_{i}\right\} _{i\in\mathbb{N}}$
of natural numbers such that for all $1\leq i\in\mathbb{N}$, there
exists $h_{i}\in G_{n_{i}}\setminus G_{n_{i-1}}$ which is in normal
form modulo $G_{n_{i-1}}$. Let $t_{k}=\thead[h_{k}]$ for all $k\in\mathbb{N}$;
then $i<j$ implies that $t_{i}$ does not divide $t_{j}$, since
otherwise $h_{j}$ would be top-reducible modulo $\left\{ h_{i}\right\} $
and hence modulo $\left\{ G_{n_{j-1}}\right\} $. Since divisibility
of terms is a Dickson partial order, this contradicts Proposition
\ref{prop:4.42 Dickson quasi order equivalence} \rom{2}.

\textit{Correctness}: It is clear that $F\subseteq G\subseteq\ideal[F]$
with $G$ a finite subset of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ is a loop
invariant. We show that 
\[
\spol\reduction[G]*0,
\]
for all $g_{1},g_{2}\in G$ and so by Theorem \ref{thm:5.48 Caracterizacion Grobner base con spol}
$G$ is Gröbner basis.

Take $g_{1},g_{2}\in G$ with $g_{1}\neq g_{2}$, that is, $\left(g_{1},g_{2}\right)\in B$
and say that the pair has been considered at the $i$th run of the
\textbf{while}-loop. Because $\spol\reduction[G_{i}]*h_{0}$, if $h_{0}=0$
we are done, otherwise, $h_{0}\neq0$ and $G_{i+1}=G_{i}\cup\left\{ h_{0}\right\} $.
Since $G_{i}\subseteq G$ for all $i$, $\spol\reduction[G]*0$ as
required. 
\end{proof}
Note that this algorithm is non-deterministic; the resulting Gröbner
basis is not uniquely determined by the input $F$ since different
pairs may be choose form the set $B$. We will refer to this pairs
as \index{critical pairs}\textbf{critical pairs}.

It is also clear that the algorithm is potentially rather complex.
In the next section, we will see how the growth of the set $B$ can
be controlled by elimination unnecessary pairs. 
\begin{example}
\label{exa: f_1 f_7}\cite{paper1985multidimensional} We now perform
the Buchberger's algorithm to the set $F=\left\{ f_{1},f_{2},f_{3}\right\} $
defined in Remark \ref{rem: f_1 f_2  f_3}. Recall that if instead
of adding $h_{0}$ to $G$ in Buchberger's algorithm, we add $h_{0}$
multiplied by a scalar, we still have a Gröbner basis $G$ as output.
Hence we can add $h_{0}$ once normalized, that is, after multiplying
by the inverse of the head coefficient as to make $h_{0}$ monic.

We know from the previous example that $\spol[f_{1}][f_{2}]=2x^{2}y+\frac{5}{2}xy+\frac{3}{2}y+8x^{2}+\frac{3}{2}x-\frac{9}{2}.$
Now, a $\reduction[G]{}$-normal form $h_{0}$ of $\spol[f_{1}][f_{2}]$
is $\frac{7}{6}xy+\frac{5}{6}y+2x^{2}-\frac{11}{6}x-\frac{5}{2}$
by Example \ref{exa: normal form of spol}; instead of adding the
previous normal form to the set $G$, we normalize it by multiplying
by $\frac{6}{7}$ and so we add $f_{4}=xy+\frac{5}{7}y+\frac{12}{7}x^{2}-\frac{11}{7}x-\frac{15}{7}$
to $G$. Now, a (normalized) normal form of $\spol[f_{1}][f_{4}]$
is $f_{5}=y-\frac{14}{3}x^{3}+\frac{38}{3}x^{2}+\frac{61}{6}x-3$,
which we add to $G$.

If we now calculate the $S$-polynomial of $f_{4}$ and $f_{5}$ (both
polynomials in $G$), and then some normal form, which we normalize,
we reach the polynomial $f_{6}=x^{4}-2x^{3}-\frac{15}{4}x^{2}-\frac{5}{4}x$,
and again, we add it to $G$.

Finally, we reach the last new polynomial $f_{7}=x^{3}-\frac{5}{2}x^{2}-\frac{5}{2}x$
after normalizing the normal form of $\spol[f_{1}][f_{3}]$.

Now, the $S$-polynomial of any two pairs $f_{i},f_{j}$ in $G$ has
$0$ as normal form, and so no polynomial is added to $G=\left\{ \variables[f][7]\right\} $
during any future execution of the while-loop. Hence the, Buchberger's
algorithm produces $G$ as output, and so, $G$ is a Gröbner basis
for $\ideal[F]$. 
\end{example}

In the following we give an algorithm to compute a reduced Gröbner
basis given a Gröbner basis. As commented in Remark \ref{rem:REDUCTIOn TO GROBNER},
application of Algorithm \ref{alg:REDUCTION} (REDUCTION) to the output
of Algorithm \ref{alg:BUCHBERGER} (BUCHBERGER) may produce the desired
reduced Gröbner basis. However this procedure may be more costly than
the necessary and the following procedure may be taken in account. 
\begin{prop}
Let $G$ be a Gröbner basis in $K\left[\variables[X]\right].$ Suppose
$K$ is computable and the term order on $T$ is decidable. Then the
following algorithm computes the reduced Gröbner basis of $\ideal[G]$. 
\end{prop}

\begin{proof}
~

\begin{algorithm}[H]
\begin{description}
\item [{\caption{REDGRÖBNER\label{alg:REDGR=00003D0000D6BNER}}
}] ~
\item [{Specification:}] $H\leftarrow$GRÖBNER$\left(G\right)$\\
 Construction of a Gröbner basis of $\ideal[G]$
\item [{Given:}] $G\mbox{ a Gröbner basis in }K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
\item [{Find:}] $H$ the reduced Gröbner basis of $\ideal[G]$
\item [{begin}] ~
\item [{$H\leftarrow\emptyset$\textmd{;$F\leftarrow G$}}] ~
\item [{while}] $F\neq\emptyset$ \textbf{do} \\
 select $h$ from $F$ \\
 $F\leftarrow F\setminus\left\{ h\right\} $\\
 \textbf{if} $\thead\nmid\thead[h]$ for all $f\in F\cup H$ \textbf{then}\\
 \textbf{$H\leftarrow H\cup\left\{ h\right\} $}\\
 \textbf{end}
\item [{end}] ~
\item [{$H\leftarrow$REDUCTION($H$)}] ~
\item [{end~REDGRÖBNER}] ~
\end{description}
\end{algorithm}

\textit{Termination} of the algorithm is clear. Now we proof \textit{Correctness.}
We see that the if condition looks for a polynomial in $f\in F\cup H$
so that $\thead[f_{0}]$ is multiple of $\thead[f]$ and in case such
polynomial does not exist, it adds $f_{0}$ to $H$. Hence $\mbox{mult}\left(\thead[F\cup H]\right)$
is a loop-invariant. Since upon initialization $F=G$ and $H=\emptyset$,
$\mbox{mult}\left(\thead[F\cup H]\right)=\mbox{mult}\left(G\right)$
and since at the end of the loop $F=\emptyset$, $\mbox{mult}\left(\thead[H]\right)=\mbox{mult}\left(G\right)$
given that $\mbox{mult}\left(\thead[F\cup H]\right)$ is a loop-invariant.
By Proposition \ref{prop:Grobner of an ideal} \rom{5}, $H$ is
a Gröbner basis of $\ideal[G]$.

To see that $H$ is reduced at the end of the loop, notice that $\thead[f]\nmid\thead[h]$
for all $h\in H$ and for all $f\in F\cup\left(H\setminus\left\{ h\right\} \right)$
is a loop-invariant (provided that $\mbox{mult}\left(\thead[F\cup H]\right)$
is a loop-invariant). At the end, $F=\emptyset$ and the loop-invariant
implies $\thead[h_{1}]\nmid\thead[h_{2}]$ for all $h_{1},h_{2}\in H$,
i.e., $\thead[H]$ is a reduced set. Now, execution of Algorithm \nameref{alg:REDUCTION}
(REDUCTION) does not change the set $\mbox{mult}\left(\thead[H]\right)$
since the reductions carried out by the algorithm are not top reductions,
otherwise $\thead[H]$ would not be reduced. Hence, after application
of Algorithm \ref{alg:REDUCTION} (REDUCTION), $H$ is a reduced Gröbner
basis of $\ideal[G]$. 
\end{proof}
\begin{example}
\label{exa:reduced grobner basis}Consider the Gröbner basis $G=\left\{ \variables[f][7]\right\} $
provided by Example \ref{exa: f_1 f_7}, that is, 
\begin{eqnarray*}
f_{1} & = & 3x^{2}y+2xy+y+9x^{2}+5x-3,\\
f_{2} & = & 2x^{3}y-x-y+6x^{3}-2x^{2}-3x+3,\\
f_{3} & = & x^{3}y+x^{2}y+3x^{3}+2x^{2},\\
f_{4} & = & xy+\frac{5}{7}y+\frac{12}{7}x^{2}-\frac{11}{7}x-\frac{15}{7},\\
f_{5} & = & y-\frac{14}{3}x^{3}+\frac{38}{3}x^{2}+\frac{61}{6}x-3,\\
f_{6} & = & x^{4}-2x^{3}-\frac{15}{4}x^{2}-\frac{5}{4}x,\\
f_{7} & = & x^{3}-\frac{5}{2}x^{2}-\frac{5}{2}x.
\end{eqnarray*}

We see that $\thead[f_{5}]$ divides the head term of $f_{1},f_{2},f_{3}$
and $f_{4}$ and no term in $\thead[G]$ divides $\thead[f_{5}]$,
thus $f_{5}\in H$ while $f_{1},f_{2},f_{3},f_{4}\notin H$. Now,
$\thead[f_{7}]$ divides $\thead[f_{6}]$ and so $f_{6}\notin H$
while $f_{7}\in H$ since no term in $\thead[G]$ divides $\thead[f_{7}]$.
As shown in Example \ref{exa:Reduction p_1 p_2}, application of REDUCTION
to $H=\left\{ f_{5},f_{7}\right\} $ leads to the reduced Gröbner
basis $\left\{ y+x^{2}-\frac{3}{2}x-3,\,\,x^{3}-\frac{5}{2}x^{2}-\frac{5}{2}x\right\} $
for $\ideal[F]$ where $F=\left\{ f_{1},f_{2},f_{3}\right\} $ w.r.t.
the inverse lexicographical order. 
\end{example}


\section{Improved Buchberger's Algorithm\label{sec:Improved-Gr=00003D0000F6bner-Basis}}

For the improvement of Buchberger's Algorithm, two results known as
Buchberger's criterion's, and first given by Buchberger itself in
\cite{buchberger1979criterion}, are needed. This results together
with its applications to the Buchberger's Algorithm constitute the
object of this section. 
\begin{defn}
Let $0\neq f\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$, $P$ a finite subset
of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$. A representation 
\[
f=\suma[i][1][k]m_{i}p_{i},
\]
with monomials $0\neq m_{i}\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ and $p_{i}\in P$
not necessarily pairwise different ($\Valores[][][k]$) is called
a\textbf{ \index{standard representation}standard representation
}of $f$ w.r.t. $P$ (and $\leq$) if 
\[
\max\left\{ \thead[m_{i}p_{i}]\mid\Valores[][][k]\right\} \leq\thead[f].
\]

In case that 
\[
\max\left\{ \thead[m_{i}p_{i}]\mid\Valores[][][k]\right\} \leq t,
\]
for some $t\in T$, we also say that $f$ has a $t$\textbf{-representation}
w.r.t. to $P$. \index{t-representation} 
\end{defn}

The following result is immediate from the definition and Proposition
\ref{prop:REDPOL algo standard representation}. 
\begin{thm}
A finite subset $G$ of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ with $0\notin G$
is a Gröbner basis w.r.t. the term order $\leq$ iff $0\neq f\in\ideal[G]$
has a standard representation w.r.t. $G$ and $\leq$. 
\end{thm}

With the previous definition, we have a new sufficient condition for
a a Gröbner basis. 
\begin{thm}
\label{thm:5.64 t representations implies grobner}Let $G$ be a finite
subset of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ with $0\neq G$. Assume that
for all $g_{1},g_{2}\in G$, $\spol$ either equals zero or it has
a $t$-representation w.r.t. $G$ for some $t<\lcm\left(\thead[g_{1}],\thead[g_{2}]\right)$.
Then $G$ is a Gröbner basis. 
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
We show that any polynomial $0\neq f\in\ideal[G]$ has a standard
representation w.r.t. $G$ and $\leq$. Because $f\in\ideal[G]$ we
can write 
\[
f=\Suma[g][G]p_{i}g,
\]
with $p_{i}\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ by Proposition \ref{prop:REDPOL algo standard representation}.
Reordering the above summands, we have 
\[
f=\suma[i][1][k]m_{i}g_{i},
\]
where the $m_{i}$ are monomials and the $g_{i}$ are not necessarily
distinct. In this case, we denote $s=\max\left\{ \thead[m_{i}g_{i}]\mid1\leq i\leq k\right\} $,
and say $s$ is the head term of the representation. Because the above
representation is not unique the term $s$ depends on the representation
and we may consider we picked one so the head term $s$ is minimal
among all possible head terms of all representations. Clearly, $\thead[f]\leq s$
and we claim that $\thead[f]=s$.

Assume for contradiction that $\thead[f]<s$, we proof there exists
a representation of $f$ with head term of the representation $s'$
with $s'<s$. In order to do so, we use induction on the number $n_{s}$
of summands in $\suma[i][1][k]m_{i}g_{i}$ with $s=\thead[m_{i}g_{i}]$.
Because $s\notin T\left(f\right)$, then $s$ cancels out of the sum
and so $n_{s}>1$.

Suppose $n_{s}=2$, say $\thead[m_{1}g_{1}]=\thead[m_{2}g_{2}]=s$.
Now we argue as in Theorem \ref{thm:5.48 Caracterizacion Grobner base con spol}
\rom{3}$\Rightarrow$\rom{1}, in order to show that $m_{1}g_{1}+m_{2}g_{2}$
is multiple of $\spol$. Because $\thead[m_{i}g_{i}]=s$, we have
$m_{i}=a_{i}t_{i}$ with $a_{i}\in K$ and $t_{i}\in T$ for $i=1,2$.
Moreover, $s=t_{i}\thead[g_{i}]$ and $s=u\cdot\lcm\left(\thead[g_{1}],\thead[g_{2}]\right)$
for some term $u\in T$. Now write 
\[
\spol=\chead[g_{2}]\cdot u_{1}\cdot g_{1}-\chead[g_{1}]\cdot u_{2}\cdot g_{2},
\]
with $u_{i}\in T$ and $u_{i}\thead[g_{i}]=\lcm\left(\thead[g_{1}],\thead[g_{2}]\right)$.
Hence $t_{i}=u\cdot u_{i}$, and because $s\nmid m_{1}g_{1}+m_{2}g_{2}$,
$a_{1}\chead[g_{1}]+a_{2}\chead[g_{2}]=0$ and so $\frac{a_{1}}{\chead[g_{2}]}=-\frac{a_{2}}{\chead[g_{1}]}$.
Now, 
\begin{eqnarray}
m_{1}g_{1}+m_{2}g_{2} & = & a_{1}t_{1}g_{1}+a_{2}t_{2}g_{2},\nonumber \\
 & = & a_{1}uu_{1}g_{1}+a_{2}uu_{2}g_{2},\nonumber \\
 & = & \frac{a_{1}}{\chead[g_{2}]}\chead[g_{2}]uu_{1}g_{1}+\frac{a_{2}}{\chead[g_{1}]}\chead[g_{1}]uu_{2}g_{2},\nonumber \\
 & = & \underbrace{\left[\frac{a_{1}}{\chead[g_{2}]}\cdot u\right]}_{=:a\cdot u}\cdot\left[\chead[g_{2}]u_{1}g_{1}-\chead[g_{1}]u_{2}g_{2}\right],\label{eq:spol}\\
 & = & a\cdot u\cdot\spol.\nonumber 
\end{eqnarray}
By hypothesis, $\spol=0$ or it has a $t$-representation for some
$t<\lcm\left(\thead[g_{1}],\thead[g_{2}]\right)$. In case $\spol=0$,
then $mg_{1}+m_{2}g_{2}=0$ and $\suma[i][3][k]m_{i}g_{i}$ is a representation
for $f$ with head term less than $s$. Otherwise $\spol\neq0$ and
has a $t$-representation, say $\spol=\suma[i][1][k']m_{i}'g_{i}'$
where $g_{i}\in G$ for all $i$. Joining this to Equation \ref{eq:spol}
produces 
\[
f=\suma[i][3][k]m_{i}g_{i}+au\suma[i][1][k']m_{i}'g_{i}',
\]
which is again a contradiction since the head term of the first summand
is less than $s$, and for the right hand, $ut<u\cdot\mlcm=s$. Therefore
the above is a $s'$-representation with $s'<s$ and the claim is
proved for $n_{s}=2$. Now suppose $n_{s}>2$ and w.l.o.g. assume
$\thead[m_{i}g_{i}]=s$ for $i=1,2$. Then, 
\begin{eqnarray*}
f & = & \suma[i][1][k]m_{i}g_{i},\\
 & = & \underbrace{m_{1}g_{1}-\frac{\chead[m_{1}g_{1}]}{\chead[m_{2}g_{2}]}m_{2}g_{2}}_{h_{1}}+\underbrace{\left(\frac{\chead[m_{1}g_{1}]}{\chead[m_{2}g_{2}]}+1\right)m_{2}g_{2}}_{h_{2}}+\underbrace{\suma[i][3][k]m_{i}g_{i}}_{h_{3}},
\end{eqnarray*}
where the term $s$ does not appear in $h_{1}$, and does appear in
$h_{3}$ $n_{s}-2$ times and at most once in $h_{2}$, that is, $n_{s}-1$
in total. By induction hypothesis, $h_{1}+h_{2}+h_{3}$ has a $s'$-representation
with $s'<s$ and so does $f$, a contradiction. 
\end{proof}
\begin{defn}
We call $s,t\in T$ \textbf{disjoint \index{disjoint}}if $s$ and
$t$ have no variable in common, i.e., $\gcd\left(s,t\right)=1$,
which implies $\lcm\left(s,t\right)=st$. 
\end{defn}

\begin{lem}[Buchberger's First Criterion]
\label{lem:Buchberger's First Criterion} Let $f,g\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
with disjoint head terms. Then $\spol[f][g]\reduction[\left\{ f,g\right\} ]*0$. 
\end{lem}

\begin{proof}
Assume that 
\[
f=\suma[i][1][k]a_{i}s_{i}\mbox{ and }g=\suma[j][1][l]b_{j}t_{j},
\]
are the representations of $f,g$ as sum of monomials $a_{i}s_{i}$
and $b_{j}t_{j}$ with $s_{i},t_{j}\in T$ so that $\variables[s][k][>]$
and $\variables[t][l][>]$. Since $\gcd\left(s_{1},t_{1}\right)=1$,
we must have $\lcm\left(s_{1},t_{1}\right)=s_{1}t_{1}$ and thus 
\[
\spol[f][g]=b_{1}t_{1}f-a_{1}s_{1}g=b_{1}t_{1}\suma[i][2][k]a_{i}s_{i}-a_{1}s_{1}\suma[j][2][l]b_{j}t_{j}.
\]
We claim that the two sums have no terms in common. If $t_{1}s_{i}=s_{1}t_{j}$
for some $2\leq i\leq k$ and $2\leq j\leq l$, then $s_{i}t_{1}$
being a common multiple of $s_{1}$ and $t_{1}$, is divided by $\lcm\left(s_{1}t_{1}\right)=s_{1}t_{1}$.
It follows that $s_{1}t_{1}\leq s_{i}t_{1}$ and thus $s_{1}\leq s_{i}$,
a contradiction.

Now we write $a_{1}s_{1}=f-\suma[i][2][k]a_{i}s_{i}$, and substituting
in $\spol[f][g]$, we have 
\begin{eqnarray*}
\spol[f][g] & = & b_{1}t_{1}\suma[i][2][k]a_{i}s_{i}+\suma[j][2][l]b_{j}t_{j}f+\suma[j][2][l]b_{j}t_{j}\suma[i][2][k]a_{i}s_{i}.
\end{eqnarray*}
We now claim that by reducing the above expression modulo $g$ eliminating
the term $t_{j}\thead$ for $j=2,...,l$, we only eliminate the sum
$\suma[j][2][l]b_{j}t_{j}f$. To see this notice that $\thead[f]$
is neither present on the first sum nor in the third one since $f,g$
have disjoint terms and $s_{1}=\thead[f]$ is not it any of them.
Hence 
\begin{eqnarray*}
\spol[f][g] & \reduction[f]* & b_{1}t_{1}\suma[i][2][k]a_{i}s_{i}+\suma[j][2][l]b_{j}t_{j}\suma[i][2][k]a_{i}s_{i}\\
 & = & g\suma[i][2][k]a_{i}s_{i}\\
 & \reduction[g]* & 0.
\end{eqnarray*}
\end{proof}
\begin{rem}
If $s,t,u\in T$. The following are equivalent:
\begin{enumerate}
\item $t\mid\lcm\left(s,u\right)$\\
 
\item $\lcm\left(s,t\right)\mid\lcm\left(s,u\right)$\\
 
\item $\lcm\left(t,u\right)\mid\lcm\left(s,u\right)$. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{rem}

\begin{proof}
\rom{1}$\Leftrightarrow$\rom{2}: By definition $s,t\cdot a$
divides $\lcm\left(s,t\cdot a\right)$, and so does $s,t$. Hence
$\lcm\left(s,t\right)\mid\lcm\left(s,t\cdot a\right)$. Now by \rom{1},
$\lcm\left(s,u\right)=t\cdot a$ for some $a\in T$, and hence, $\lcm\left(s,t\right)\mid\lcm\left(s,\lcm\left(s,u\right)\right)=\lcm\left(s,u\right)$.
Conversely, $t\mid\lcm\left(s,t\right)\mid\lcm\left(s,u\right)$ and
\rom{1} holds. 
\end{proof}
\begin{prop}[Buchberger's Second Criterion]
\label{prop:Buchberger's Second Criterion}Let $F$ be a finite subset
of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ and $g_{1},g_{2},p\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
such that the following hold:
\begin{enumerate}
\item $\thead[p]\mid\lcm\left(\thead[g_{1}],\thead[g_{2}]\right),$ and\\
 
\item $\spol[g_{i}][p]$ has a $t_{i}$-representation with respect to $F$
with $t_{i}<\lcm\left(\thead[g_{i}],\thead[p]\right)$ for $i=1,2$. 
\end{enumerate}
Then the $S$-polynomial $\spol$ has a $t$-representation w.r.t.
$F$ for some $t<\lcm\left(\thead[g_{1}],\thead[g_{2}]\right)$. 
\end{prop}

\begin{proof}
By assumption \rom{2}, $\spol[g_{i}][p]$ has a $t_{i}$-representation
for $i=1,2$, say

\[
\spol[g_{1}][p]=\suma[i][][k_{1}]m_{1i}f_{1i},
\]
with $\max\left\{ \thead[m_{1i}f_{1i}]\mid\Valores[][][k_{1}]\right\} <\lcm\left(\thead[g_{1}],\thead[p]\right)$,
and 
\[
\spol[p][g_{2}]=\suma[i][][k_{2}]m_{2i}f_{2i},
\]
with $\max\left\{ \thead[m_{2i}f_{2i}]\mid\Valores[][][k_{2}]\right\} <\lcm\left(\thead[p],\thead[g_{2}]\right)$,
where $m_{ij}\in M$ and $f_{ij}\in F$. Because $p\mid\mlcm$, by
the previous remark there exist $s_{1},s_{2}\in T$ with 
\begin{eqnarray*}
s_{1}\cdot\mlcm[g_{1}][p] & = & \mlcm,\\
s_{2}\cdot\mlcm[p][g_{2}] & = & \mlcm.
\end{eqnarray*}

Let $a=\chead[g_{1}]$, $b=\chead[p]$, $c=\chead[g_{2}]$ and consider
$u_{1},v_{1},u_{2},v_{2}\in T$ such that 
\begin{eqnarray*}
\mlcm[g_{1}][p] & = & u_{1}\cdot\thead[g_{1}]=v_{1}\cdot\thead[p],\\
\mlcm[p][g_{2}] & = & u_{2}\cdot\thead[p]=v_{2}\thead[g_{2}].
\end{eqnarray*}

By the above, we can easily see that $s_{1}v_{1}=s_{2}u_{2}$, and
so 
\begin{eqnarray*}
cs_{1}\spol[g_{1}][p]+as_{2}\cdot\spol[p][g_{2}] & = & cs_{1}\left(bu_{1}g_{1}-av_{1}p\right)+as_{2}\left(cu_{2}p-bv_{2}g_{2}\right)\\
 & = & cbs_{1}u_{1}g_{1}-abs_{2}v_{2}g_{2}\\
 & = & b\cdot\spol.
\end{eqnarray*}

Substituting $\spol[g_{1}][p]$ and $\spol[g_{2}][p]$ by its representations
on the above equation, we get 
\begin{equation}
\spol=\frac{1}{b}\left(cs_{1}\suma[i][][k_{1}]m_{1i}f_{1i}+as_{2}\suma[i][][k_{2}]m_{2i}f_{2i}\right).\label{eq:SC}
\end{equation}

By the choice of these representations, we may conclude that 
\begin{eqnarray*}
s_{1}\cdot\thead[m_{1i}f_{1i}] & < & s_{1}\cdot\mlcm[g_{1}][p]\\
 & = & \mlcm,
\end{eqnarray*}
for $\Valores[][][k_{1}],$ and similarly, 
\begin{eqnarray*}
s_{2}\cdot\thead[m_{2i}f_{2i}] & < & s_{2}\cdot\mlcm[p]\\
 & = & \mlcm,
\end{eqnarray*}

for $\Valores[][][k_{2}].$ Now if we let $t$ be a maximal of $s_{1}\cdot\thead[m_{1j}f_{1j}]$
for $1\leq j\leq k_{1}$ and $s_{2}\cdot\thead[m_{2j}f_{2j}]$ for
$1\leq j\leq k_{2}$, then we see that Equation \ref{eq:SC} is a
$t$-representation of $\spol$ and $t<\mlcm$. 
\end{proof}
Proposition and lemma above can be used to improve \nameref{alg:BUCHBERGER}
(Algorithm \ref{alg:BUCHBERGER}). Before to present the implementations,
we shall discuss the idea behind of this results. We discuss the possible
implementations described in paper \cite{paper1985multidimensional},
and give the Algorithm \ref{alg:GR=00003D0000D6BNERNEW1} of \cite{book-bueno-Grobner_Bases}.
Certainly, the algorithm is due to Buchberger and was first published
in \cite{buchberger1979criterion}.

For an speed up of the Buchberger's algorithm (Algorithm \ref{alg:BUCHBERGER}),
three different strategies may apply. 
\begin{enumerate}
\item The order of selection of pairs the pairs $\left\{ g_{1},g_{2}\right\} $
for which the $S$-polynomials are formed have a crucial influence
on the complexity of the algorithm. As general rule, pairs whose least
common multiple of their head terms are minimal w.r.t. $\leq$ should
be treated first. This strategy is known as \textbf{normal \index{normal strategy}strategy}.\\
 
\item Each time a new polynomial is adjoined to the basis, all the other
polynomials may be reduced using also the new polynomial. Moreover,
if this process is carried out in the course of the algorithm, the
result is a reduced Gröbner basis.\\
 
\item Since the most expensive operations in the algorithm are the reduction
of the normal form $h$ modulo $G$ in the \textbf{while}-loop, application
of Buchberger's criterion's allows us to detect if a certain $S$-polynomial
$h$ can be reduced to zero without carrying out the reduction. 
\end{enumerate}
In the following algorithm, we implement strategies \rom{1} and
\rom{3}. The reader is advised to consult \cite{paper1985multidimensional},
page 196, as it discusses the use of three different strategies
\begin{thm}
Let $F$ be a finite subset of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$. Suppose
the ground field is computable and the term order on $T$ is decidable.
Then Algorithm \ref{alg:GR=00003D0000D6BNERNEW1} computes a Gröbner
basis $G$ in $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ such that $\ideal[G]=\ideal[F]$. 
\end{thm}

\begin{proof}
~

\begin{algorithm}[H]
\begin{description}
\item [{\caption{GRÖBNERNEW1\label{alg:GR=00003D0000D6BNERNEW1}}
}]~
\item [{Specification:}] \textbf{$G\leftarrow\mbox{GRÖBNERNEW1}\left(F\right)$}\\
 Construction of a Gröbner basis $G$ for $\ideal[F]$
\item [{Given:}] $F=$ a finite subset of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
\item [{Find:}] $G=$ a finite subset of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
such that $G$ is a Gröbner basis in $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
with $\ideal[G]=\ideal[F]$
\item [{begin}] ~
\item [{$G\leftarrow F$}] \% It is also possible to set \textbf{$G\leftarrow\mbox{REDUCTION}\left(F\right)$}
\item [{$B\leftarrow\left\{ \left\{ g_{1},g_{2}\right\} \mid g_{1},g_{2}\in G\mbox{ with non-disjoint head terms, }g_{1}\neq g_{2}\right\} $}] ~
\item [{create~a~matrix~$M$~with~boolean~entry~$M\left(g_{1},g_{2}\right)$~for~each~$g_{1},g_{2}\in G$~with~$g_{1}\neq g_{2}$}] ~
\item [{for~all}] $\left\{ g_{1},g_{2}\right\} $ with $g_{1},g_{2}\in G$
with $g_{1}\neq g_{2}$ \textbf{do}\\
 \textbf{if} $\left\{ g_{1},g_{2}\right\} \in B$ \textbf{then} $M\left(g_{1},g_{2}\right)\leftarrow$\textbf{false}\\
 \textbf{else $M\left(g_{1},g_{2}\right)\leftarrow$true end}
\item [{end}] ~
\item [{while}] $B\neq\emptyset$ \textbf{do}\\
 select $\left\{ g_{1},g_{2}\right\} $ form $B$ with $\mlcm$\\
 minimal among all pairs in $B$\\
 $B\leftarrow B\setminus\left\{ \left\{ g_{1},g_{2}\right\} \right\} $\\
 $M\left(g_{1},g_{2}\right)\leftarrow$\textbf{true}
\begin{description}
\item [{if}] there does not exist $p\in G$ with: \\
 $\thead[p]\mid\mlcm$ and $M\left(g_{1},p\right)=M\left(g_{2},p\right)=\mathbf{true}$,\textbf{
then}\\
 \textbf{$h\leftarrow\spol$}\\
 \textbf{$h_{0}$ }some normal form of $h$ modulo $G$
\begin{description}
\item [{if}] $h_{0}\neq0$ \textbf{then}
\begin{description}
\item [{for~all}] $g\in G$ \textbf{do}\\
 enlarge $M$ by an entry for $\left\{ h_{0},g\right\} $
\begin{description}
\item [{if}] $\thead[g],\thead[h_{0}]$ are disjoint \textbf{then}\\
 $M\left(g,h_{0}\right)\leftarrow$ \textbf{true}
\item [{else}] ~
\item [{~}] $B\leftarrow B\cup\left\{ \left\{ g,h_{0}\right\} \right\} $
\\
 $M\left(g,h_{0}\right)\leftarrow$\textbf{false}
\item [{end~if}] ~
\end{description}
\item [{end~for}] ~
\end{description}
\item [{~}] $G\leftarrow G\cup\left\{ h_{0}\right\} $
\item [{end~if}] ~
\end{description}
\item [{end~if}] ~
\end{description}
\item [{end~while}] ~
\item [{return~($G$)}] ~
\item [{end~GRÖBNERNEW1}] ~
\end{description}
\end{algorithm}

\textit{Termination: }The algorithm terminates since an infinite loop
would be an infinite loop of the \nameref{alg:BUCHBERGER} (Algorithm
\ref{alg:BUCHBERGER}).

\textit{Correctness:} We first note that 
\[
F\subseteq G\subseteq\ideal[F],
\]
with $G$ finite is an invariant of the \textbf{while}-loop. Thus
the output $G_{out}$ is a finite basis of the ideal $\ideal[F].$
To see that $G$ is a Gröbner basis, we verify the hypothesis of Theorem
\ref{thm:5.64 t representations implies grobner}. Assume for contradiction
that there exists a pair $\left\{ g_{1},g_{2}\right\} \in G_{out}$
such that $\spol$ does not have a $t$-representation w.r.t. $G_{out}$
for any $t<\mlcm$. If $g_{1}$ and $g_{2}$ have disjoint head terms,
then $\spol$ would reduce to $0$ modulo $G_{out}$ by \nameref{lem:Buchberger's First Criterion}
(Lemma \ref{lem:Buchberger's First Criterion}) and thus even have
$\spol$ has a standard representation w.r.t. $G_{out}$ by Proposition
\ref{prop:REDPOL algo standard representation}. We may assume that
$g_{1,}g_{2}$ have non disjoint head terms, that is, $\left(g_{1},g_{2}\right)\in B$
and w.l.o.g. that $\left\{ g_{1},g_{2}\right\} $ was selected from
the critical pair list $B$ in first place w.r.t. some other pair
with non disjoint head terms selected during the execution of the
\textbf{while}-loop.

Moreover, we know that $\spol$ does not reduce to $0$ modulo $G_{out}$
since otherwise it would even have a standard representation w.r.t.
$G_{out}$. Hence, the pair $\left\{ g_{1},g_{2}\right\} $ did not
pass the \textbf{if}-condition following the assignment $M\left(g_{1},g_{2}\right)\leftarrow\mathbf{true}$,
that is, there exists $p\in G$ with 
\[
\thead[p]\mid\mlcm,\mbox{ and }M\left(g_{1},p\right)=M\left(p,g_{2}\right)=\mbox{\textbf{true}}
\]
at that point of the computation. Because the entry $M\left(g_{i},p\right)=\mathbf{true}$,
we conclude that either $g_{i}$ and $p$ have disjoint terms, or
the pair $\left\{ g_{i},p\right\} \in B$ was selected form $B$ at
an earlier stage for $i=1,2$. By our choice of the pair $\left\{ g_{1},g_{2}\right\} $,
the latter could not have happened, and so, $g_{i},p$ have disjoint
terms. Hence, by \nameref{lem:Buchberger's First Criterion} (Lemma
\ref{lem:Buchberger's First Criterion}), $\spol[g_{i}][p]$ has a
$t_{i}$-representation for some $t_{i}<\mlcm[g_{i}][p]$ for $i=1,2,$
and \nameref{prop:Buchberger's Second Criterion} (Proposition \ref{prop:Buchberger's Second Criterion})
provides the desired contradiction. 
\end{proof}
\begin{rem}
\cite{book-bueno-Grobner_Bases} The normal strategy for the selection
of critical pairs from $B$ has shown efficiency in practice. Moreover,
correctness of the above algorithm may be partially regarded as a
consequence of this strategy. To see this, assume that at some point
during computation, the par $\left\{ g_{1},g_{2}\right\} $ is selected
form $B$, and there is, at this time, $p\in G$ with 
\[
\thead[p]\mid\mlcm.
\]

Then Buchberger's second criterion tells us that we should treat the
pairs $\left(p,g_{1}\right)$ and $\left(p,g_{2}\right)$ we do not
have to test the pair $\left(g_{1},g_{2}\right)$. In case $\mlcm[g_{i}][p]$
properly divides $\mlcm$, by the normal strategy we deduce that $\left\{ g_{i},p\right\} $
is not a critical pair in $B$, and so $M\left(g_{i},p\right)\leftarrow$\textbf{true}
by initialization for $i=1,2$. Hence, by removing the normal strategy,
we miss the Buchberger's second criterion. 
\end{rem}

\begin{example}
\label{exa:GROBNERNEW1}Consider the set $F=\left\{ f_{1},f_{2},f_{3}\right\} $
as in Remark \ref{rem: f_1 f_2  f_3}. Then $B=\left\{ \left\{ f_{1},f_{2}\right\} ,\left\{ f_{2},f_{3}\right\} ,\left\{ f_{1},f_{3}\right\} \right\} $
upon initialization and $M\left(f_{i},f_{j}\right)=\mbox{\textbf{false}}$
for $i\neq j$. We have $\thead[f_{1}]=x^{2}y$, $\thead[f_{2}]=x^{3}y$
and $\thead[f_{3}]=x^{3}y$, thus $\mlcm[f_{i}][f_{j}]=x^{3}y$ for
$i\neq j$ and we can select any pair in $B$. Select $\left\{ f_{1},f_{2}\right\} $
and set $B=\left\{ \left\{ f_{2},f_{3}\right\} ,\left\{ f_{1},f_{3}\right\} \right\} $,
$M\left(f_{1},f_{2}\right)=\mbox{\textbf{true}}$. Now, if $p\in G$
is such that $p\mid\mlcm[f_{1}][f_{2}]$, because there is only one
entry of the matrix $M$ set as true, condition $M\left(f_{1},p\right)=M\left(f_{2},p\right)=\mathbf{true}$
cannot be satisfied. Hence, we consider $h\leftarrow\spol[f_{1}][f_{2}]$
and then calculate some $\reduction[G]{}$-normal form $h_{0}$ of
$h$. From Example \ref{exa: f_1 f_7}, we known that $h_{0}=\frac{7}{6}xy+\frac{5}{6}y+2x^{2}-\frac{11}{6}x-\frac{5}{2}\neq0$,
and so $M\left(f_{i},h_{0}\right)=\mbox{\textbf{true}}$ for $1\leq i\leq3$
and $G=\left\{ f_{1},f_{2},f_{3},h_{0}\right\} $. However, no pair
$\left\{ f_{i},h_{0}\right\} $ is added to $B$. 
\end{example}

Now, restarting the while-loop, we select the pair $\left\{ f_{2},f_{3}\right\} $
form $B$, and set $B=\{\left\{ f_{1},f_{3}\right\} $. For the if-condition
we have $h_{0}\in G$ and $\thead[h_{0}]=xy\mid\mlcm[f_{2}][f_{3}]$.
Moreover, $M\left(f_{i},h_{0}\right)=\mathbf{true}$ and so if-condition
is not satisfied. Restarting the while-loop, we select the pair $\left\{ f_{1},f_{3}\right\} $
and set $B=\emptyset$. Now, just like before, the if condition is
not satisfied by letting $p=h_{0}\in G$ and the algorithm terminates.

We see that only one polynomial, $h_{0}$, was added to $F$ in order
to form a Gröbner basis for $\ideal[F]$ whereas as shown is Example
\ref{exa: f_1 f_7}, Buchberger's algorithm introduces four new polynomials
to $F$ constructing a Gröbner basis for $\ideal[F]$ with seven different
polynomials. Clearly, Algorithm \ref{alg:GR=00003D0000D6BNERNEW1}
constitutes an improvement of Buchberger's algorithm (Algorithm \ref{alg:BUCHBERGER}).
\begin{example}
\label{exa:equiv}We now give an example of Algorithm \ref{alg:EQUIV}.
Let $G=F\cup\left\{ h_{0}\right\} $ be the Gröbner basis of the example
above. Then $\reduction[G]{}$ is a locally confluent noetherian reduction
relation that is adequate for $\equiv_{\ideal[G]}$. Now consider
the polynomials $f=x^{2}-y$ and $g=xy+2$, we want to know whether
$\left[f\right]=\left[g\right]$ or not. Because $f$ is already in
$\reduction[G]{}$-normal form, we only have to calculate a $\reduction[G]{}$-normal
form for $g$. By reducing $g\reduction[G]{}g-\frac{6}{7}h_{0}$ we
achieve the polynomial $g'=\frac{1}{7}\left(-12x^{2}-5y+11x+29\right)$
which is in normal form. Because $f\neq g'$, we conclude that $\left[f\right]\neq\left[g\right]$.
In particular, we see that $\left[1\right]$,$\left[x^{n}\right]$
and $\left[y^{n}\right]$ for $n\in\mathbb{N}$ are different classes
w.r.t. $\equiv_{\ideal[G]}$ 
\end{example}


\chapter{Applications and specializations of Gröbner-bases}

In Section \ref{sec:Applications} several applications of Gröbner
theory are given. In Sections \ref{sec:Euclid's-Algorithm} and \ref{sec:Gaussian-elimination}
we see how Gröbner theory is linked with the Euclid's algorithm the
Gaussian elimination. Moreover we show how Gröbner theory generalizes
this concepts and can be used in order to compute them.

\section{Applications\label{sec:Applications}}

This section is a review of the applications of Gröbner theory shown
in \cite{paper1985multidimensional}.

Given an ideal $I$ and provided of a Gröbner basis $G$, two polynomials
$f,g\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ are in the same equivalence
class w.r.t. $\equiv_{I}$ iff $f-g\in I$ iff $f-g\reduction[G]*0$;
this last formula can be be effectively computed by Buchberger's algorithm
and Algorithm \ref{alg:REDPOL} (REDPOL). Then we have the first application
of Gröbner theory. 
\begin{prop}
Let $F$ be a finite subset of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$, let
$I=\ideal[F]$ and assume that $K$ is computable. Then the following
hold:
\begin{enumerate}
\item The membership problem for the ideal $I$ is decidable.\\
 
\item The residue class ring $K\left[\variables[X]\right]/I$ is computable. 
\end{enumerate}
\end{prop}

\begin{proof}
\rom{1} is obvious form the above commented while \rom{2} is consequence
of \rom{1} (see Example \ref{exa: R/I}). 
\end{proof}
\begin{rem}
For the proof of the above result, we can also reason that given a
Gröbner basis $G$ for $\ideal[F]$, $\reduction[G]{}$ is a locally
confluent noetherian reduction relation that is adequate for $\equiv_{I}$
by Theorem \ref{thm:Theorem-Definition}, Theorem \ref{thm: reuction P is notherian}
and Lemma \ref{lem5.26:equiv related with fii}, thus Algorithm \ref{alg:EQUIV}
proofs claim \rom{1}. 
\end{rem}

\begin{prop}
\label{prop:G intersec K=00003D00005B=00003D00005D, book and paper}Let
$K\left[\variables[X]\right]$, $K$ a subfield of $K'$, $n'\geq n$,
and $K'\left[\variables[X][n']\right]$. Then the following hold:
\begin{enumerate}
\item Suppose $\leq$ is a term order on $T'$. Then every Gröbner basis
in $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ w.r.t. the restriction of $\leq$
to $T$ is a Gröbner basis in $K'\left[\variables[X][n']\right]$
w.r.t. $\leq$.\\
 
\item Let $F$ be a finite subset of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ and
denote by 
\[
\mbox{Id}_{K'}\left(F\right)\mbox{ and }\mbox{Id}_{K}\left(F\right)
\]
