the ideals generated by $F$ in $K'\left[\variables[X][n']\right]$
and $K\left[\variables[X]\right],$ respectively. Then 
\[
\mbox{Id}_{K'}\left(F\right)\cap K\left[\variables[X]\right]=\mbox{Id}_{K}\left(F\right).
\]
\end{enumerate}
\end{prop}

\begin{proof}
\rom{1} Let $g_{1},g_{2}\in G$; then $\spol$ is the same in $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
and in $K'\left[\variables[X][n']\right]$ and since $\spol\reduction[G]*0$
in $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$, so it does in $K'\left[\variables[X][n']\right]$.
By Theorem \ref{thm:5.48 Caracterizacion Grobner base con spol},
$G$ is a Gröbner basis in $K'\left[\variables[X][n']\right]$.

\rom{2} The inclusion $\supseteq$ is trivial. Now consider 
\[
f\in\mbox{Id}_{K'}\left(F\right)\cap K\left[\variables[X]\right],
\]
and let $G\subseteq K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ be a Gröbner basis
of $\mbox{Id}_{K}\left(F\right)$ w.r.t. some term order $\leq$.
By \rom{1}, $G$ is Gröbner basis in $K'\left[\variables[X][n']\right]$
w.r.t. any term order on $T'$ whose restriction to $T$ equals $\leq$.
Hence 
\[
\mbox{Id}_{K'}\left(G\right)=\mbox{Id}_{K'}\left(F\right),
\]
and so $f\reduction[G]*0$. Since $f\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
and this reduction takes place in $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$,
we see that $f\in\mbox{Id}_{K}\left(G\right)=\mbox{Id}_{K}\left(F\right)$
by Lemma \ref{lem5.26:equiv related with fii}. 
\end{proof}
In the following, we focus on applying Gröbner bases theory for solving
problems related with ideals of polynomials over a field and the residue
class ring $K\left[\variables[X]\right]/\ideal[F]$ for some finite
set $F\subseteq K\left[\variables[X]\right]$. However we remark that
further motivations and applications, as the uniform word problem
or the computation of Syzygies, \index{uniform word problem}\index{Syzygies}are
in the kernel of this Gröbner basis theory.
\begin{problem}
Given two finite sets $F_{1},F_{2}\subseteq K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
decide whether $\ideal[F_{1}]\subseteq\ideal[F_{2}]$. 
\end{problem}

\begin{proof}[\textbf{Solution}]
 Compute $G_{2}$ a Gröbner basis for $F_{2}$. Then set $\ideal[F_{1}]\subseteq\ideal[F_{2}]$
iff for all $f\in F_{1}$, $f_{1}\reduction[G_{2}]*0$. 
\end{proof}
\begin{problem}
Given two finite sets $F_{1},F_{2}\subseteq K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
decide whether $\ideal[F_{1}]=\ideal[F_{2}]$. 
\end{problem}

\begin{proof}[\textbf{Solution}]
 Clearly application of solution before would lead to solve the equality
problem. Other possible solution is to compute reduced Gröbner bases
for $F_{1}$ and $F_{2}$, then $F_{1}=F_{2}$ iff such bases are
equal. 
\end{proof}
\begin{prop}
\label{prop: problem base of the quatientent ring}Let $G$ be a Gröbner
basis. Let 
\[
B=\left\{ \left[t\right]\mid t\in T\mbox{ and }t\notin\mbox{mult}\left(\thead[G]\right)\right\} .
\]
Then $B$ is a linearly independent vector basis for the vector space
$K\left[\variables[X]\right]/\ideal[G]$. 
\end{prop}

\begin{proof}
By definition $B$ is formed only by classes of terms. Moreover, if
$\left[f\right]\in K\left[\variables[X]/\ideal[G]\right]$ we may
consider that $f$ is in $\reduction[G]{}$-normal form, and so it
cannot be reduced modulo $G,$ that is, if $t\in T\left(f\right)$
then $t\notin\mbox{mult}\left(\thead[G]\right)$, and so $B$ is a
generator system. Assume for contradiction that $B$ is not linearly
independent, then there exists a linear dependence 
\[
c_{1}\cdot\left[t_{1}\right]+...+c_{l}\cdot\left[t_{l}\right]=\left[0\right],
\]
with $c_{i}\neq0$ for some $1\leq i\leq l$ and $\left[t_{j}\right]\in B$
for $j=1,...,l$ . Hence 
\[
0\neq f=c_{1}\cdot t_{1}+...+c_{l}\cdot t_{l}\in\ideal[G],
\]
and so, by Theorem \ref{thm:Theorem-Definition}, $f$ can be reduced
to $0$ modulo $G$. However, $f$ is already in normal form because
non of the $t_{i}$ can be reduced modulo $G$, a contradiction. 
\end{proof}
\begin{example}
\cite{paper1985multidimensional}Consider $G=\left\{ f_{1},f_{2},f_{3},h_{0}\right\} $
as in Example \ref{exa:GROBNERNEW1}, that is 
\begin{align*}
f_{1}= & 3x^{2}y+2xy+y+9x^{2}+5x-3,\\
f_{2}= & 2x^{3}y-x-y+6x^{3}-2x^{2}-3x+3,\\
f_{3}= & x^{3}y+x^{2}y+3x^{3}+2x^{2},\\
h_{0}= & \frac{7}{6}xy+\frac{5}{6}y+2x^{2}-\frac{11}{6}x-\frac{5}{2}.
\end{align*}

By definition, $t\in\mbox{mult}\left(\thead[F]\right)$ iff $\thead[f]$
divides $t$ for some $f\in F$. Moreover, we also know that a term
$x^{e_{1}}y^{e_{2}}$ divides $x^{d_{1}}y^{d_{1}}$ if and only if
$e_{1}\leq d_{1}$ and $e_{2}\leq d_{2}$. Hence $\thead[h_{0}]=xy$
does not divide $1$, $x^{n}y^{0}$ and $x^{0}y^{n}$ for any $n\in\mathbb{N}$.
Because $\thead[h_{0}]$ divides $\thead[f_{i}]$ for $i=1,2,3$,
we conclude that $B=\left\{ \left[1\right],\left[x^{n}\right],\left[y^{n}\right]\mid n\in\mathbb{N}\right\} $
is a linear independent basis of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]/\ideal[G]$. 
\end{example}

\begin{problem}
Find a basis for the vector space $K\left[\variables[X]\right]/\ideal[F]$
and for any two elements $\left[u\right],\left[v\right]\in B$ find
a linear representation of $\left[u\right]\cdot\left[v\right]$ in
terms of the basis elements in $B$ (i.e. find the multiplication
table for $K\left[\variables[X]\right]/\ideal[F]$). 
\end{problem}

\begin{proof}[\textbf{Solution}]
Compute $G$ a Gröbner basis for $\ideal[F]$ and set $B$ as in
proposition above as basis of the residue class ring. For the representation
of $\left[u\right]\cdot\left[v\right]$ w.r.t. $B$, we calculate
a $\reduction[G]{}$-normal form $h$ of $u\cdot v$; thus any term
in $h$ is in $\mbox{mult}\left(\thead[G]\right)$ since $h$ is not
reducible modulo $G$, and so $h\in B$. 
\end{proof}
\begin{problem}
Given a finite set $F\subseteq K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ such
that $K\left[\variables[X]\right]/\ideal[F]$ is a finite dimensional
vectorial space. Given two polynomials $f,h$, find $g$ such that
$fg\equiv_{I}h$ in $K\left[\variables[X]\right]/I$ where $I=\ideal[F]$. 
\end{problem}

\begin{proof}[\textbf{Solution}]
Compute $G$, a Gröbner basis for $\ideal[F].$ Represent $f$ and
$h$ as linear combination of the elements in $B$ and represent $g$
as a linear combination of elements of $B$ (which is finite) with
unknown coefficients. Thus, one gets a finite linear system of equations
for the unknown coefficients, which is solvable iff a solution $g$
exists. 
\end{proof}
\begin{rem}
In particular, we can calculate the inverse of an element $f\in K\left[\variables[X]\right]/\ideal[G]$. 
\end{rem}

\begin{example}
Consider the set $H=G\cup\left\{ x^{3},y^{2}\right\} $ where $F$
is as in Example \ref{exa:GROBNERNEW1}. Then $B=\left\{ \left[1\right],\left[x\right],\left[x^{2}\right],\left[y\right]\right\} $
is a basis of $K\left[\variables[X]\right]/\ideal[H]$. Consider the
polynomials $f=3x^{2}+1$ and $h=3y-2$ in $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$,
we want to find $g$ such that $\left[f\right]\cdot\left[g\right]=\left[h\right]$.
Clearly, $\left[f\right]=3\left[x^{2}\right]+\left[1\right]$ and
$\left[h\right]=3\left[y\right]+-2\left[1\right]$; we write 
\[
g=a_{1}\left[1\right]+a_{2}\left[x\right]+a_{3}\left[x^{2}\right]+a_{4}\left[y\right].
\]
We see that $\left[x^{2}\right]\cdot\left[1\right]=\left[x^{2}\right]$,
$\left[x^{2}\right]\cdot\left[x\right]=\left[x^{3}\right]=\left[0\right]$
since $x^{3}\in\mbox{mult}\left(\thead[H]\right)$, $\left[x^{2}\right]\cdot\left[x^{2}\right]=\left[x^{4}\right]=\left[0\right]$
since $x^{4}\in\mbox{mult}\left(x^{3}\right)$and $\left[x^{2}\right]\cdot\left[y\right]=\left[x^{2}y\right]=\left[0\right]$
since $x^{2}y=\thead[f_{1}]$ . Hence, the equation $\left[f\right]\cdot\left[g\right]=\left[h\right]$
can be written as 
\[
\left(3a_{1}\left[x^{2}\right]\right)+\left(a_{1}\left[1\right]+a_{2}\left[x\right]+a_{3}\left[x^{2}\right]+a_{4}\left[y\right]\right)=+3\left[y\right]+-2\left[1\right],
\]
and so, we have the linear system 
\begin{eqnarray*}
a_{1} & = & -2,\\
a_{2} & = & 0,\\
3a_{1}+a_{3} & = & 0,\\
a_{4} & = & 3.
\end{eqnarray*}
which has unique solution $\left[g\right]$, where $g=3y+6x^{2}-2$. 
\end{example}

\begin{defn}
For a set $F\subseteq K\left[\variables[X]\right]$, we say that $a=\left(\variables[a]\right)$
is a solution for $F$, if $f\left(a\right)=0$ for all $f\in F$. 
\end{defn}

\begin{problem}
\label{prob: finitely many or infinitely many}Given a finite set
$F\subseteq K\left[\variables[X]\right]$, decide whether $F$ has
finitely or infinitely many solutions. 
\end{problem}

\begin{proof}[\textbf{Solution}]
Compute a Gröbner basis $G$ for $\ideal[F]$ w.r.t. some term order.
We claim that $F$ has finitely many solutions iff for all $i=1,...,n$
a power of product of the form $X_{i}^{j_{i}}$ occurs among $\thead[G]$.

It is known that $F$ has finitely many solutions iff the vector space
$K\left[\variables[X]\right]/\ideal[F]$ has finite vector space dimension,
and by problem \ref{prop: problem base of the quatientent ring} we
know that 
\[
B=\left\{ \left[t\right]\mid t\in T\mbox{ and }t\notin\mbox{mult}\left(\thead[G]\right)\right\} ,
\]
is a basis for the residue class ring. If for all $i=1,...,n$, a
power of product of the form $X_{i}^{j_{i}}$ occurs among $\thead[G]$,
then the set $B=\left\{ \left[X_{i}\right]^{j}\mid0\leq j<j_{i},i=1,...,n\right\} $
is finite. Conversely, if condition above does not occur for some
$1\leq i\leq n$, then $\left\{ \left[X_{i}^{j}\right]\mid j\in\mathbb{N}\right\} \subseteq B$
since otherwise, $X_{i}^{j}\in\mbox{mult}\left(\thead[G]\right)$
for some $j$, and so $X_{i}^{j'}\in\thead[G]$ for some $j'\leq j$. 
\end{proof}
\begin{prop}
Let $G\subseteq K\left[\variables[X]\right]$ be a Gröbner basis w.r.t.
the inverse lexicographical ordering. Then 
\[
\ideal[G]\cap K\left[\variables[X][i]\right]=\mbox{Id}\left(G\cap K\left[\variables[X][i]\right]\right).
\]

for $i=1,...,n$ where the ideal on right side is formed in $K\left[\variables[X][i]\right]$. 
\end{prop}

\begin{proof}
If $g\in\mbox{Id}\left(G\right)\cap K\left[\variables[X][i]\right]$,
then $g$ can be reduced to $0$ modulo $G$. Moreover, since we are
using the inverse lexicographical ordering, $g$ can be reduced to
zero subtracting $b_{j}\cdot u_{j}\cdot g_{j}$ where $b_{j}\in K$,
$u_{j}$ is a monomial in $K\left[\variables[X][i]\right]$ and $g_{j}\in G$
is such that $\thead[g_{j}]$ contains only the indeterminates form
the set $\left\{ \variables[X][i]\right\} $. Hence all power products
occurring in $g_{j}$ contains only indeterminates in this set (just
like $u_{j}$). Thus, we obtain a representation for $g$ of the form
\[
g=\sum b_{j}\cdot u_{j}g_{j},
\]
which shows that $T\left(g\right)\subseteq T\left(\variables[X][i]\right)$.
Thus, we may conclude that $g\in\mbox{Id}\left(G\cap K\left[\variables[X][i]\right]\right)$. 
\end{proof}
\begin{problem}
\label{prob:Find p}Given a Gröbner basis $G$ in $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$,
such that $G$ has finitely many solutions. Find $p\in\ideal[G]\cap K\left[X_{1}\right]$
with minimal degree provided that $\ideal[G]\cap K\left[X_{1}\right]\neq\emptyset$. 
\end{problem}

\begin{proof}[\textbf{Solution}]
 First recall that $X_{1}$ is set for convenience, that is, we can
find the polynomial with minimal degree in $\ideal[G]\cap K\left[X_{i}\right]$
for very $i$ provided that $\ideal[G]\cap K\left[X_{i}\right]\neq\emptyset$.

The calculus of the minimal polynomial $p$ can be carried out by
the following algorithm: 
\begin{algorithm}[H]
\begin{lyxlist}{00.00.0000}
\item [{\caption{MINIPOL\label{alg:MINIPOL}}
}] ~
\item [{\textbf{Specification:}}] $p\leftarrow\mbox{UNIPOL\ensuremath{\left(G\right)}}$
\item [{\textbf{Given:}}] a Gröbner basis $G$ in $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
\item [{\textbf{Find:}}] a polynomial $p$ in $G\cap K\left[X_{1}\right]$
with minimal degree
\item [{$i=1$}] ~
\item [{\textbf{repeat}}] $p_{i}=\mbox{a normal form of \ensuremath{X_{1}^{i}} modulo \ensuremath{G}}$
\begin{lyxlist}{00.00.0000}
\item [{$i=i+1$}] ~
\end{lyxlist}
\item [{\textbf{until}}] there exists $\left(d_{0},...,d_{i-1}\right)\neq\left(0\right)$
with $d_{0}+d_{1}p_{1}+...+d_{i-1}p_{i-1}=0$
\item [{$r=i-1$}] ~
\item [{\textbf{return}~$p=\polinomio[d][r][X_{1}]$}] ~
\item [{\textbf{end}~MINIPOL}] ~
\end{lyxlist}
\end{algorithm}

Because $G$ has finitely many solutions, no scalar $\lambda\in K$
is in $G$, and so every polynomial $p\in\ideal[G]\cap K\left[X_{1}\right]$
has degree greater or equal than one. With this,\textit{ Correctness}
should be clear whereas \textit{Termination }is consequence of $\ideal[G]\cap K\left[X_{1}\right]\neq\emptyset$. 
\end{proof}
\begin{problem}
Given a finite set $F\subseteq K\left[\variables[X]\right]$, find
all solutions of $F$ provided that $F$ has finitely many solutions. 
\end{problem}

\begin{proof}[\textbf{Solution}]
Compute a Gröbner basis $G$ a w.r.t. the inverse lexicographical
order. Because $G$ has finitely many solutions, as argued in Problem
\ref{prob: finitely many or infinitely many}, $X_{i}^{j_{i}}$ occurs
among $\thead[G]$ for some $j_{i}\in\mathbb{N}$ for all $i=1,...,n$.
In particular $\ideal[G]\cap K\left[X_{1}\right]\neq\emptyset$.

Now, we are under the hypothesis of the previous problem and the calculus
of the solutions can be carried out by the following algorithm:

\begin{algorithm}[H]
\caption{SOLUTIONS\label{alg:SOLUTIONS}}

\begin{lyxlist}{00.00.0000}
\item [{\textbf{Specification:}}] \textbf{$S\leftarrow\mbox{SOLUTIONS}\left(G\right)$}
\item [{\textbf{Given:}}] a Gröbner basis $G$ in $K\left[\variables[X]\right]$
\item [{\textbf{Find:}}] all solutions of $G$
\item [{\textbf{begin}}] ~
\item [{$p=\mathbf{MINPOL}\left(G\right)$}] ~
\item [{$S_{1}=\left\{ \left(a\right)\mid p\left(a\right)=0\right\} $}] ~
\item [{\textbf{for}}] \textbf{$i=1,...,n-1$ do}
\begin{lyxlist}{00.00.0000}
\item [{$S_{i+1}=\emptyset$}] ~
\item [{\textbf{for~all}}] \textbf{$\left(\variables[a][i]\right)\in S_{i}$
do}
\begin{lyxlist}{00.00.0000}
\item [{$H\leftarrow\left\{ g'\left(\variables[a][i],X_{i+1}\right)\mid g'\in G'\right\} $}] where
\item [{~~~$G'=G\cap K\left[\variables[X][i+1]\right]\setminus K\left[\variables[X][i]\right]$}] ~
\item [{$p=\gcd\left(H\right)$}] ~
\item [{$S_{i+1}=S_{i+1}\cup\left\{ \left(\variables[a][i],a\right)\mid p\left(a\right)=0\right\} $}] ~
\end{lyxlist}
\item [{\textbf{end}}] ~
\end{lyxlist}
\item [{\textbf{end}}] ~
\item [{\textbf{return~$S_{n}$}}] ~
\item [{\textbf{end}~SOLUTIONS}] ~
\end{lyxlist}
\end{algorithm}

\textit{Termination }of the algorithm is clear. Let's check \textit{Correctness}.
If $a=\left(\variables[a]\right)$ is a solution of $G$, we proof
by induction that $\left(\variables[a][i]\right)\in S_{i}$ for $i=1,...,n$.
For $i=1$, since $p\in\ideal[G]$ we have $p\left(a_{1}\right)=0$,
and so $a_{1}\in S_{1}$. Now we assume the result is true for $i$,
we show that $\left(\variables[a][i+1]\right)\in S_{i+1}$. Because
$a$ is a solution of $G$, there exist $g\in G$ with $\thead[g]=X_{i+1}^{j_{i+1}}$
for some $j_{i+1}\in\mathbb{N}$ (see Problem \ref{prob: finitely many or infinitely many}).
Because $G$ is Gröbner basis w.r.t. the inverse lexicographical order,
the variables $X_{j}$ with $j>i+1$ are not in $g$, and so $g$
can be seen as a polynomial in $G'$. Hence $g\left(\variables[a][i],X_{i+1}\right)\in H$
and so $p\left(X_{i+1}\right)=\gcd\left(H\right)\mid g\left(\variables[a][i],X_{i+1}\right)$.
Because $a$ is a solution of $G$, $g\left(\variables[a][i+1]\right)=0$
since $g\in G'$, and so $p\left(a_{i+1}\right)=0$, that is, $\left(\variables[a][i+1]\right)\in S_{i+1}$.
We have shown that algorithm above computes the all the solutions
of $G$. Now, if $f\in F$, then $f\in\ideal[F]=\ideal[G]$ and so
$f=\lineal[\lambda][g][m]$ for some $\lambda_{i}\in K$, $g_{i}\in G$.
Hence if $g\left(a\right)=0$ for all $g\in G$, then $f\left(a\right)=0$.
We see that all the solutions of $G$ are solutions of $F$, and repeating
the argument for $G$, we conclude that the solutions of $F$ and
$G$ are the same. 
\end{proof}
\begin{rem}
The above algorithm is limited by the difficulty of finding the roots
of a polynomial, however this is an intrinsic problem of the solvability
if polynomial equations. Moreover, the determination of $p$ as the
polynomial in $K\left[X_{1}\right]$ is non deterministic since it
can be computed by Problem \ref{prob:Find p}. 
\end{rem}

\begin{example}
Consider $F$ as in Remark \ref{rem: f_1 f_2  f_3}. We know by Example
\ref{exa:reduced grobner basis} that $G=\left\{ y+x^{2}-\frac{3}{2}x-3,\,\,x^{3}-\frac{5}{2}x^{2}-\frac{5}{2}x\right\} $
is a reduced Gröbner basis for $\ideal[F]$ w.r.t. the inverse lexicographical
order. Application of Algorithm \ref{alg:MINIPOL} produced $p=x^{3}-\frac{5}{2}x^{2}-\frac{5}{2}x$
as result. To see this, note that $x,x^{2}$ are in $\reduction[G]{}$-normal
form, and so, the equation $d_{0}+d_{1}x+d_{2}x^{2}=0$ only has trivial
solution $d_{0}=d_{1}=d_{2}=0$. Then $x^{3}$ is the first power
of $x$ that is reducible modulo $G$, and $p_{3}=\frac{5}{2}x^{2}+\frac{5}{2}x$
is a normal form for $x^{3}$. Now the equation $d_{0}+d_{1}x+d_{2}x^{2}+d_{3}p_{3}=0$
has as solution $d_{0}=0,d_{1}=-\frac{5}{2},d_{3}=-\frac{5}{2}$ and
$d_{3}=1$. Hence $p=x^{3}-\frac{5}{2}x^{2}-\frac{5}{2}x$ is a polynomial
in $\ideal[G]\cap K\left[x\right]$ with minimal degree.

Now, we have $S_{1}=\left\{ 0,\frac{5}{4}-\frac{\sqrt{65}}{4},\frac{5}{4}+\frac{\sqrt{65}}{4}\right\} $
and $G'=\left\{ y+x^{2}-\frac{3}{2}x-3\right\} $. Hence, for each
root of $p$, we have $H_{0}=\left\{ y-3\right\} ,$ $H_{\frac{5}{4}-\frac{\sqrt{65}}{4}}=\left\{ y-\frac{\sqrt{65}}{4}+\frac{3}{4}\right\} $
and $H_{\frac{5}{4}+\frac{\sqrt{65}}{4}}=\left\{ y+\frac{\sqrt{65}}{4}+\frac{3}{4}\right\} $.
Because $H$ has only one polynomial $p=\gcd\left(H\right)$ is its
unique polynomial and so 
\[
S_{2}=\left\{ \left(a,b\right)\mid a\in\left\{ 0,\frac{5}{4}\pm\frac{\sqrt{65}}{4}\right\} ,b\in\left\{ 3,\pm\frac{\sqrt{65}}{4}-\frac{3}{4}\right\} \right\} ,
\]
are all the solutions of $G$. 
\end{example}


\section{Euclid's Algorithm\label{sec:Euclid's-Algorithm}}

The following is based on \cite[pg. 95, Ex. 11]{book_profesor_Ideals_varieties_and_algorithms}.

We show that the result of the Euclid's algorithm in $K\left[x\right]$
for two polynomials $f,g\in K\left[x\right]$ is a reduced Gröbner
basis for $\ideal[\left\{ f,g\right\} ]$ (after reducing the basis).

First, we describe the connection between division and Euclidean algorithms
in $K\left[x\right]$ and Gröbner bases.

Given two polynomials $f,g\in K\left[x\right]$ with $g\neq0$, by
Theorem \ref{thm:Division algorithm K x} there exist unique polynomials
$q,r\in K\left[x\right]$ such that $f=qg+r$ with $r=0$ or $r\neq0$
and $\deg\left(r\right)<\deg\left(g\right)$. We now use this fact
to show that the reduction relation $\reduction[g]{}$ in $K\left[x\right]$
has unique normal form using the division algorithm (Theorem \ref{thm:Division algorithm K x}).
Since $\reduction[g]{}$ is noetherian, every polynomial $f\in K\left[x\right]$
has an least one normal form $r$, and we can find a finite $\rightarrow$-chain
\[
f\reduction[g]{}f-q_{1}g\reduction[g]{}f-q_{1}g-q_{2}g\reduction[g]{}...\reduction[g]{}\underbrace{f-q_{1}g-...-q_{n}g}_{=r},
\]
for some monomials $q_{i}\in M$. Because $r$ cannot be reduced modulo
$g$, $r=0$ or $r\neq0$ and $\deg\left(r\right)<\deg\left(g\right)$.
Therefore, given that $f=\left(\variables[q][][+]\right)g+r$, we
see that $q=\variables[q][][+]$ and $r$ are the quotient and the
remainder and so they are uniquely determined by $f,g$. Therefore,
uniqueness of the remainder $r$ implies $\reduction[g]{}$ has unique
normal form.

If we have the finite set $G=\left\{ f,g\right\} $, then we may consider
to reduce it. To do so Algorithm \ref{alg:REDUCTION} (REDUCTION)
may be applied to the univariate case $K\left[x\right]$, but as said
before it specializes to the Euclid's algorithm.

\textbf{Euclid's Algorithm:} Given two polynomials $f,g\in K\left[x\right]$,
with $g\neq0$ and $\deg\left(f\right)\geq\deg\left(g\right)$ we
perform the division of $f$ by $g$. Then 
\[
f=q_{1}g+r_{1},
\]
where $q_{1},r_{1}$ are the quotient and the remainder of the division.
If $r\neq0$, because $\deg\left(r\right)<\deg\left(g\right)$ we
can perform the division of $g$ by $r_{1}$, and we have 
\[
g=q_{2}r_{1}+r_{2},
\]
where $q_{2},r_{2}$ are the quotient and the remainder. If we set
$i=1$, division of $r_{i}$ by $r_{i+1}$ may be performed and a
new remainder $r_{i+2}$ may be taking in account, and division of
$r_{i+1}$ by $r_{i+1}$ may proceed if $r_{i+1}\neq0$. Repetition
of this process leads to a chain of remainders which is finite since
$0\leq\deg\left(r_{i}\right)<\deg\left(r_{i-1}\right)$. Say we obtain
\begin{eqnarray*}
f & = & q_{1}g+r_{1},\\
g & = & q_{2}r_{1}+r_{2},\\
r & = & q_{3}r_{2}+r_{3},\\
\cdot\cdot\cdot & \cdot\cdot\cdot & \cdot\cdot\cdot\\
r_{k-2} & = & q_{k}r_{k-1}+r_{k},\\
r_{k-1} & = & q_{k+1}r_{k}+r_{k+1}.
\end{eqnarray*}

Because division of $r_{k}$ by $r_{k+1}$ cannot be performed, $r_{k+1}=0$
and $r_{k}$ divides $r_{k-1}$. Euclid's theorem asserts that $\gcd\left(f,g\right)=\gcd\left(g,r_{1}\right)$
if $r_{1}\neq0$, and so $\gcd\left(f,g\right)=\gcd\left(r_{i},r_{i+1}\right)$
for all $i<k$. In particular $\gcd\left(f,g\right)=\gcd\left(r_{k-1},r_{k}\right)=r_{k}$.

If $G=\left\{ r_{k}\right\} $ our previous claim stands that $\ideal[\left\{ f,g\right\} ]=\ideal[G]$
and $G$ is a reduced Gröbner basis.

In order to link Euclid's algorithm with Gröbner-bases theory we give
the following version of Euclid's algorithm.

Recall that we write $r_{i-1}\reduction[r_{i}]*r_{i+1}$ where $r_{i+1}$
is a $\reduction[r_{i}]{}$-normal form meaning that we perform the
division of $r_{i-1}$ by $r_{i}\neq0$ with residue $r_{i+1}$.

\begin{algorithm}[H]
\caption{EUCLID'S}

\begin{lyxlist}{00.00.0000}
\item [{\textbf{Specification:}}] $G\leftarrow\mbox{EUCLID'S}\left(f,g\right)$
\item [{\textbf{Given:}}] \textbf{$f,g\in K\left[x\right]$}, with $g\neq0$
and $\deg\left(f\right)\geq\deg\left(g\right)$
\item [{\textbf{Find:}}] $G=\left\{ r_{k}\right\} $ so that $\left\{ f,g\right\} $
reduces to $G$
\item [{\textbf{begin}}] ~
\item [{$r_{-1}=f,\,r_{0}=g$}] ~
\item [{$i=0$}] ~
\item [{\textbf{while}}] \textbf{$r_{i}\neq0$ then}\\
 \textbf{$G=\left\{ r_{i-1},r_{i}\right\} $}\\
 Find $r_{i+1}$ in $\reduction[r_{i}]{}$-normal form so that $r_{i-1}\reduction[r_{i}]*r_{i+1}$\\
 $i=i+1$
\item [{\textbf{end}}] ~
\item [{$G=\left\{ r_{k}\right\} $}] ~
\item [{\textbf{return($G$)}}] ~
\item [{\textbf{end}~EUCLID'S}] ~
\end{lyxlist}
\end{algorithm}

\textit{Termination }of the algorithm is clear.

\textit{Correctness: }As before, say the \textbf{while}-loop ends
at $i=k+1$ with $G=\left\{ r_{k-1},r_{k}\right\} $ and denote by
$G_{i}$ the set $G$ during the $i+1$th run of the loop. We claim
that the upgrading of $G$ consist in a reduction of $G$, to see
this note that $r_{i-1}\in G_{i}$ is reduced to $r_{i+1}$ using
$r_{i}\in G_{i}\setminus\left\{ r_{i-1}\right\} $. Now, actualization
of $G_{i}$ consists in removing the polynomial $r_{i-1}$ and joining
$r_{i+1}$. Therefore $G_{0}$ reduces to $G_{k}$ and since upon
termination $r_{k+1}=0$ and $G_{k}$ reduces to $G_{k+1}=\left\{ r_{k}\right\} $,
$G_{k}$ also reduces to $G_{k+1}$.

Because each run of the loop produces a reduction of $G$, $\ideal[G]$
is an invariant of the loop and since upon initialization $G_{0}=\left\{ f,g\right\} $,
then $\ideal[\left\{ f,g\right\} ]=\ideal[G_{k}]=\ideal[G_{k+1}]$.
Now the claim $G_{k+1}$ is a reduced Gröbner basis for $\ideal[\left\{ f,g\right\} ]$
immediately follows from uniqueness of the remainder in $K\left[x\right]$.

As consequence of our first claim, given that any two polynomials
$f,g$$\in K\left[x\right]$ the set $\left\{ f,g\right\} $ may be
reduced to a set with only one element. Therefore, any finite set
$G$ can be reduced to a set with a unique element. Since $K\left[x\right]$
is noetherian, every ideal $I$ is finitely generated and so $I$
has a reduced Gröbner basis with a single element. Moreover, $K\left[x\right]$
is a principal ideal domain.

If we relate the division algorithm which asserts there exists of
unique residues as the equivalent of Gröbner bases existence in $K\left[x\right]$,
Euclid's algorithm should be related with Buchberger's algorithm for
constructing such a basis. 
\begin{example}
Given $f=\left(x-1\right)\left(x^{2}-1\right)=x^{3}-x^{2}-x+1$ and
$g=\left(x-1\right)x^{2}=x^{3}-x^{2}$. If we set $G_{0}=\left\{ f,g\right\} $
the above algorithm may start by reducing $f$ modulo $g$; in particular,
we have $f\reduction[g]{}f'=x-1$ and $G_{1}=\left\{ f',g\right\} $.
Now $g$ can be reduced by to zero by means of $f'$, and so the while-loop
ends and $G_{2}=\left\{ f'=x-1\right\} $ is the reduced Gröbner-bases
for $\ideal[\left\{ f,g\right\} ],$that is, $x-1=\gcd\left(f,g\right)$. 
\end{example}


\section{Gaussian elimination\label{sec:Gaussian-elimination}}

The following is based on \cite[pg. 95, Exercise 10]{book_profesor_Ideals_varieties_and_algorithms}.

Let $A=\left(a_{ij}\right)$ be a $n\times m$ matrix with entries
in $K$ and let $f_{i}=a_{i1}x_{1}+...+a_{in}x_{n}$ be the linear
polynomials in $K\left[\variables[x]\right]$ determined by the rows
of $A$. Then consider $I=\mbox{Id}\left(\variables[f]\right)$ and
the lexicographical order in $T$. Now let $B\left(b_{ij}\right)$
be the row echelon matrix determined by $A$ and let $\variables[g][t]$
be the polynomials determined by the non-zero rows of $B$. We now
show that $G=\left\{ \variables[g][t]\right\} $ is a reduced Gröbner
basis of $I$ w.r.t the lexicographical order.

First, remark that by echelon matrix we refer to the matrix obtained
after performing the Gauss elimination so to obtain an upper triangular
matrix, and then perform again the row elimination, now, from down
to top.

Row operation in the Gaussian elimination can be of three different
types, 
\begin{enumerate}
\item multiply a row by a scalar $a\in K$, 
\item swap row $i$ with row $j$, and 
\item adding a row $j$ to a row $i$ multiplied by a scalar $a\in K$. 
\end{enumerate}
The first case, applied to row $i$, produces the family of polynomials
$F=\left\{ f_{1},...,af_{i},...,f_{n}\right\} $ and it is clear that
$I=\ideal[F]$. In the second case, we have the family of polynomials
$F=\left\{ f_{1},...,f_{i-1},f_{j},f_{i},...,f_{j-1},f_{i},f_{i+1},...,f_{n}\right\} $
and again $I=\ideal[F]$. Finally, the third case gives us the family
$F=\left\{ f_{1},...,f_{i}-af_{j},...,f_{n}\right\} $. We claim that
$I=\ideal[F]$. The relation $I\subseteq\ideal[F]$ follows easily
from the fact that 
\begin{eqnarray*}
g & = & \lineal[a][f]\\
 & = & a_{1}f_{1}+...+a_{i}(f_{i}-af_{j}+af_{j})+...+f_{n}\\
 & = & a_{1}f_{1}+...+a_{i}\left(f_{i}-af_{j}\right)+...+\left(a_{j}-a_{i}a\right)f_{i}+...+f_{n}.
\end{eqnarray*}

Conversely, if $g\in I$ then 
\begin{eqnarray*}
g & = & a_{1}f_{1}+...+a_{i}(f_{i}-af_{j})+...+f_{n}\\
 & = & a_{1}f_{1}+...+a_{i}f_{i}+...+\left(a_{j}-a_{i}a\right)f_{j}+...+f_{n}
\end{eqnarray*}
and $\ideal[F]\subseteq I$.

Because the family of polynomials $G=\left\{ \variables[g][t]\right\} $
has been obtained from $\left\{ \variables[f]\right\} $ by performing
these operations, we conclude that $\mathit{I=\ideal[G]}$.

To see that $G$ is a Gröbner basis, we prove that $\spol[g_{i}][g_{j}]\reduction[G]*0$
for all $g_{i},g_{j}\in G$. Because $g_{i},g_{j}$ are defined by
the echelon matrix $B$, we can write $g_{i}=x_{r}+g_{i}'$ and $g_{j}=x_{k}+g_{j}'$
where $g_{i}',g_{j}'$ are linear polynomials in $K\left[x_{r+1},...,x_{n}\right]$
and $K\left[x_{k+1},...,x_{n}\right]$ respectively. Now, $\spol[g_{i}][g_{j}]=x_{k}x_{r}+x_{k}g_{i}'-x_{r}x_{k}-x_{r}g_{j}'=x_{k}g_{i}'-x_{r}g_{j}'$,
and we write $g_{i}'=\suma[t][1][\alpha]m_{t}$ as sums of monomials
with $\variables[m][\alpha][>]$. Because $\thead[g_{j}]=x_{k}$,
we may reduce $\spol[g_{i}][g_{j}]\reduction[g_{j}]{}\spol[g_{i}][g_{j}]-m_{1}g_{j}$
by eliminating $x_{k}\thead[g_{i}']=x_{k}\thead[m_{1}]$. Repeating
this process up to $m_{\alpha}$ we get 
\begin{eqnarray*}
\spol[g_{i}][g_{j}] & \reduction[g_{j}]* & \spol[g_{i}][g_{j}]-m_{1}g_{j}-...-m_{\alpha}g_{j}\\
 & = & \spol[g_{i}][g_{j}]-\left(\variables[m][\alpha][+]\right)g_{j}\\
 & = & \spol[g_{i}][g_{j}]-g_{i}'\left(x_{k}+g_{j}'\right)\\
 & = & -x_{r}g_{j}'-g_{i}'g_{j}'.
\end{eqnarray*}
By repeating the argument for $-x_{r}g_{j}'-g_{i}'g_{j}'$ using $-x_{r}$
instead $x_{k}$ and $g_{i}$ instead of $g_{j}$, we have 
\begin{eqnarray*}
-x_{r}g_{j}'-g_{i}'g_{j}' & \reduction[g_{i}]* & \left(-x_{r}g_{j}'-g_{i}'g_{j}'\right)-\left(-g_{j}'g_{i}\right)=-x_{r}g_{j}'-g_{i}'g_{j}'+g_{j}'x_{r}+g_{j}'g_{i}'=0.
\end{eqnarray*}
So far, we have proved that $\spol[g_{i}][g_{j}]\reduction[\left\{ g_{i},g_{j}\right\} ]*0$
for every pair $g_{i}\neq g_{j}\in G$, that is, $G$ is a Gröbner
basis.

Furthermore, $G$ is reduced. Because we are dealing with linear equations,
no term of the form $x_{i}x_{j}\in T\left(G\right)$. Then, if $g_{i}\reduction[g_{j}]{}h$
by eliminating $t$, $t=\thead[g_{j}]$ and the claim follows since
such reductions are equivalent to subtracting row $j$ to row $i$
multiplied by the appropriate factor in $K$, which cannot happen
since the polynomials in $G$ are defined by the non-zero rows of
$B$, the echelon matrix of $A$.
